Sanhedrin



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Cases concerning <b>monetary law</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges. Cases concerning <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges. Cases concerning <b>damage</b> that one is responsible for because he or his property caused the damage are adjudicated by three judges as well. Likewise, cases concerning payment for <b>half the damage,</b> which is paid in the event that an ox whose owner has not been warned that it gored more than two times gores another animal (see Exodus 21:35); cases concerning <b>payment of double</b> the principal by a thief who was caught stealing (see Exodus 22:3); <b>and</b> cases concerning <b>payment of four or five</b> times the principal by a thief who slaughtered or sold a stolen ox or a lamb (see Exodus 21:37) are all adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges.
Cases concerning <b>one who rapes or one who seduces</b> a virgin girl, and must therefore pay the girl’s father fifty silver shekels (see Deuteronomy 22:29, Exodus 22:15); <b>and</b> cases concerning <b>a defamer</b> who falsely asserts that his wife was not a virgin when she married him, and brings false witnesses who testify that she committed adultery while betrothed to him and who must therefore pay the girl’s father one hundred silver shekels as well as receive lashes (see Deuteronomy 22:13–19): All of these are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Cases concerning <b>a defamer</b> are adjudicated <b>by</b> a court of <b>twenty-three</b> judges, which is the type of court authorized to judge cases of capital law, <b>because</b> this case <b>includes</b> the possibility of becoming a case of <b>capital law.</b> The husband brings witnesses that his wife committed adultery. If she is found guilty, she is liable to receive the death penalty. This punishment applies to the witnesses if they are exposed as conspiring witnesses.
Cases concerning the violation of prohibitions that render one liable to receive <b>lashes</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges. The Sages <b>stated in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> Cases concerning lashes are adjudicated <b>by twenty-three</b> judges.
The <b>intercalation of the month</b> is performed <b>by</b> a panel of <b>three</b> judges. The <b>intercalation of the year,</b> meaning the decision to add an extra month to the year when necessary, is also decided <b>by</b> a panel of <b>three</b> judges; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The deliberations <b>begin with three</b> judges, <b>and they debate</b> the matter <b>with five</b> judges, <b>and they conclude</b> the matter <b>with seven</b> judges, due to the significance of the decision. <b>And</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel concedes that <b>if they concluded</b> the matter <b>with</b> only <b>three</b> judges, the intercalation is valid and it is <b>a leap</b> year.
Both the <b>laying of hands by the Sages and the breaking of the heifer’s neck</b> in a case where a person was found murdered and it is not known who killed him (see Deuteronomy 21:1–9) are performed in front of a panel <b>of three</b> judges; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> These rituals are performed in front <b>of five</b> judges. Both <b><i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> the ritual through which the <i>yavam</i>, a surviving brother of a married man who died without sons, frees the <i>yevama</i>, the widow, of her levirate bond in a case where the <i>yavam</i> does not wish to marry the <i>yevama</i> (see Deuteronomy 25:5–10), <b>and the refusal</b> of a girl before reaching majority to remain married to the man to whom her mother or brother married her off, are performed before a court <b>of three</b> judges.
The <i>halakha</i> concerning fruit of a fourth-year sapling and second-tithe produce is that they are to be brought to Jerusalem and eaten there. If this is impractical, the produce can be redeemed and the redemption money brought to Jerusalem, where it is used to purchase food and drink. Valuation of fruit of <b>a fourth-year sapling or second-tithe</b> produce in cases <b>where their value is not known</b> is performed <b>by three</b> judges. The valuation of <b>consecrated</b> property for purposes of redemption is performed <b>by three</b> judges, and <b>the valuations that are movable property</b> (see Leviticus 27:1–8) are performed <b>by three</b> judges. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One of</b> the three judges must be <b>a priest.</b>
<b>And the</b> valuation of consecrated <b>land</b> is performed by <b>nine</b> judges <b>and,</b> in addition, one <b>priest. And</b> the valuation of <b>a person</b> for the purpose of a vow is performed in <b>a similar manner to</b> that of land.
§ Cases of <b>capital law</b> are judged <b>by twenty-three</b> judges. <b>An animal that copulated with a person and an animal that was the object of bestiality</b> are judged <b>by twenty-three</b> judges, <b>as it is stated:</b> “And if a woman approaches any animal to lie with it, <b>you shall kill the woman and the animal”</b> (Leviticus 20:16), <b>and it states:</b> “And if a man lies with an animal, he shall be put to death <b>and you shall kill the animal”</b> (Leviticus 20:15). In cases of bestiality, the verse juxtaposes the execution of the animal to the execution of the person, and therefore the case of the animal is adjudicated in the same way as cases of capital law.
Similarly, <b>an ox that is</b> to be <b>stoned</b> because it killed a person is judged <b>by twenty-three</b> judges, <b>as it is stated:</b> “But if the ox was wont to gore in time past, and warning has been given to its owner, but he did not guard it and it kills a man or a woman <b>the ox shall be stoned and also its owner shall be put to death”</b> (Exodus 21:29). From this verse it is derived that <b>just as</b> the manner of <b>the death of the owner, so is</b> the manner of <b>the death of the ox.</b> The same <i>halakha</i> applies in the case of <b>a wolf or a lion, a bear or a leopard, or a cheetah, or a snake</b> that killed a person: <b>Their death</b> is decreed <b>by twenty-three</b> judges. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> these dangerous animals do not need to be brought to court; rather, <b>anyone who kills them first merits</b> the performance of a mitzva. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Their death</b> is decreed <b>by twenty-three</b> judges.
§ The court <b>judges</b> cases involving an entire <b>tribe</b> that sinned, <b>or a false prophet</b> (see Deuteronomy 18:20–22), <b>or a High Priest</b> who transgressed a prohibition that carries a possible death sentence, <b>only on the basis of a court of seventy-one</b> judges, i.e., the Great Sanhedrin. <b>And</b> the king may <b>bring</b> the nation <b>out to an optional war,</b> i.e., a war that was not mandated by the Torah and is not a war of defense, <b>only on the basis of a court of seventy-one</b> judges. <b>They may extend the city</b> of Jerusalem <b>or the courtyards</b> of the Temple <b>only on the basis of a court of seventy-one</b> judges. <b>And</b> they may <b>appoint</b> a lesser <b>Sanhedrin</b> of twenty-three judges <b>for the tribes only on the basis of a court of seventy-one</b> judges.
A city <b>may be designated</b> as <b>an idolatrous city,</b> i.e., a city whose residents all practice idolatry, and therefore according to Torah law all the residents must be killed and the city must be destroyed (see Deuteronomy 13:13–19), <b>only in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>a court of seventy-one</b> judges. Additionally, the court <b>may not designate</b> a city as <b>an idolatrous city</b> if it is <b>on the frontier,</b> close to the borders of Eretz Yisrael, <b>and three</b> adjoining cities may <b>not</b> be designated as idolatrous cities. <b>But</b> the court <b>may designate one</b> city, <b>or two</b> adjoining cities, as idolatrous cities.
§ With regard to the number of judges in the different courts the mishna presents a halakhic midrash: The <b>Great Sanhedrin was</b> composed <b>of seventy-one</b> judges, <b>and a lesser</b> Sanhedrin was composed <b>of twenty-three. From where</b> is it derived <b>that the Great</b> Sanhedrin <b>was</b> composed <b>of seventy-one</b> judges? <b>As it is stated: “Gather Me seventy men of the Elders of Israel,</b> whom you know to be the Elders of the people and officers over them, and bring them into the Tent of Meeting, and they shall stand there with you” (Numbers 11:16), <b>and</b> together with <b>Moses at the head of</b> this body, there are a total of seventy-one. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Moses was indeed at the head of the body, but he is not counted as part of the group. Consequently, a future Great Sanhedrin modeled after these Elders is to be composed of <b>seventy</b> judges.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that a lesser</b> Sanhedrin <b>is</b> composed <b>of twenty-three</b> judges? <b>As it is stated: “And the congregation shall judge</b> between the assailant and the avenger…<b>and the congregation shall save</b> the manslayer from the hands of the avenger” (Numbers 35:24–25). Therefore, there must be <b>a congregation,</b> which consists of at least ten judges, that <b>judges</b> the accused and attempts to convict him, <b>and</b> there must be <b>a congregation,</b> also consisting of at least ten judges, which attempts to <b>save</b> the accused by finding him innocent. Together, <b>there are twenty</b> judges <b>here.</b>
Before proceeding to derive the requirement for the final three judges, the mishna clarifies: <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that a congregation</b> consists <b>of</b> at least <b>ten</b> men? <b>As it is stated</b> concerning the spies: <b>“How long shall I bear with this evil congregation</b> that keep complaining about me?” (Numbers 14:27) There were twelve spies; <b>excluding Joshua and Caleb,</b> who did not complain, there would be ten men who are called: A congregation. Accordingly, the verses describing a congregation that attempts to convict the accused and a congregation that attempts to acquit him together add up to twenty judges.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>to bring three more</b> judges to the court? <b>From the implication of that</b> which <b>is stated: “You shall not follow a multitude to convict”</b> (Exodus 23:2), <b>I</b> would <b>derive that</b> I may not convict a person on the basis of a majority but <b>I should follow</b> the majority <b>to exonerate. If so, why is it stated</b> in the same verse: <b>“To incline after a multitude,”</b> from which it can be understood that the majority is followed in all cases? In order to resolve the apparent contradiction it must be explained: <b>Your inclination</b> after the majority <b>to exonerate is not like your inclination</b> after the majority <b>to convict. Your inclination</b> after the majority <b>to exonerate</b> can result in a verdict <b>by</b> a majority of <b>one</b> judge. But <b>your inclination</b> after the majority <b>to convict</b> a transgressor must be <b>by</b> a more decisive majority of at least <b>two.</b> Therefore, the court must have at least twenty-two judges.

Daf 2b

<b>And</b> since there is a principle that <b>a court may not</b> be composed of <b>an even</b> number of judges, as such a court may be unable to reach a decision, therefore <b>they add another one to them,</b> and <b>there are twenty-three</b> judges <b>here.</b>
<b>And how many</b> men must <b>be in the city for</b> it <b>to be eligible for</b> a lesser <b>Sanhedrin? One hundred and twenty. Rabbi Neḥemya says: Two hundred and thirty, corresponding to the ministers of tens,</b> as outlined by Moses and Yitro in the wilderness (Exodus, chapter 18). That is to say, each member of the Sanhedrin can be viewed as a judge with responsibility for ten residents. If there are not enough men in the city to enable this calculation, it would not be honorable to appoint a Sanhedrin, as their members will each preside over less than the minimum of ten residents.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that cases of monetary law are adjudicated by three judges, and that cases of robbery and personal injury must also be adjudicated by three judges. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury are not</b> cases of <b>monetary law?</b> Obviously they are; why did the mishna delineate them separately? <b>Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> The mishna <b>teaches</b> this clause employing the style: <b>What are these,</b> meaning that the expression: Cases of monetary law, is a description of a category, followed by the specification. Accordingly, the mishna should be read as follows: <b>What are these</b> cases of <b>monetary law</b> that are adjudicated by three judges? Cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury. But</b> cases of <b>admissions,</b> where one party admits that he owes another money, <b>and</b> cases of <b>loans</b> that were not repaid are <b>not</b> included in this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>And</b> this specification <b>is necessary, as had</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> only that cases of <b>monetary law</b> are adjudicated by three judges, <b>I would say that</b> this applies <b>even</b> to cases of <b>admissions and loans.</b> Therefore, to avoid this misunderstanding, <b>he taught:</b> Cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury,</b> in order to clarify that only they are included in the <i>halakha</i>. <b>And had he taught</b> only cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury and had not taught</b> cases of <b>monetary law, I would say</b> that <b>the same is true even</b> with regard to <b>admissions and loans,</b> that they are adjudicated in the same manner. <b>And</b> I would understand <b>this</b> fact, <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> specifically cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury,</b> by saying that these are mere examples and that the mishna mentions them <b>because</b> in the <b>primary</b> cases in which the requirement for <b>three</b> judges <b>is written</b> in the Torah, <b>it is written with regard to</b> cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury.</b>
The Gemara explains this assertion. With regard to cases of <b>robbery, as it is written</b> with regard to a bailee who accepted a deposit from another and then claims that it was stolen: <b>“The owner of the house shall come near the court [<i>ha’elohim</i>],</b> to see whether he has not put his hand upon his neighbor’s property” (Exodus 22:7). And with regard to cases of personal <b>injury,</b> they are adjudicated in the same manner as cases of robbery, because <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if another <b>injured one’s body</b> and <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> if another <b>injured one’s property?</b> Therefore, in order to clarify that the <i>halakha</i> applies only to cases of robbery and injury, the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught: What are these</b> cases of <b>monetary law?</b> Cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury. But</b> this <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> apply with regard to cases of <b>admissions and loans.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to which</b> <i>halakha</i> are cases of admissions and loans unlike cases of robbery and injury? <b>If we say that we do not need</b> a court of <b>three</b> judges to adjudicate such cases, <b>but doesn’t Rabbi Abbahu say:</b> With regard to a court of <b>two</b> judges <b>that adjudicated</b> cases of <b>monetary law</b> of any type, which would include cases of admissions and loans, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>their judgment is not</b> a valid <b>judgment,</b> as a court with fewer than three judges is invalid?
The Gemara answers: This is not the difference between the categories; <b>rather,</b> the difference is <b>that</b> for cases of admissions and loans <b>we do not require expert,</b> ordained judges who have studied extensively and received permission to judge; any three laymen can serve as a court for these types of cases. The mishna singled out cases of robbery and personal injury in order to indicate that for those cases expert judges are necessary.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>hold? If he holds</b> that <b>a merging of</b> Torah <b>portions is written here,</b> then <b>he should also require expert</b> judges for cases of admissions and loans. The passage from which the <i>halakha</i> requiring three judges is derived (Exodus 22:6–8) discusses several different <i>halakhot</i>. According to the understanding that these portions should be considered as merged, they are interpreted to indicate equivalence between those <i>halakhot</i>. <b>And if he holds</b> that <b>there is no merging of</b> Torah <b>portions written here,</b> meaning that the <i>halakhot</i> are to be derived only from verses that discuss them directly, then <b>why do I</b> need <b>three</b> judges for admissions and loans? The requirement for three judges is derived from the repetition of the word <i>elohim</i> three times in the context of cases of robbery and personal injury.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>a merging of</b> Torah <b>portions is written here, and by right</b> he <b>should have required expert</b> judges to judge cases of admissions and loans <b>as well. And this</b> fact, i.e., <b>that we do not require expert</b> judges for these cases, is <b>due to</b> the reasoning <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina, as Rabbi Ḥanina says: By Torah law, both</b> cases of <b>monetary law and</b> cases of <b>capital law</b> require <b>inquiry and interrogation</b> of witnesses in order to conclusively determine the time, place, and circumstance of the incident, with the purpose of finding any possible contradiction in the witnesses’ testimony.

Daf 3a

The source for this is <b>as it is stated: “You shall have one manner of law”</b> (Leviticus 24:22), from which it is derived that all judges must judge in the same manner. And since with regard to cases of capital law it is stated: “And you shall inquire and investigate, and ask diligently” (Deuteronomy 13:15), the same should apply to cases of monetary law. <b>And what is the reason</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that in cases of <b>monetary law we do not require inquiry and interrogation</b> of witnesses? The Gemara answers: The Sages established this exemption <b>so as not to lock the door in the face of</b> potential <b>borrowers.</b> If inquiry and interrogation of the witnesses would be required in order to have the court rule that the lender can collect payment of a loan, lenders would be deterred by the difficulty of proving the matter and might cease to lend money to the poor. For the same reason, the Sages also waived the need for expert judges in these cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then if these laymen <b>err they should not</b> be liable to <b>pay</b> compensation to the party unfairly wronged by their judgment, just as expert judges are not liable. The Gemara responds: If this is the <i>halakha</i>, <b>you are all the more so locking the door in the face of</b> potential <b>borrowers;</b> wealthy people will not want to lend money, as they will fear that a court of laymen will judge the case incorrectly.
With regard to Rabbi Abbahu’s method of explaining the mishna, the Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then instead of explaining the mishna employing the style: What are these, Rabbi Abbahu could more easily say that <b>two</b> matters <b>are taught</b> in the mishna, and explain it as follows: Cases of <b>monetary law,</b> meaning cases of admissions and loans, are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges who could be non-ordained <b>laymen [<i>hedyotot</i>],</b> and cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> ordained, <b>expert</b> judges.
<b>And furthermore,</b> according to Rabbi Abbahu’s explanation that the term: Cases of robbery and personal injury, simply clarifies the meaning of the term: Cases of monetary law, <b>why do I</b> need the repetitive statement that cases of monetary law are adjudicated by <b>three</b> judges and cases of robbery and injury are adjudicated by <b>three</b> judges? The repetition seems to indicate that these are two separate matters.
<b>Rather, Rava said: Two</b> matters <b>are</b> in fact <b>taught</b> in the mishna, <b>because</b> of the statement <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina</b> that the Sages instituted leniencies with regard to cases of monetary law so as not to lock the door in the face of potential borrowers. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: By Torah law,</b> the adjudication of <b>one</b> judge is <b>also valid</b> in cases of admissions and loans, <b>as it is stated: “In righteousness shall you judge your neighbor”</b> (Leviticus 19:15), in the singular. <b>But</b> by rabbinic law, three judges are required, <b>due to</b> the concern that a single judge may be one of <b>those who sit</b> idly on street <b>corners,</b> i.e., unlearned people who are not involved in business and are unlikely to judge the case correctly.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>with three</b> judges <b>they</b> will <b>not be</b> among <b>those who sit</b> idly on street <b>corners?</b> How is this concern addressed by increasing the number of judges? The Gemara answers: When there are three judges <b>it is impossible,</b> i.e., highly unlikely, <b>that there is not among them one who is learned.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then if <b>they err they should not</b> be liable to <b>pay</b> compensation, since rabbinic law authorizes laymen to judge cases of this nature. The Gemara answers: If the judges will be exempt from paying compensation in the event that they err in their judgment, this lack of accountability will lead <b>all the more so</b> to having <b>many</b> of <b>those who sit</b> idly on street <b>corners</b> assume the role of judges.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are</b> the implications of the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> who says that cases of monetary law may be adjudicated by three laymen due to the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>and</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika,</b> who holds that according to the Torah one judge is sufficient? The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between</b> them is with regard to <b>that</b> which <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>adjudicated</b> a case, <b>their judgment</b> is a valid <b>judgment, but they are called an impudent court. Rava is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel,</b> as he holds that three judges are required by Torah law. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel,</b> as he holds that fundamentally, even one judge may judge a case of monetary law.
§ The mishna teaches that cases involving payment for <b>damage and</b> payment for <b>half the damage</b> are adjudicated by three judges. The Gemara challenges: <b>Damage is</b> the same as <b>injury,</b> since the term: Injury, includes various damages one causes another directly or by his property. The Gemara explains: <b>Since he needed to teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to payment of <b>half</b> the cost of <b>the damage, he also taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to payment of the <b>full</b> cost of the <b>damage.</b>
The Gemara challenges: Payment of <b>half the damage is also</b> the same as personal <b>injury,</b> so it did not need to be stated separately. The Gemara explains: There is a difference. The <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case of <b>monetary matters, and</b> he also <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case of <b>a fine,</b> such as payment of half the damage in a case where an innocuous ox gored another animal. Consequently, payment of half the cost of the damage needed to be stated separately from payment for injury, and once he needed to teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to payment for half the cost of the damage, he first mentioned general payments for damages.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>the</b> payment for <b>half</b> the cost of <b>the damage</b> is considered <b>a fine,</b> meaning that according to the standard <i>halakhot</i> of damages the owner of the goring ox should be exempt, and the Torah instituted a payment of half the cost of the damage as a penalty for not being exceedingly careful. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>the</b> payment for <b>half</b> the cost of <b>the damage</b> is an actual <b>monetary</b> payment, meaning that according to the standard <i>halakhot</i> of damages the owner of the goring ox should be fully liable but the Torah exempted him from part of his liability due to the unusual nature of the damage, <b>what can be said?</b> Therefore, this explanation must be rejected.
<b>Rather, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>needed to teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to cases involving <b>payment of double</b> the principal <b>and payment of four or five</b> times the principal, <b>which</b> are cases of <b>money</b>

Daf 3b

<b>that is not paid according to its value,</b> meaning that the payment is not equal to the cost of the damage but is actually more than that amount, <b>he also taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to payment of <b>half</b> the cost of <b>the damage, which is</b> also <b>money that is not paid according to its value,</b> as he pays less than the full cost of the damage. <b>And since he needs to teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to payment of <b>half</b> the cost of <b>the damage, he also taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to payment of the full cost of the <b>damage.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive the fundamental requirement for <b>three</b> judges? The Gemara answers: This is <b>as the Sages taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“The owner of the house shall come near the court,</b> to see whether he has not put his hand upon his neighbor’s property” (Exodus 22:7), so <b>there is one</b> judge <b>here.</b> The following verse states: <b>“The cause of both parties shall come before the court,”</b> so <b>there are two</b> judges <b>here.</b> And that verse concludes: <b>“He whom the court shall condemn</b> shall pay double to his neighbor,” so <b>there are three</b> judges <b>here,</b> corresponding to the three mentions of the term “the court.” This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yonatan says: The first</b> instance of the term “the court” <b>is stated first</b> as part of the primary text of the passage, and it is necessary for conveying the straightforward meaning of the verse. <b>And one does not derive</b> tallies for halakhic matters by counting the <b>first</b> mention of a term. Rabbi Yonatan holds that when a tally is derived from the number of instances a certain word appears in the Torah, the first instance is not included in the tally, as it is necessary to teach the mitzva itself; the tally may be counted only from subsequent mentions. <b>Rather,</b> this is how it is derived: <b>“The cause of both parties shall come before the court,” there is one</b> judge <b>here,</b> and the continuation of the verse: <b>“He whom the court shall condemn”</b> teaches that <b>there are two</b> judges <b>here. And</b> since <b>a court may not</b> be composed of <b>an even</b> number of judges, <b>they</b> must <b>add an additional one to them,</b> so <b>there are three</b> judges <b>here.</b>
<b>Let us say</b> that Rabbi Yoshiya and Rabbi Yonatan <b>disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>one derives</b> tallies for halakhic matters from the <b>first</b> mention of a term in the Torah. <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoshiya, <b>holds</b> that <b>one derives</b> tallies from the <b>first</b> mention of the term in the Torah, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yonatan, <b>holds</b> that <b>one does not derive</b> tallies from the <b>first</b> mention of the term. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> actually <b>everyone</b> holds that <b>one does not derive</b> tallies from the <b>first</b> mention of the term, but in this case there is a separate source for the derivation, as <b>Rabbi Yoshiya</b> could have <b>said to you: If it is true</b> that no <i>halakha</i> is derived from the first mention, <b>let the verse say: The owner of the house shall come near to the judge [<i>hashofet</i>]. What,</b> then, is the significance of the unique expression: <b>“To the court [<i>haelohim</i>]”? Conclude from it</b> that the term <i>elohim</i> was chosen <b>to</b> count toward <b>the tally.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>Rabbi Yonatan</b> respond to this analysis? The Gemara answers: He would say that the verse <b>employed the</b> common <b>language of the world, as people say: One who has a case,</b> a claim against another, <b>should approach the</b> regular <b>judge,</b> the one who generally judges cases and can be referred to by the term <i>elohim</i>. Consequently, no unique <i>halakha</i> can be derived from this first usage.
<b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoshiya accept</b> the principle that <b>a court</b> must be composed of <b>an odd</b> number of judges? <b>And isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, says: What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “To incline after a multitude to pervert justice”</b> (Exodus 23:2)? The meaning is that <b>the Torah is saying</b> to you: <b>Make for yourself a court</b> that is composed of an odd number of judges, that will perforce <b>incline</b> in one direction, so that there will always be a majority that can be followed.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoshiya does not accept this <i>halakha</i> but instead <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says:</b> A Great Sanhedrin is composed of <b>seventy</b> judges. <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: The <b>Great Sanhedrin was</b> composed <b>of seventy-one</b> judges, and <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It is composed of <b>seventy</b> judges. Clearly, Rabbi Yehuda does not accept the principle that a court must be composed of an odd number of judges.
The Gemara asks: <b>Say that you heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> said this <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to the Great Sanhedrin,</b> about <b>which</b> specific <b>verses are written,</b> and he derives from these verses that the Great Sanhedrin must be composed of exactly seventy judges. <b>Have you heard him</b> say <b>with regard to the rest of the courts,</b> those whose composition is not explicitly addressed in the Torah, that these courts can also be composed of an even number of judges?
<b>And if you would say: There is no difference;</b> Rabbi Yehuda does not differentiate between the Great Sanhedrin and lower courts, <b>but didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: The <b>laying of hands by the Sages and the breaking of the heifer’s neck</b> are performed in front of a panel <b>of three</b> judges; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> These rituals are performed in front <b>of five</b> judges.
<b>And we say</b> with regard to this <i>halakha</i>: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The verse states: “And the Elders of the congregation shall lay their hands upon the head of the bullock” (Leviticus 4:15). The term: <b>“Shall lay their hands,”</b> which is in the plural, indicates that there are <b>two,</b> and the word <b>“Elders,”</b> which is also plural, indicates another <b>two,</b> meaning a total of four. <b>And</b> since <b>a court may not</b> be composed of <b>an even</b> number of judges, <b>we add another one to them,</b> and <b>there are five</b> judges <b>here.</b> Consequently, Rabbi Yehuda does accept the <i>halakha</i> that a court may not be composed of an even number of judges.
The Gemara answers: It can be explained <b>that Rabbi Yoshiya</b> holds in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> but <b>goes further than</b> he does. This is <b>because Rabbi Yehuda does not accept</b> the principle that a court must be composed of an odd number of judges in connection <b>with a Great Sanhedrin, but with regard to other courts he does accept</b> it. <b>And Rabbi Yoshiya also does not accept</b> it <b>with regard to other courts.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what does he do with this</b> verse: <b>“To incline</b> after a multitude to pervert justice”? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoshiya <b>interprets it in</b> relation to cases of <b>capital law.</b> In such cases he agrees that the court must be composed of an odd number of judges, in order that it will be possible to exonerate the accused on the basis of a majority of one judge.
The Gemara asks: <b>But does</b> Rabbi Yoshiya <b>not</b> accept the requirement for an odd number of judges <b>with regard to</b> cases of <b>monetary law? But</b> there is <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (29a): If <b>two</b> judges <b>say</b> the defendant is <b>exempt</b> from payment <b>and one says</b> he is <b>liable,</b> he is <b>exempt;</b> if <b>two say</b> he is <b>liable and one says</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> he is <b>liable. Let us say that</b> this mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya,</b> as Rabbi Yoshiya does not accept the requirement for an odd number of judges concerning cases of monetary law, and therefore perhaps he holds that the verdict must be agreed upon unanimously by all the judges.
The Gemara rejects this possibility: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya.</b> Although he does not accept the requirement for an odd number of judges in cases of monetary law, he does allow for a decision on the basis of a majority. <b>He derives this</b> principle based <b>on an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> cases of <b>capital law: If</b> concerning cases of <b>capital law, which are strict, the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>Follow the majority,</b> and does not require a unanimous ruling, concerning cases of <b>monetary law,</b> which are more lenient, is it <b>not all the more so</b> clear that a majority ruling is sufficient?
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> Cases concerning <b>monetary law</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> They are adjudicated <b>by five</b> judges, <b>so that a verdict can be issued with three</b> judges. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that with a court <b>of three</b> judges <b>a verdict cannot be issued by two</b> judges? The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> what Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>is saying:</b> Cases of monetary law are adjudicated by five judges, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that a verdict</b> must be issued <b>by three.</b> In other words, according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the judges who form the majority that decides the verdict must themselves be eligible to constitute a court. <b>Evidently,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>when</b> the requirement for <b>three</b> judges <b>is written</b> in the Torah, it <b>is written with regard to</b> the number of judges necessary to issue <b>the verdict.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu</b> would <b>ridicule [<i>megaddef</i> ] this</b> suggestion. <b>If that is so,</b> then <b>the Great Sanhedrin would need</b> to consist of <b>141</b> judges, <b>so that the verdict can be issued by seventy-one, and a lesser Sanhedrin would need</b> to consist of <b>forty-five</b> judges, <b>so that the verdict can be issued by twenty-three.</b> But these assertions contradict the <i>halakha</i> as derived from the verses.
<b>Rather, the Merciful One states: “Gather Me seventy men</b> of the Elders of Israel” (Numbers 11:16), and this means that <b>from the time of gathering,</b> there must be <b>seventy.</b> Likewise, the verse states: <b>“And the congregation shall judge…and the congregation shall save”</b> (Numbers 35:24–25), from which it is derived that cases of capital law are adjudicated by twenty-three judges, and this <b>also</b> means that <b>from the time that the congregation judges</b> there must be twenty-three. <b>Similarly,</b> with regard to a case of monetary law, the verse states: <b>“The owner of the house shall come near to the court”</b> (Exodus 22:7), and this means <b>from the time of coming near</b> to judge the cases there must be <b>three</b> judges. Consequently, there is no requirement that the verdict be decided by a majority who could themselves form a court.
Therefore, the previous explanation must be rejected. <b>Rather, this is the reasoning of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: It is stated in the next verse: <b>“He whom the court shall condemn”</b> (Exodus 22:8) in the plural, which means there must be <b>two</b> judges. Consequently, <b>it is stated: “The court,”</b> in the verse <b>below and it is stated: “The court,”</b> in the verse <b>above. Just as below</b> it is referring to <b>two</b> judges, as the word: “Shall condemn,” is written in the plural, <b>so too above</b> it is referring to <b>two</b> judges, making a total of four. <b>And</b> since <b>a court may not</b> be composed of <b>an even</b> number of judges, <b>they add another one to them, so there are five</b> judges <b>here.</b>

Daf 4a

<b>And</b> how would <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s proof? They would say that although the term: <b>“Shall condemn”</b> is pronounced as a plural verb, it is <b>written</b> in a way that could also be read in the singular. Consequently, one cannot derive a requirement for more than one judge from there.
§ The dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Sages is explained as an example of the more general question of whether the written consonantal text or the vocalization of the Torah is authoritative. As <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosei says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Roetz, Beit Shammai, Rabbi Shimon, and Rabbi Akiva, they all hold</b> that the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative,</b> and that the <i>halakha</i> is therefore decided based on the meaning of the word as pronounced, and not on possible alternative readings of the written text.
The Gemara explains the basis for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s assertion with regard to each of the <i>tanna’im</i> that he mentioned: With regard to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, the proof is <b>that which we have</b> just <b>said,</b> with regard to the interpretation of the verse: “He whom the court shall condemn” (Exodus 22:8) deriving a requirement for five judges in cases of monetary law based on the vocalized plural pronunciation of the term: “Shall condemn.”
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Roetz,</b> it is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: His <b>students asked Rabbi Yehuda ben Roetz:</b> The verse states: “But if she gives birth to a female, then she shall be unclean for two weeks, as in her menstrual impurity; and she shall then continue in the blood of purification for sixty-six days” (Leviticus 12:5). Based on the written consonantal text, <b>I can read</b> the amount of time she is impure as: <b>“Seventy [<i>shivim</i>]</b> days,” and not as: “Two weeks [<i>shevuayim</i>].” One <b>might</b> have thought, therefore, that a woman who <b>gives birth to a female should be impure</b> for <b>seventy</b> days.
Rabbi Yehuda ben Roetz <b>said to them:</b> It can be proven that this is not the <i>halakha</i>, as the Torah <b>deemed</b> her <b>impure and deemed</b> her <b>pure</b> when she gave birth <b>to a male, and deemed</b> her <b>impure and deemed</b> her <b>pure</b> when she gave birth <b>to a female. Just as when it deemed</b> her <b>pure</b> for thirty-three days after the initial period of impurity when she gave birth <b>to a male,</b> when she gives birth <b>to a female</b> she is pure for sixty-six days, which is <b>double</b> the amount of time; <b>so too, when it deemed</b> her <b>impure</b> for seven days when she gave birth <b>to a male,</b> when she gives birth <b>to a female</b> she is also impure for <b>double</b> the amount of time. Consequently, the verse must be read according to the vocalized reading: “Two weeks,” and not according to the consonantal text, which could be read: “Seventy.”
<b>After they left,</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Roetz <b>went out and followed them.</b> He then <b>said to them: You do not need this</b> proof that I gave based on the comparison of the periods of impurity with the periods of purity. Rather, <b>we read</b> the verse as: <b>“Two weeks,” and</b> the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative.</b>
With regard to <b>Beit Shammai,</b> the proof that they also hold that the vocalization of the Torah is authoritative is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 36b): <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> With regard to <b>all</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood must be <b>presented on the external altar,</b> once the blood has been <b>presented with one presentation</b> the offering <b>has effected atonement,</b> even if more presentations are ideally required, <b>as it is stated: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured out</b> against the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27). This verse teaches that even with regard to a burnt-offering, which requires multiple presentations of the blood, a single presentation is sufficient to render the offering valid after the fact. <b>But with regard to a sin-offering,</b> it is valid only if there were at least <b>two presentations. And Beit Hillel say: Even with regard to a sin-offering that one presented with one presentation, it has effected atonement</b> after the fact.
<b>And Rav Huna says: What is the reasoning</b> for the opinion <b>of Beit Shammai?</b> The verse states: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin-offering with his finger, and put it on the <b>horns</b> of the altar” (Leviticus 4:25); and “The priest shall take of the blood thereof with his finger, and put it on the <b>horns</b> of the altar” (Leviticus 4:30); and again: “The priest shall take of the blood of the sin-offering with his finger, and put it on the <b>horns</b> of the altar” (Leviticus 4:34). As the minimum amount justifying the use of plural, i.e., “horns,” is two, one may conclude that <b>there are six</b> references to the horns of the altar <b>here. Four</b> of them are mentioned <b>for the mitzva,</b> meaning that he should present the blood on all four horns of the altar <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and</b> the other <b>two</b> were mentioned <b>to invalidate</b> the offering if he did not present it on at least two horns.
<b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> The matter should be understood according to the written consonantal text. The word <b>“horns”</b> is written once plene, with a <i>vav</i>, which means that it must be read in the plural; and the other two times the words <b>“horns”</b> and <b>“horns”</b> are written deficient, without a <i>vav</i>, in a way that can be vocalized in the singular. Therefore, <b>there are four</b> references to horns <b>here. Three</b> of these presentations are written <b>to</b> indicate that they are performed only as <b>a mitzva,</b> i.e., they are performed <i>ab initio</i>, but the offering is valid even absent their presentation. <b>And</b> the remaining <b>one,</b> i.e., the fourth presentation, is written <b>to</b> indicate that its absence <b>invalidates</b> the offering, i.e., the offering is not valid if the blood was not presented against at least one horn of the altar. Evidently, Beit Shammai hold the vocalization is authoritative, whereas Beit Hillel hold the consonantal text is authoritative.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to this explanation of Beit Hillel, why not <b>say</b> that <b>all of them are</b> written <b>for the mitzva</b> and none to invalidate, meaning the blood must be presented on all four horns <i>ab initio</i>, but the offering atones after the fact even if it has not been presented at all? The Gemara rejects this possibility: <b>We have not found</b> anywhere in the Torah an example of an offering in which <b>atonement</b> can be achieved <b>with no</b> presentation of the blood of the offering at all.
With regard to <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> it is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that records a dispute among the Sages with regard to the number of walls required in a <i>sukka</i>: There must be <b>two</b> walls <b>in their standard sense,</b> completely closing each of those two sides, <b>and a third</b> wall, which, based on a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, may measure <b>even</b> as little as one <b>handbreadth. Rabbi Shimon says</b> that there must be <b>three</b> walls <b>in their standard sense, and a fourth</b> one that can measure <b>even</b> one <b>handbreadth.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Rabbis hold</b> that the <b>tradition</b> of the manner in which the verses in the Torah are written <b>is authoritative, and Rabbi Shimon holds that</b> the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The Rabbis hold that</b> the <b>tradition</b> of the manner in which the verses in are written <b>is authoritative.</b> The Torah states: “You shall reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i>”</b> (Leviticus 23:42) spelled deficient, without the letter <i>vav</i>, in a way that can be read in the singular. And later in that verse it also states: “All that are homeborn in Israel shall reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i>”</b> spelled the same way. And in the next verse it states: “So that your future generations will know that I caused the children of Israel to reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i>,”</b> this time spelled plene, with a <i>vav</i>, which means it must be plural. Therefore, <b>there are four</b> walls <b>here. Remove one verse,</b> which is needed <b>to</b> teach the mitzva to sit in a <i>sukka</i> <b>itself,</b> and <b>three</b> walls <b>remain. The <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, which says that one of the walls may be incomplete, <b>comes</b> and <b>reduces the third and establishes it as</b> a minimum of one <b>handbreadth.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that the vocalization is authoritative. Since the verses state: “You shall reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i>,”</b> and: “All that are homeborn in Israel shall reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i>,”</b> and: “So that your future generations will know that I caused the children of Israel to reside <b>in <i>sukkot</i>,”</b> all of which are pronounced as plural nouns, <b>there are six</b> walls <b>here. Remove one verse to</b> teach the mitzva of <i>sukka</i> <b>itself,</b> and <b>four</b> walls <b>remain. The <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai then <b>comes</b> and <b>reduces the fourth</b> wall, <b>and establishes it at</b> a minimum of one <b>handbreadth.</b> Consequently, it is clear that Rabbi Shimon also holds that the vocalization is authoritative.
With regard to <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> it is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is known that a quarter<i>-log</i> of blood that came from a corpse imparts ritual impurity in a tent. And <b>Rabbi Akiva says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a quarter</b><i>-log</i> <b>of blood that came out of two</b> separate <b>corpses</b> also <b>imparts ritual impurity in a tent? As it is stated</b> with regard to a priest: <b>“He shall not come upon any dead bodies”</b> (Leviticus 21:11). The word “bodies” is pronounced as a plural word, and since the Torah teaches elsewhere that: “The blood is the life” (Deuteronomy 12:23), this indicates that impurity can be imparted by <b>one measure</b> of blood that came from <b>two bodies. And the Rabbis</b> say: The word <b>“bodies” is written</b> deficient, without a <i>vav</i>, so that it can also be read as a singular word, indicating that a quarter<i>-log</i> of blood imparts impurity in a tent only if it came from a single corpse.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov objects to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s assertion that all of the above disputes are based on the question of whether the traditional consonantal text or the vocalized text of the Torah is authoritative: <b>Is there</b> a Sage <b>who does not accept</b> the principle that the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “You shall not cook a young goat <b>in its mother’s milk [<i>baḥalev</i>]”</b> (Exodus 23:19). One <b>might</b> have thought the verse should be read as prohibiting the cooking of the young goat <b>in the fat [<i>beḥelev</i>]</b> of the mother, and there is no prohibition against cooking the meat with milk.

Daf 4b

<b>You</b> therefore <b>say</b> in response: The <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative,</b> and the verse prohibits cooking the young goat in its mother’s milk.
<b>Rather, everyone</b> agrees that the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative. But</b> in actuality, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the Rabbis disagree with regard to this: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that the phrase <b>“the court shall condemn”</b> is referring to <b>other</b> judges, in addition to the three that were derived from the earlier verse, leading to a total of five, whereas <b>the Rabbis hold</b> that the term <b>“shall condemn”</b> means <b>these</b> judges, i.e., <b>those</b> who have already been mentioned, and therefore there are only three.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Roetz,</b> who applied the principle: The vocalization of the Torah is authoritative, to the question of the duration of the ritual impurity of a woman who gave birth to a female, it can be explained that <b>the Rabbis do not disagree with him,</b> as everyone agrees that the vocalization of the Torah is authoritative.
With regard to <b>Beit Hillel,</b> who hold that a single presentation of blood is sufficient to atone even when bringing a sin-offering, this is not because they hold the traditional consonantal text is authoritative. Rather, their opinion is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the sin-offering brought by a ruler: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement</b> for him” (Leviticus 4:26), and with regard to a sin-offering of a goat brought by an ordinary person: “And the priest <b>shall make atonement</b> for him” (Leviticus 4:31), and with regard to a sin-offering of a lamb brought by an ordinary person: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement</b> for him” (Leviticus 4:35), repeating this term three times. This repetition is <b>due to the</b> following <b>logical inference:</b>
<b>Could this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference?</b> There <b>is stated</b> a term of <b>blood below,</b> in the verse written with regard to a bird brought as a sin-offering (see Leviticus 5:9), <b>and</b> there <b>is stated</b> a term of <b>blood above,</b> in the verse written with regard to an animal brought as a sin-offering (see Leviticus 4:25, 31, 35). <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>blood that is stated below, when it is presented with one presentation it has effected atonement, so too</b> with regard to the <b>blood that is stated above, when it is presented with one presentation it has effected atonement.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way,</b> offering a different explanation: There <b>is stated</b> a term of <b>blood</b> in the verse written <b>with regard to the external</b> altar, i.e., in the verse written with regard to a sin-offering of an ordinary person that is brought on the external altar in the courtyard (see Leviticus 4:25), <b>and</b> there <b>is stated</b> a term of <b>blood</b> in the verse written <b>with regard to</b> the <b>inner</b> altar, i.e., with regard to a sin-offering of the community or the High Priest, the blood of which is sprinkled on the incense altar inside the Sanctuary (see Leviticus 4:7, 18). <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>blood that was stated concerning</b> the <b>inner</b> altar, i.e., if <b>one of the presentations is lacking it has not accomplished anything</b> and the offering is not valid, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>blood that was stated concerning the external</b> altar, if one <b>of the presentations is lacking it has accomplished nothing.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the two possibilities: <b>Let us see to which</b> of the two comparisons <b>this is</b> more <b>similar.</b> It can be claimed: <b>We derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>external</b> altar <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>external</b> altar, <b>but we do not derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>external</b> altar <b>from</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to the <b>inner</b> altar.
<b>Or go this way: We derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to a <b>sin-offering</b> whose blood is to be sprinkled on the <b>four corners</b> of the altar <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to <b>a sin-offering</b> whose blood is to be sprinkled on the <b>four corners</b> of the altar, <b>and this</b> sin-offering consisting of a bird, <b>which is not a sin-offering</b> of the type whose blood is to be sprinkled on the <b>four corners</b> of the altar, <b>cannot prove</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is similar with regard to a sin-offering whose blood is to be sprinkled on the four corners of the altar.
Since there are two legitimate inferences, the <i>halakha</i> cannot be decided through a logical inference. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,” “And</b> the priest <b>shall make atonement,”</b> three times, <b>due to the logical inference.</b> The verses are interpreted as follows: “The priest <b>shall make atonement,” even though he presented only three</b> presentations, and then a second verse repeats: “The priest <b>shall make atonement,” even though he presented only two</b> presentations, and then a third verse repeats: “The priest <b>shall make atonement,” even though he presented only one</b> presentation. This interpretation is the source of Beit Hillel’s opinion.
<b>And</b> concerning <b>Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis,</b> who disagreed with regard to the number of walls required in a <i>sukka</i>, it is <b>with regard to this</b> that <b>they disagree: Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that <b>the</b> basic requirement of placing <b>roofing [<i>sekhakha</i>]</b> on the <i>sukka</i> <b>does not need a verse</b> to teach that it is required, as it is implied by the word <i>sukka</i>. Consequently, the word <i>sukkot</i> appears two times in the text beyond the initial mitzva, teaching a requirement for four walls, and there is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai that reduces the minimum size of one of the walls to a handbreadth. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that the requirement of placing <b>roofing does need a verse.</b> Therefore, one of the four derivations is used to teach that requirement, and only three walls remain, one of which is reduced to a handbreadth.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis,</b> who disagreed about the issue of a quarter<i>-log</i> of blood that emanated from two corpses, it is <b>with regard to this</b> that <b>they disagree: Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>“bodies”</b> in plural <b>indicates two.</b> Consequently, a quarter<i>-log</i> of blood that emanated from two corpses also renders one impure. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>“bodies”</b> in plural <b>indicates</b> a <b>general</b> <i>halakha</i>, and no derivation can be made with regard to blood that emanated from two corpses. Both opinions, however, agree that the vocalized text of the Torah is authoritative.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does everyone</b> actually hold that the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the number of compartments in the phylacteries of the head, the verse states: “It shall be for a sign upon your hand, and <b>for <i>totafot</i></b> between your eyes” (Exodus 13:16), with the word <i>totafot</i> spelled deficient, without a second <i>vav</i>, in a way that can be read as singular; and again: “They shall be <b>for <i>totafot</i></b> between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 6:8), spelled as a singular word; and again: “They shall be <b>for <i>totafot</i></b> between your eyes” (11:18), this time spelled plene, with a second <i>vav</i>, in a manner that must be plural? <b>There are four</b> mentions of <i>totafot</i> <b>here,</b> as the third one is written in the plural and therefore counts as two. Consequently, it is derived that the phylacteries of the head must have four compartments. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: There is no need</b> for this proof, as the requirement of four compartments can be derived from the word <i>totafot</i> itself: The word <b><i>tat</i> in</b> the language of the <b><i>Katfei</i></b> means <b>two,</b> and the word <b><i>pat</i> in</b> the language of <b><i>Afriki</i></b> also means <b>two,</b> and therefore <i>totafot</i> can be understood as a compound word meaning: Four. The <i>baraita</i> therefore indicates that Rabbi Yishmael holds that not the vocalization but rather the tradition of the manner in which the verses in the Torah are written is authoritative.
<b>Rather,</b> the explanation that everyone holds that the vocalization of the Torah is authoritative must be rejected, and it must be explained that the Sages <b>actually</b> do <b>disagree</b> whether it is the vocalization of the Torah or the tradition of the manner in which the verses in the Torah are written that is authoritative. <b>And</b> in order to explain the unresolved problem with regard to the <i>baraita</i> about the prohibition of cooking a young goat in its mother’s milk, the explanation is that <b>this statement, that they disagree</b> as to whether the vocalization or the tradition is authoritative, applies <b>where the vocalization</b> of the word <b>differs from the tradition</b> of the manner in which the word is written. <b>But</b> in <b>this</b> case the words <b>milk [<i>ḥalev</i>] and fat [<i>ḥelev</i>] are</b> written in <b>an identical</b> manner, as there is no difference in the writing at all, only in the way they are vocalized. Therefore, all agree that the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the words: <b>“Shall see”</b> and <b>“shall appear” are</b> written in <b>an identical</b> matter, <b>and</b> nevertheless the Sages <b>disagree</b> about which reading is authoritative. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Yoḥanan ben Dahavai says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima: One who is blind in one of his eyes is exempt from the</b> mitzva of <b>appearance,</b> i.e., the obligation to appear in the Temple and to sacrifice an offering on the three pilgrimage Festivals, <b>as it is stated:</b> “Three times in the year all your males shall appear [<i>yera’eh</i>] before the Lord God” (Exodus 23:17). According to the way in which the verse is written, without vocalization, it can be read as <b><i>yireh</i>,</b> meaning: <b>Shall see,</b> instead of <b><i>yera’eh</i>,</b> meaning: <b>Shall appear.</b> This teaches that <b>in the</b> same <b>manner that one comes to see, so he comes to appear,</b> i.e., to be seen: <b>Just as</b> the usual way <b>to see</b> is <b>with both of one’s eyes, so too,</b> the obligation <b>to appear</b> applies only to one who comes <b>with</b> the sight of <b>both his eyes.</b>
It is therefore apparent that even when there is no difference in the way the words are written, some say that the tradition, not the vocalization, is authoritative. <b>Rather, Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said:</b> The reason all agree that there is a prohibition to cook a young goat in its mother’s milk and not in its mother’s fat is that <b>the verse states: “You shall not cook a young goat”</b> (Exodus 23:19). The verse teaches that the action <b>the Torah prohibited</b> is in <b>the manner of cooking,</b> which is generally done in a liquid such as milk and not in a solid substance such as fat.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Cases of <b>monetary law</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges.

Daf 5a

<b>But if</b> one <b>was</b> a judge accepted as <b>an expert for the public,</b> then <b>he may judge</b> cases <b>even</b> as the <b>lone</b> judge. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> One <b>such as I may judge</b> cases of <b>monetary law as</b> the <b>lone</b> judge. <b>And similarly, Rabbi Ḥiyya said:</b> One <b>such as I may judge</b> cases of <b>monetary law as</b> the <b>lone</b> judge.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: What is the meaning of: Such as I, in the statements of these Rabbis? Did they intend to say: <b>Such as I,</b> in <b>that I have studied and</b> have the skills to <b>extrapolate</b> and derive new rulings on the basis of earlier decisions, <b>and have</b> also <b>received permission</b> to judge as the lone judge? <b>But</b> accordingly, if one <b>has not received permission</b> to judge as the lone judge, <b>his judgment is not</b> a valid <b>judgment? Or perhaps</b> this is not the correct reading of the statements, and the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>even though he did not receive permission</b> to judge as the lone judge, <b>his judgment is</b> nevertheless a valid <b>judgment?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this dilemma from the following case: <b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman,</b> once <b>adjudicated</b> a certain <b>case and erred</b> in his ruling. Upon recognizing his error, <b>he came before Rav Yosef</b> to ask what he should do. Rav Yosef <b>said to him: If</b> the litigants <b>accepted you upon themselves</b> as the lone judge, and both had agreed that they would accept your ruling, <b>you are not</b> liable to <b>pay</b> restitution to the party who lost the case due to your erroneous ruling. <b>But if</b> they did <b>not</b> accept you on themselves, but were rather compelled to be judged before you, you must <b>go</b> and <b>pay</b> restitution. And <b>learn from it</b> that even in a case <b>where one did not receive permission</b> to judge as the lone judge, <b>his ruling is</b> a valid <b>judgment.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from it</b> that this is the case.
§ <b>Rav says: One who wants to adjudicate a case and wants to be exempt</b> from payment of restitution <b>if he errs</b> in his judgment <b>must receive permission from the Exilarch</b> to judge cases. <b>And similarly, Shmuel says:</b> In such a case <b>he must receive permission from the Exilarch.</b> Once he receives permission, even an erroneous decision carries halakhic force and therefore it is as if he did not err.
Since the Gemara mentioned the importance of a judge receiving authorization from the Exilarch, it now discusses the scope of this authority. It is <b>obvious</b> that <b>from here to here,</b> meaning relying on permission granted by the Exilarch in Babylonia in order to adjudicate cases within Babylonia, <b>and from there to there,</b> relying on permission granted by the <i>Nasi</i> in Eretz Yisrael in order to adjudicate cases within Eretz Yisrael, the authorization <b>is effective. And</b> it is also obvious that <b>from here to there,</b> relying on permission granted by the Exilarch to adjudicate cases within Eretz Yisrael, it <b>is also effective,</b> as the authority of the Exilarch is greater than that of the <i>Nasi</i>. This is so <b>since</b> the Exilarch <b>here</b> in Babylonia may be termed <b>a scepter,</b> i.e., a ruler with actual power of governance, <b>and</b> the <i>Nasi</i> <b>there</b> in Eretz Yisrael is only <b>a staff,</b> i.e., a legislator with limited power.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “The scepter shall not depart from Judah nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet until Shiloh comes” (Genesis 49:10). The term “Shiloh” is understood as a reference to the Messiah, and therefore the verse is interpreted as delineating the authority of Jewish rulers during the exile, before the Messiah comes. <b>“The scepter shall not depart from Judah”; these are the Exilarchs in Babylonia, who</b> are empowered by the government and consequently <b>subjugate the Jewish people</b> as <b>with a scepter. “Nor the ruler’s staff from between his feet”; These are the grandchildren of Hillel</b> the Elder <b>who</b> hold the position of <i>Nasi</i> and <b>teach Torah in public,</b> but do not have authority to actually enforce their judgments.
If one has permission <b>from there,</b> from the <i>Nasi</i>, and wants <b>to</b> adjudicate cases <b>here</b> in Babylonia, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an incident <b>that</b> occurred: <b>Rabba bar Ḥana adjudicated a case</b> in Babylonia <b>and erred. He came before Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> to ask what he should do. Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to him: If</b> the litigants <b>accepted you upon themselves, you are not</b> liable to <b>pay</b> restitution to the party who unjustly lost the case, <b>but if not, go</b> and <b>pay. But Rabba bar Ḥana received permission</b> from the <i>Nasi</i> in Eretz Yisrael; therefore, <b>learn from</b> this incident that permission <b>from there to</b> adjudicate cases <b>here is not effective.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from it</b> that this is the case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is this permission <b>not effective? But when Rabba bar Rav Huna was</b> involved <b>in a dispute with the</b> members of <b>the house of the Exilarch he said:</b> It is <b>not from you</b> that <b>I received permission</b> to judge cases. <b>I received permission from my father, my master,</b> i.e., Rav Huna, <b>and my father, my master,</b> received permission <b>from Rav, and Rav from Rabbi Ḥiyya, and Rabbi Ḥiyya from Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi in Eretz Yisrael. Therefore, it seems that permission received in Eretz Yisrael is in fact effective in Babylonia. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>He was</b> merely <b>standing up to them with words alone,</b> but there was no halakhic validity to his statement.
The Gemara asks: <b>But since</b> permission to judge received in Eretz Yisrael <b>is not effective</b> in Babylonia, <b>why did Rabba bar Ḥana</b> need to <b>receive permission</b> when he left for Babylonia? What was the value of that permission? The Gemara answers: The permission is effective <b>for the cities that stand on the borders</b> of Babylonia, which are not entirely in the jurisdiction of Babylonia, so permission from Eretz Yisrael is effective there.
§ <b>What</b> is the specific nature of this <b>permission?</b> The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabba bar Ḥana descended to Babylonia,</b> his uncle <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>My brother’s son is descending to Babylonia. May he teach</b> people and issue rulings with regard to what is prohibited and what is permitted? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>He may teach.</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya then asked: <b>May he</b> also <b>adjudicate</b> cases of monetary law, and be absolved from payment if he errs? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>He may adjudicate.</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya continued: <b>May he declare a firstborn</b> animal <b>permitted?</b> The male firstborn of a kosher animal may not be eaten, as it is supposed to be offered in the Temple. But if it acquires a permanent blemish it is unfit for an offering, and it may be eaten. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>He may declare</b> such an animal <b>permitted.</b>
Similarly, <b>when Rav,</b> who was also Rabbi Ḥiyya’s nephew, <b>descended to Babylonia, Rabbi Ḥiyya said to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>My sister’s son is descending to Babylonia. May he teach</b> people and issue rulings with regard to what is prohibited and what is permitted? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>He may teach.</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya then asked: <b>May he</b> also <b>adjudicate</b> cases of monetary law, and be absolved from payment if he errs? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi responded: <b>He may adjudicate.</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya continued: <b>May he declare a firstborn</b> animal <b>permitted?</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>He may not declare</b> such an animal <b>permitted.</b>
This incident raises several questions, which the Gemara asks in sequence. <b>What is different concerning this Sage,</b> Rabba bar Ḥana, <b>that</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>called him: My brother’s son, and what is different concerning that Sage,</b> Rav, <b>that</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>called him: My sister’s son? And if you would say that this was</b> the <b>situation:</b> Rabba bar Ḥana was his brother’s son and Rav was his sister’s son, <b>but doesn’t the Master say: Aivu,</b> Rav’s father, <b>and Ḥana,</b> the father of Rabba bar Ḥana, <b>and Sheila, and Marta, and Rabbi Ḥiyya, were all sons of Abba bar Aḥa Karsala from Kafrei?</b> Consequently, Rav would also be Rabbi Ḥiyya’s brother’s son. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav</b> was <b>his brother’s son who was</b> also <b>his sister’s son,</b> as Rabbi Ḥiyya’s half-brother married Rabbi Ḥiyya’s half-sister; while <b>Rabba bar Ḥana was his brother’s son who was not his sister’s son.</b> Therefore, he referred to Rav in a manner that emphasized the additional relationship.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that he called him: My sister’s son, for a different reason:

Daf 5b

It was <b>due to his</b> extraordinary <b>wisdom, as it is written: “Say to wisdom: You are my sister”</b> (Proverbs 7:4). Therefore, calling him: My sister’s son, was an indication of his great wisdom.
The Gemara had related that Rabbi Ḥiyya asked Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: May Rav <b>declare a firstborn</b> animal <b>permitted,</b> and that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi had responded: <b>He may not declare</b> such an animal <b>permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that he denied him this permission? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>because</b> Rav <b>was not</b> sufficiently <b>wise</b> and learned, <b>but</b> that is difficult, as <b>we</b> already <b>said that he was exceedingly wise. Rather,</b> it must be that it was <b>because,</b> although he was quite knowledgeable about the <i>halakha</i>, <b>he was not an expert with regard to blemishes,</b> meaning that he lacked the practical expertise to apply the <i>halakha</i> to actual cases.
The Gemara rejects this answer. <b>But didn’t Rav say: I apprenticed with a shepherd</b> for <b>eighteen months</b> in order to be able <b>to know which</b> blemish is <b>a permanent blemish, and which</b> is <b>a temporary blemish?</b> Evidently, he had a high level of practical expertise in this matter. The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> it was in order <b>to bestow honor upon Rabba bar Ḥana.</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi wanted to ensure that Rabba bar Ḥana would be treated with respect, so he made sure that there was an area of <i>halakha</i> with regard to which the people would not be able to consult with Rav and would need to consult with Rabba bar Ḥana instead.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>It is due to this</b> fact <b>itself: Since Rav was a great expert with regard to blemishes, he</b> would <b>permit blemishes</b> that average <b>people do not know about. And</b> as a result, <b>they would</b> erroneously <b>say</b> with regard to a different blemish: In <b>a case like this Rav declared</b> the animal <b>permitted, and</b> in this way <b>they would come to</b> erroneously <b>permit</b> an animal with <b>a temporary blemish,</b> believing it to be identical to the blemish that Rav had declared permitted. Due to this concern, Rav was denied the authority to declare firstborn animals permitted on the basis of a blemish.
With regard to the permission granted to Rabba bar Ḥana and Rav, the Gemara had related that Rabbi Ḥiyya asked Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>May he teach</b> people and issue rulings concerning what is prohibited and what is permitted? And Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi responded: <b>He may teach.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If he had studied</b> and mastered the relevant <i>halakhot</i>, <b>why do I</b> need him <b>to receive permission?</b> The need for formal authority is understandable when it comes to serving on a court to judge cases of monetary law, but any knowledgeable person should be qualified to answer questions about ritual law. The Gemara explains: The need for such permission is <b>due to an incident that took place.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>once went to a certain place, and he saw people</b> there <b>kneading dough</b> while they were <b>in</b> a state of ritual <b>impurity,</b> and they believed that nevertheless, the dough remained ritually pure. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to them: For what</b> reason <b>are you kneading your dough in</b> a state of ritual <b>impurity? They said to him: A certain Torah scholar came here and taught us</b> that <b>water</b> from <b>swamps [<i>mei betza’im</i>] does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to contract ritual impurity. Therefore, they would take water from swamps and knead dough with it, in the mistaken belief that such dough would not be susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>But</b> in reality, what <b>he taught them</b> was that <b>water of eggs [<i>mei beitzim</i>],</b> i.e., the albumin of eggs, does not render food susceptible to impurity, as it is not considered water. <b>But they thought he said: Water</b> from <b>swamps.</b>
<b>And</b> the residents of that same place <b>erred also with regard to this:</b> It was taught in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 8:10): <b>The waters of</b> the <b>Keramiyyon</b> River <b>and the waters of</b> the <b>Piga</b> River <b>are not fit</b> for mixing with ashes of the red heifer to use as water of purification, <b>since they are water</b> from <b>swamps. And they</b> erroneously <b>thought: Since</b> this water <b>is not fit</b> for use as <b>water of purification,</b> this means it is not considered water, and therefore <b>it also does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to contracting impurity. <b>But it is not so,</b> as <b>there, with regard to</b> water of <b>purification, we need: “Running water”</b> (see Numbers 19:17), and water from swamps is not running water. But <b>here,</b> with regard to <b>rendering</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity, <b>any</b> water <b>renders</b> food <b>susceptible.</b>
<b>It was taught: At that time,</b> when Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi discovered the consequences resulting from a Torah scholar who was not precise with his terminology, the Sages <b>decreed: A Torah scholar may not teach</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>unless he receives permission from his teacher</b> to do so. The teacher should not grant him this permission if he does not know how to express himself in a clear manner.
Concerning a similar matter, the Gemara relates: <b>Tanḥum, son of Rabbi Ami, arrived</b> at a place called <b>Ḥatar,</b> and <b>he taught them: It is permitted to wash wheat</b> in a small amount of water in order to make it easier to peel during the grinding process <b>on Passover,</b> and there is no concern that perhaps it will become leavened. <b>They said to him: Isn’t Rabbi Mani from Tyre here</b> i.e., near our location? <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A Torah scholar may not teach</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in the vicinity of his teacher, unless he is distant from</b> the teacher by at least <b>three parasangs [<i>parsaot</i>], corresponding to the</b> size of the <b>camp of Israel.</b> In the encampment in the wilderness no one else judged cases, as all the Jewish people brought their cases to Moses (see Exodus 33:7). Tanḥum, son of Rabbi Ami, <b>said to them: It did not enter my mind</b> that Rabbi Mani was in the vicinity.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya saw a certain man standing in a cemetery. He said to him: Are you not the son of so-and-so</b> the <b>priest?</b> As it is prohibited for priests to come into contact with the dead (see Leviticus 21:1–4), Rabbi Ḥiyya was surprised to see a priest standing in a cemetery. The man <b>said to him: Yes,</b> but <b>that man’s,</b> meaning his own, <b>father was</b> a man <b>with raised eyes</b> who would desire things that he saw, even if they were forbidden. <b>He set his eyes upon a divorcée</b> and married her despite the Torah prohibition against such a union (see Leviticus 21:7), <b>and</b> thereby <b>disqualified</b> the offspring of that union from the sanctity of priesthood. As the son of a priest and a divorcée, the man had the status of a <i>ḥalal</i> and was therefore not obligated to abide by the restrictions specific to priests.
Continuing the discussion about receiving permission to teach <i>halakha</i>, the Gemara discusses the extent of this authority. It is <b>obvious</b> that one’s teacher can grant <b>partial</b> permission, meaning permission to rule on certain types of cases but not others, as <b>it has been said</b> above <b>that</b> doing so is <b>effective.</b> But <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to granting such permission <b>conditionally?</b> Is it possible to grant permission limited to a certain period of time, or limited to a certain location? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the solution to this matter from what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Rav Shemen: You have our permission</b> to instruct and to adjudicate <b>until you return to us.</b> This statement proves that it is possible to grant permission limited to a specific period of time.
§ Earlier, the Gemara discussed the possibility of a court consisting of only two judges adjudicating a case. Concerning <b>the</b> matter <b>itself, Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>two</b> judges <b>who adjudicated</b> a case, <b>their judgment is</b> a valid <b>judgment, but they are called an impudent court. Rav Naḥman sat and said this <i>halakha</i>. Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman</b> from a mishna (29a): In a case where three judges are adjudicating a case, <b>even</b> if <b>two</b> judges <b>deem</b> the defendant <b>exempt</b> from payment <b>or two</b> judges <b>deem</b> him <b>liable</b> to pay, <b>and one says: I do not know, the judges must add</b> another judge, since the one who abstained has removed himself from the court, and there are not enough judges. <b>And if it is so</b> as Shmuel says, <b>they should be</b> viewed <b>as two</b> judges <b>who adjudicated</b> the case, and there would be no need to add another judge, as a judgment passed by two judges is valid.
Rav Naḥman answered him: <b>It is different there, as they convened from the outset with the knowledge that they are three</b> and intended to judge the case with three judges. Therefore, if one abstains, they must add another to complete the quorum. But <b>here they did not convene with the knowledge that they are three,</b> but rather intended to adjudicate the case as a court of two judges.
Rava <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Naḥman from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> Cases of monetary <b>law</b> are adjudicated <b>by three</b> judges, <b>and</b> mediation leading to <b>compromise</b> can be performed <b>by two</b> mediators. <b>And the power of compromise is greater than the power of adjudication, as</b> if <b>two</b> judges <b>adjudicated</b> a case, <b>the litigants are able to withdraw</b> from the case and demand a court with a complete quorum. <b>But</b> if <b>two</b> mediated <b>a compromise, the litigants may not withdraw.</b>

Daf 6a
