He is made to stand at the edge of the platform, and then <b>one of the witnesses</b> who testified against him <b>pushes him</b> down <b>by the hips,</b> so that he falls face up onto the ground. If <b>he turned over onto his chest,</b> with his face downward, the witness <b>turns him</b> over <b>onto his hips. And if he dies through this</b> fall to the ground, the obligation to stone the transgressor is <b>fulfilled.</b>
<b>And if</b> the condemned man does <b>not</b> die from his fall, <b>the second</b> witness <b>takes the stone</b> that has been prepared for this task <b>and places,</b> i.e., casts, <b>it on his chest.</b> And <b>if he dies with</b> the casting of <b>this</b> first stone, the obligation to stone the transgressor <b>is fulfilled. And if</b> he does <b>not</b> die with the casting of this stone, then <b>his stoning</b> is completed <b>by all of the Jewish people,</b> i.e., by all the people who assembled for the execution, <b>as it is stated: “The hand of the witnesses shall be first upon him to put him to death, and afterward the hand of all the people”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:7).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Adding together the height of the platform, which is twice the height of an ordinary person, <b>and</b> the condemned man’s own <b>height,</b> it turns out that <b>there is</b> a height <b>here three</b> times the height of an ordinary person. The Gemara asks: <b>Do we</b> really <b>need all that</b> height to kill him? The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to the <i>baraita</i> from what was taught in a mishna (<i>Bava Kamma</i> 50b) when discussing the <i>halakhot</i> of damage caused by a pit: Why does the Torah specify a pit when one is liable for the damage caused by any type of excavation that he digs into the ground? This teaches that <b>just as a pit that is</b> of <b>sufficient</b> depth <b>to cause</b> one’s <b>death</b> from falling into it is at least <b>ten handbreadths</b> deep, <b>so too, any</b> other excavations <b>that are</b> of <b>sufficient</b> depth <b>to cause</b> one’s <b>death</b> may be no less than <b>ten handbreadths.</b> If a fall of ten handbreadths is sufficient to kill a person, why must the platform from which the condemned man is pushed be twice the height of an ordinary person?
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> The <b>verse states: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself”</b> (Leviticus 19:18), teaching that even with regard to a condemned man, <b>select a good,</b> i.e., a compassionate, <b>death for him.</b> Therefore, even though the one being executed is likely to die from a fall from a lesser height, a platform is built that is twice the height of an ordinary person in order to ensure a quick and relatively painless death. The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, they should raise</b> the platform even <b>higher.</b> The Gemara answers: This is not done, <b>because</b> if the condemned man were pushed from a higher platform, <b>he would become</b> seriously <b>disfigured,</b> and this would no longer be considered a compassionate form of death.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>one of the witnesses</b> who had testified against the condemned party <b>pushes him</b> off the platform. Concerning this <i>halakha</i> <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived that the punishment of stoning can be fulfilled <b>by pushing</b> the condemned party from a high place, so that he dies from his fall? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to those who crossed the boundaries that were set up around Mount Sinai and touched the mountain: “Take heed to yourselves, that you not go up into the mountain, or touch the border of it; whoever touches the mountain shall be put to death; no hand shall touch him, but he shall be stoned or <b>shall be thrown down”</b> (Exodus 19:12–13). <b>And from where</b> is it derived that this punishment can be fulfilled <b>with</b> actual <b>stoning? The verse states: “He shall be stoned.”</b>
<b>And from where</b> is it derived that this punishment is sometimes fulfilled both <b>by stoning and by pushing,</b> i.e., if the transgressor did not die from his fall, he is then stoned? <b>The verse states: “He shall be stoned or shall be thrown down.” And from where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> the condemned man <b>died from the pushing,</b> the obligation to stone him <b>has been fulfilled,</b> and there is no further need to actually stone him? <b>The verse states: “Or shall be thrown down,”</b> with the term “or” indicating that only one of the two options must be fulfilled. <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> not only at Mount Sinai, but <b>even</b> with regard <b>to</b> future <b>generations?</b>

Daf 45b

<b>The verse states: “He shall be stoned [<i>sakol yissakel</i> ],”</b> with the doubled verb form indicating that the <i>halakha</i> applies in all places and at all times.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>if</b> the condemned party does <b>not</b> die from his fall, <b>the second witness takes the stone</b> that had been prepared for this task and casts it on his chest. The Gemara asks: Does the witness <b>take</b> the stone by himself? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: A stone was there</b> with <b>a weight</b> that could be lifted only by <b>two men.</b> The witness <b>takes it and places,</b> i.e., casts, <b>it on</b> the condemned party’s <b>chest. If he dies with</b> the casting of <b>this</b> stone, the obligation to stone the transgressor <b>is fulfilled.</b> This indicates that one individual could not lift the stone by himself. The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>itself should pose a difficulty for you,</b> as it first states that the stone was of <b>a weight</b> that could be lifted only by <b>two men,</b> and then it says that the witness <b>takes it and places it on</b> the condemned party’s <b>chest,</b> apparently acting alone.
<b>Rather,</b> both the mishna and the <i>baraita</i> should be explained as follows: The second witness <b>lifts</b> the stone <b>together with the other</b> witness, <b>but</b> then the second witness alone <b>casts it so that it should fall with force</b> upon the condemned party’s chest, as two people working together cannot aim their throw with precision.
The mishna teaches: <b>And if</b> the condemned party does <b>not</b> die with the first stone, then <b>his stoning</b> is completed by all of the Jewish people. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Never did a person repeat</b> the stoning, as the condemned party always died with the first stone cast upon him? The Gemara answers: <b>Did we say that they acted</b> so? Rather, <b>we said that if</b> the condemned party did not die with the casting of the first stone and <b>it was necessary</b> to try again, the stoning is completed by all of the people who assembled for the execution.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>a stone was</b> there, indicating that a special stone was kept in the place of stoning and used time and time again for this purpose. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The stone with which</b> the condemned party <b>was stoned and the tree on which</b> his corpse <b>was hung, or the sword with which he was killed, or the cloth with which he was strangled, all</b> of them <b>are buried</b> together <b>with him?</b> If so, the same stone could not have been used for every execution. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach <b>that</b> after the stones were buried with the transgressor, <b>they would prepare other</b> stones <b>and bring them</b> to the place of stoning <b>in their place.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that all of the items used in the execution <b>are buried</b> together <b>with</b> the transgressor. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> that <b>they are not buried</b> together <b>with</b> the transgressor? <b>Rav Pappa said: What</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it says that these items are buried together <b>with him?</b> They are not actually buried together with him in the same grave; rather, they are buried <b>within his grasp,</b> i.e., in the area surrounding his grave.
§ <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>the witnesses’ hands were severed</b> after the transgressor was sentenced to be stoned, so that they can no longer stone him themselves, the transgressor is <b>exempt</b> from punishment and is not executed. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? This is <b>because I need</b> to fulfill what is stated in the verse: <b>“The hand of the witnesses shall be first upon him to put him to death”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:7), <b>and</b> here this is <b>not</b> possible.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the witnesses themselves must stone the transgressor or else the sentence is not carried out, if <b>the witnesses lacked hands from the outset,</b> when they offered their testimony, <b>are they also disqualified?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as the verse states: “The hand of the witnesses,”</b> indicating that the hands <b>that were</b> there <b>already</b> when the witnesses gave their testimony must throw the first stone when the transgressor is executed. If the witnesses already lacked hands at the time of their testimony, others can throw the first stone.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Shmuel from what is taught in a mishna (<i>Makkot</i> 7a): In <b>any place where two</b> witnesses <b>testify</b> before a court <b>and say: We testify about so-and-so that his</b> death <b>sentence was issued in such and such a court, and so-and-so and so-and-so</b> were <b>his witnesses, he is executed,</b> and there is no need to retry him. This seems to indicate that the transgressor is put to death even if the witnesses are not there to throw the first stone. The Gemara explains: <b>Shmuel interpreted</b> the mishna as referring to a case where the witnesses who testify about the transgressor’s conviction <b>in</b> a different court <b>are the same witnesses</b> who had testified against him at his original trial, and they are present to throw the first stone.
The Gemara raises another difficulty against the opinion of Shmuel: <b>But do we</b> really <b>need</b> to fulfill what is stated in <b>the verse</b> exactly <b>as it is written? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse with regard to a murderer states: <b>“He that smote him shall be put to death, for he is a murderer”</b> (Numbers 35:21)? <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the murderer is put to death <b>with the</b> mode of <b>execution written concerning him,</b> i.e., decapitation. <b>From where</b> do I derive <b>that if you cannot put him to death with the</b> mode of <b>execution written concerning him,</b> e.g., if he is escaping from the court, <b>you can put him to death with any</b> mode of <b>execution with which you can put him to death? The verse states: “He that smote him shall be put to death [<i>mot yumat</i>],”</b> where the doubled verb teaches that he is put to death <b>in any case,</b> by any mode of execution. Here too, the condemned party should be executed even if the witnesses cannot cast the first stone.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> concerning a murderer, <b>it is different, as the verse</b> explicitly <b>states: “He</b> that smote him <b>shall be put to death,”</b> which serves to include all modes of execution.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>learn from</b> this <i>halakha</i> a principle that can be applied in all cases of capital punishment? The Gemara responds: This case does not prove a principle, <b>because</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the murderer and</b> of <b>the blood redeemer,</b> i.e., a relative of one who was killed who takes it upon himself to redeem his relative’s death, <b>are two verses that come as one, and</b> the rule is that <b>two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a principle. In other words, if a <i>halakha</i> is stated in the Torah with regard to two individual cases, the <i>halakha</i> is understood to apply only to those cases. Had the <i>halakha</i> applied to all other relevant cases as well, it would not have been necessary for the Torah to teach it twice. The fact that two cases are mentioned indicates that they are the exceptions rather than the rule.
The Gemara explains: The <i>halakha</i> that capital punishment need not necessarily be imposed in accordance with the Torah’s specific instructions is taught with regard to two cases, that of the murderer and that of the blood redeemer. The case of <b>a murderer</b> is <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that we said</b>. With regard to the case of <b>a blood redeemer, what is it? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“The blood redeemer shall slay the murderer</b> when he meets him” (Numbers 35:21). This <b>mitzva</b> of redeeming the death caused by an unintentional killer falls <b>on the blood redeemer,</b> a relative of the victim. <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> the victim <b>has no</b> blood <b>redeemer the court appoints</b> a blood <b>redeemer for him? As it is stated: “When he meets him,”</b> which teaches that <b>in any case</b> he shall slay the murderer, whether he is a relative or a court-appointed blood redeemer.
<b>Mar Kashisha, son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: And do we not need</b> to fulfill what is stated in <b>the verse</b> exactly <b>as it is written? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 71a) with regard to a stubborn and rebellious son: If <b>one of</b> the boy’s parents <b>is with-out a hand, or</b> is <b>mute, or lame, or blind, or deaf,</b> the boy <b>is not rendered a stubborn and rebellious son?</b>
This <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>as it is stated:</b> “Then shall his father and his mother lay hold of him, and bring him out to the elders of his city and to the gate of his place” (Deuteronomy 21:19). This serves to teach: His father and mother <b>“lay hold of him,” but not</b> those <b>without a hand</b> who cannot grab him; <b>“and bring him out,” but not</b> those who are <b>lame</b> and cannot take him out. And it is stated: “And they shall say to the elders of his city: This our son is stubborn and rebellious; he does not obey our voice; he is a glutton and a drunkard” (Deuteronomy 21:20). This verse serves to teach: <b>“And they shall say,” but not mute people; “this our son,” but not the blind,</b> who cannot point to the boy; <b>“he does not obey our voice,” but not the deaf.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> that in all these cases the boy is not rendered a stubborn and rebellious son? <b>Is it not because we need</b> to fulfill what is stated in <b>the verse</b> exactly <b>as it is written,</b> and this principle should hold true with regard to other verses as well? The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No, there,</b> in the case of the stubborn and rebellious son, <b>it is different, as the entire verse is superfluous.</b> Therefore, all of the conditions inferred from the verse must be precisely met or else the boy cannot be rendered a stubborn and rebellious son. One cannot apply this principle to other verses.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from what is taught in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to an idolatrous city, the majority of whose inhabitants engaged in idol worship, about which the verse states: “And you shall gather all the spoil of it into the midst of the open place of the city, and shall burn with fire both the city and the entire plunder taken in it” (Deuteronomy 13:17): If the city <b>does not have an open place, it is not rendered an idolatrous city;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> If <b>it does not have an open place, they make an open place for it.</b>
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva <b>disagree only with regard to</b> this detail, <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, <b>holds</b> that <b>we need an open place</b> that existed <b>from the outset</b> when the idolatry was committed, <b>while the</b> other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that <b>an open place</b> that exists <b>now is like</b> an open place that existed <b>from the outset. But everyone</b> agrees that <b>we need</b> to fulfill what is stated in <b>the verse</b> exactly <b>as it is written.</b>
The Gemara answers: This issue <b>is</b> the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:9) concerning the purification process of a leper, during the course of which blood and oil must be applied to his right thumb, right big toe, and right ear: If the leper <b>has no</b> right <b>thumb,</b> right <b>big toe,</b> or <b>right ear, he can never</b> attain <b>ritual purity,</b> as he cannot fulfill the conditions of the verse. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> In such a case, the priest may <b>apply</b> the blood and oil <b>to the place</b> where the missing finger, toe, or ear should have been, <b>and</b> the leper <b>has</b> thereby <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The priest may <b>apply</b> it <b>to his left</b> thumb, left big toe, or left ear, <b>and</b> the leper <b>has</b> thereby <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. The first <i>tanna</i> apparently holds that the Torah’s instructions must be fulfilled exactly as they are written, while Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon disagree and say that when this is impossible, they are dispensable.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The corpses of all those <b>who are stoned are hung</b> after their death; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say: Only</b> the corpse of <b>the blasphemer,</b> who has cursed God, <b>and</b> the corpse of <b>the idol worshipper are hung.</b>
The corpse of <b>a man is hung facing the people, but</b> the corpse of <b>a woman,</b> out of modesty, is hung with <b>facing the tree;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say:</b> the corpse of <b>a man is hung, but</b> the corpse of <b>a woman is not hung. Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Did Shimon ben Shataḥ not hang in Ashkelon women</b> who were found guilty of witchcraft, proving that the corpse of a woman who is executed is also hung? <b>They said to him:</b> No proof can be brought from here, as <b>he hanged eighty women</b> on that day, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the same court <b>may not judge</b> even <b>two</b> people charged with capital transgressions <b>on the same day.</b> It is therefore clear that he was not acting in accordance with Torah law, but rather his execution of the eighty women was an extraordinary punishment necessitated by unusually pressing circumstances.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the corpses of all those who are killed by stoning are hung after their death. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a related <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And if a man has committed a sin worthy of death, <b>and he is put to death, and you shall hang</b> him on a tree” (Deuteronomy 21:22): One <b>might</b> have thought that the corpses of <b>all those who are put to death are hung.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “His body shall not remain all night upon the tree…<b>for he that is hung is a curse of God”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:23), teaching that <b>just as the blasphemer,</b> who <b>is</b> liable <b>to</b> be punished by <b>stoning,</b> is hung after his death, <b>so too, all those</b> who are liable <b>to</b> be punished by <b>stoning</b> are later hung, but those who are liable to be executed in other ways are not hung after their death. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And the Rabbis say: Just as the blasphemer,</b> who <b>denies the principle</b> of belief in God, is hung after his death, <b>so too, all who deny the principle</b> of belief in God are hung after they die. But others, even if they are liable to be punished by stoning, are not hung after they are put to death.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? The Rabbis interpret</b> the verses based on the principle of <b>generalizations and details,</b> one of the methods by which the Torah is interpreted. And <b>Rabbi Eliezer interprets</b> them based on the principle of <b>amplifications and restrictions,</b> a different approach to biblical exegesis.
How so? <b>The Rabbis expound</b> the verses based on the principle of <b>generalizations and details.</b> The phrase <b>“And he is put to death, and you shall hang</b> him” is <b>a generalization,</b> as no particular offense is specified. The phrase <b>“For</b> he that is hung is <b>a curse of</b> God” is <b>a detail,</b> as a specific transgression is mentioned. <b>Were</b> the generalization and the detail <b>next to each other</b> in the same verse, <b>we would</b> apply the principle of generalizations and details and <b>say</b> that <b>the generalization includes only that which is</b> stated <b>in the detail.</b> Therefore, <b>this</b> transgressor, the blasphemer, <b>yes,</b> his corpse is subject to being hung after he is executed, but the corpse of <b>anyone else</b> is <b>not.</b>

Daf 46a

<b>Now that</b> the generalization and the detail <b>are distant from each other,</b> i.e., they are written in different verses, the verses <b>serve to include</b> one who was found guilty of <b>idol worship, as he is similar to</b> the blasphemer <b>in all matters.</b> He too is subject to be hung after he is executed.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer,</b> by contrast, <b>interprets</b> the verses based on the principle of <b>amplifications and restrictions.</b> The phrase <b>“And he is put to death, and you shall hang</b> him” is <b>an amplification.</b> The phrase <b>“For</b> he that is hung is <b>a curse of</b> God” is <b>a restriction. Were</b> the amplification and the restriction right <b>next to each other, we would</b> apply the principle of amplifications and restrictions and <b>include only</b> one who is guilty of <b>idol worship, as he is similar to</b> the blasphemer <b>in all ways. Now that they are distant from each other,</b> the verses <b>serve to include</b> all <b>those who are</b> liable to be <b>stoned</b> to death. All of their corpses are hung after they are put to death.
§ The mishna teaches that according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, the corpse of <b>a man is hung</b> facing the people while the corpse of a woman is hung facing the tree, whereas the Rabbis say that the corpse of a woman is not hung at all. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning</b> behind the opinion <b>of the Rabbis?</b> The Gemara answers: As <b>the verse states:</b> “And if a man has committed a sin worthy of death, and he is put to death, <b>and you shall hang him</b> on a tree” (Deuteronomy 21:22), which teaches that you shall hang <b>him</b> on a tree after his death, <b>but</b> you shall <b>not</b> hang <b>her</b> on a tree after her death. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer</b> would respond that that the inference to be drawn from this verse is that after his death they hang <b>him</b> by himself, <b>without his clothing.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive that the corpse of the executed man is hung without his clothing? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so</b> that they agree that the word “him” teaches that the corpse is hung without clothing. <b>But</b> the source of their ruling is <b>the verse</b> that <b>states: “And if a man has committed a sin,”</b> which indicates that <b>a man</b> is hung after he is put to death, <b>but a woman</b> is <b>not</b> hung after she is put to death.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Eliezer, what does he learn from this</b> clause of the verse: <b>“And if a man</b> has committed a sin”? <b>Reish Lakish says: That</b> clause of the verse serves <b>to exclude a stubborn and rebellious son,</b> who, according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, is not hung after he is executed, because he is not a man. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A stubborn and rebellious son is</b> first <b>stoned and</b> afterward his corpse is <b>hung;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer? Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says:</b> That part of the verse comes <b>to include a stubborn and rebellious son,</b> that his corpse is also hung. <b>What is the reason</b> for this?
The Gemara explains: <b>As the verse states: “And if a man has committed a sin,”</b> indicating that only the corpse of <b>a man</b> is hung, <b>but not</b> that of <b>a child,</b> thereby excluding a stubborn and rebellious son. And the word <b>“sin”</b> indicates that only the corpse of <b>one who is put to death on account of a sin</b> is hung, <b>to the exclusion of a stubborn and rebellious son, who is executed</b> not because of a sin that he has already committed but <b>on account of</b> what he is likely to do in <b>the future. This is</b> an example of <b>a restrictive expression following a restrictive expression,</b> as both expressions indicate that a stubborn and rebellious son is not hung after he is put to death. <b>And</b> there is a hermeneutical principle that <b>a restrictive expression following a restrictive expression</b> serves <b>only to amplify</b> the <i>halakha</i> and include additional cases. In this case, it serves to teach that the corpse of a stubborn and rebellious son is hung after he is put to death.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Did Shimon ben Shataḥ not hang in Ashkelon women</b> who were found guilty of witchcraft? And the Rabbis replied that no proof can be brought from there since he hanged eighty women on a single day, which clearly indicates that this was an extraordinary measure and therefore cannot serve as a precedent for normative <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rav Ḥisda says: They taught</b> that one court may not judge two capital cases on one day <b>only when</b> the two cases involve <b>two</b> different modes of <b>execution, but when</b> they involve only <b>one</b> mode of <b>execution,</b> the court <b>may</b> in fact <b>judge</b> them on the same day. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But the incident</b> relating to <b>Shimon ben Shataḥ involved</b> only <b>one</b> mode of <b>execution,</b> as all the women were accused of witchcraft, and <b>yet</b> the Rabbis <b>said to him that</b> the court <b>may not judge</b> them on one day.
<b>Rather, if</b> a ruling <b>was stated</b> citing Rav Ḥisda, <b>this is</b> what <b>was stated: They taught</b> that one court may not judge two capital cases on one day <b>only when</b> the two cases involving <b>one</b> mode of <b>execution</b> are <b>similar to</b> two cases involving <b>two</b> different modes of <b>execution. And what are the circumstances</b> of such a situation? <b>For example,</b> when there are <b>two</b> different <b>transgressions</b> that are punishable by the same mode of execution, the court may not judge two such cases in one day. <b>But</b> where there is only <b>one</b> mode of <b>execution and</b> only <b>one transgression,</b> the court <b>may</b> in fact <b>judge</b> two cases on one day.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that states: The same court <b>may not judge two</b> people charged with capital transgressions <b>on one day,</b> not <b>even an adulterer and an adulteress.</b> This indicates that a court may not judge two cases on one day even if the two cases involve only one mode of execution and the same transgression. <b>Rav Ḥisda interpreted</b> the <i>baraita</i> as referring to a case of adultery involving <b>the daughter of a priest and the man with whom she engaged in intercourse,</b> as the daughter of a priest is liable to receive death by burning, while the man is liable to receive death by stoning if the woman was betrothed to another man, or strangulation if she was married to another man.
<b>Or,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case of adultery involving <b>the daughter of a priest and those who rendered as conspiring witnesses</b> the witnesses who <b>rendered as conspiring witnesses</b> the witnesses who testified about <b>her.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: I heard that the court may administer lashes and</b> capital <b>punishment,</b> even <b>when not</b> required <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>And</b> they may <b>not</b> administer these punishments with the intention <b>of violating the statement of the Torah,</b> i.e., to disregard the punishment stated in the Torah and administer another punishment; <b>rather,</b> they may administer these punishments <b>to erect a fence around the Torah,</b> so that people will fear sinning.
<b>And an incident</b> occurred <b>involving one who rode a horse on Shabbat during the days of the Greeks, and they brought him to court and stoned him, not because he deserved that</b> punishment, as riding a horse on Shabbat is forbidden only by rabbinic decree, <b>but because the hour required it,</b> as people had become lax in their observance of Shabbat and therefore it became necessary to impose the severe punishment for a relatively minor offense. <b>Another incident</b> occurred <b>involving a man who engaged in intercourse with his wife</b> in public <b>under a fig tree, and they brought him to court and flogged him, not because that</b> punishment <b>was fitting</b> for him, as such conduct is not forbidden by the Torah, <b>but because the hour required it.</b> People had become remiss in matters of modesty; therefore, stringent measures had to be taken to rectify the situation.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>How do they hang</b> the corpse of one who was put to death by stoning? <b>They sink a post into the earth</b> with a piece of <b>wood jutting out,</b> forming a T-shaped structure. <b>And</b> the court appointee then <b>places</b> the dead man’s <b>two hands one upon the other,</b> ties them, <b>and hangs him</b> by his hands. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: The post</b> is not sunk into the ground; rather, it <b>leans against a wall, and he hangs</b> the corpse on it <b>the way that butchers do</b> with meat.
The dead man hangs there for only a very short time, <b>and</b> then <b>they immediately untie him. And if he was left</b> hanging <b>overnight, a prohibition is transgressed, as it is stated: “His body shall not remain all night upon the tree, but you shall bury him</b> that day, <b>for he that is hung is a curse of God”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:23). <b>That is to say:</b> Were the corpse left hanging on the tree overnight, people would ask: <b>For what</b> reason <b>was this one hung</b> after he was put to death? They would be answered: <b>Because he blessed God,</b> a euphemism for blasphemy. <b>And therefore the name of Heaven would be desecrated</b> were the dead man’s corpse to remain hanging, reminding everybody of his transgression.
<b>Rabbi Meir said:</b> The phrase “for he that is hung is a curse [<i>kilelat</i>] of God” should be understood as follows: <b>When a man suffers</b> in the wake of his sin, <b>what expression does the Divine Presence use? I am distressed [<i>kallani</i>] about My head, I am distressed about My arm,</b> meaning, I, too, suffer when the wicked are punished. From here it is derived: <b>If God suffers</b> such distress <b>over the blood of the wicked that is spilled,</b> even though they justly deserved their punishment, it can be inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> that He suffers distress <b>over the blood of the righteous.</b>
<b>And</b> the Sages <b>said not only this,</b> that an executed transgressor must be buried on the same day that he is killed, <b>but</b> they said that <b>anyone who leaves his deceased</b> relative <b>overnight</b> with-out burying him <b>transgresses a prohibition.</b> But if <b>he left</b> the deceased <b>overnight for the sake of</b> the deceased’s <b>honor,</b> e.g., <b>to bring a coffin or shrouds</b> for his burial, <b>he does not transgress</b> the prohibition against leaving him unburied overnight.
After the executed transgressor is taken down he is buried, <b>and they would not bury him in his ancestral</b> burial <b>plot. Rather, two graveyards were established for</b> the burial of those executed by <b>the court: One for those who were killed</b> by decapitation <b>or strangled, and one for those who were stoned or burned.</b> Once <b>the flesh</b> of the deceased <b>had decomposed, they would gather his bones and bury them in their</b> proper <b>place</b> in his ancestral burial plot. <b>And</b> soon after the execution, <b>the relatives</b> of the executed transgressor <b>would come and inquire about the welfare of the judges and about the welfare of the witnesses, as if to say: We hold no</b> grudges <b>against you, as you judged a true judgment.</b>

Daf 46b

<b>And</b> the relatives of the executed man <b>would not mourn</b> him with the observance of the usual mourning rites, so that his unmourned death would atone for his transgression; <b>but they would grieve</b> over his passing, <b>since grief is</b> felt <b>only in the heart.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Were it stated:</b> And if a man has committed <b>a sin</b> worthy of death <b>you shall hang</b> him on a tree, <b>I would have said</b> that first <b>they hang him and</b> only <b>afterward they put him to death, the way the</b> gentile <b>government does,</b> executing the transgressor by hanging. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And if a man has committed a sin worthy of death, <b>and he is put to death, and you shall hang</b> him on a tree” (Deuteronomy 21:22), teaching that first <b>they put him to death, and</b> only <b>afterward they hang him. How so? They delay</b> the verdict <b>until</b> it is <b>near</b> to <b>sunset, and</b> then <b>they conclude his judgment, and they put him to death, and</b> immediately <b>afterward hang him. One ties</b> him to the hanging post, <b>and another</b> immediately <b>unties</b> him, <b>in order to fulfill the mitzva of hanging</b> the corpse of the executed transgressor.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> From the verse: “And you shall hang him on <b>a tree,” I</b> would <b>derive</b> that the body may be hung <b>either</b> on a tree that has been <b>detached</b> from the ground <b>or</b> on one that is still <b>attached</b> to the ground. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “His body shall not remain all night upon the tree, <b>but you shall bury</b> him [<b><i>kavor</i></b> <i>tikberennu</i>] that day” (Deuteronomy 21:23). Based on the doubled verb, it is derived that not only must the transgressor’s body be buried, but the tree on which it is hung must also be buried. As the verse employs the same term to instruct that both must be buried, the verse teaches that the corpse must be hung on a tree <b>that</b> has already been detached from the ground and <b>is lacking only burial,</b> just as the corpse is lacking only burial. This serves to <b>exclude</b> hanging the corpse on a tree <b>that</b> is still attached to the ground and <b>is lacking</b> both <b>cutting down and burial.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The tree upon which the corpse is hung is not sunk into the ground; rather, it is leaned against a wall, as the verse teaches that the tree must be <b>lacking only burial.</b> This serves to <b>exclude</b> hanging the corpse on a tree <b>that is lacking</b> both <b>detachment and burial. And the Rabbis</b> say: <b>Detaching</b> from the ground a tree that had already been cut down and was later sunk back into the ground <b>is nothing,</b> i.e., it is an insignificant act.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>That is to say:</b> Were the dead man’s corpse to remain hanging, reminding everyone of his transgression, people would ask: <b>For what</b> reason <b>was this one hung?</b> They would be answered: <b>Because he blessed</b> God, a euphemism for blasphemy, and the name of Heaven would be desecrated. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The Sages <b>told a parable: To what is this matter comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to two brothers</b> who were <b>twins</b> and lived <b>in the same city. One was appointed king, while the other went out to</b> engage in <b>banditry. The king commanded</b> that his brother be punished, <b>and they hanged</b> his twin brother for his crimes. <b>Anyone who saw</b> the bandit hanging <b>would say: The king</b> was <b>hanged. The king,</b> therefore, <b>commanded</b> that his brother be taken down, <b>and they took</b> the bandit <b>down.</b> Similarly, people are created in God’s image, and therefore God is disgraced when a corpse is hung for a transgression that the person has committed.
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Meir said</b> that the phrase “For he that is hung is a curse [<i>kilelat</i>] of God” should be understood as follows: When a man suffers in the wake of his sin, the Divine Presence says: I am distressed [<i>kallani</i>] about My head, I am distressed about My arm. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is this <b>inferred?</b> How does Rabbi Meir understand the word <i>kilelat</i>? <b>Abaye says:</b> When a man is hung after he is put to death, God is <b>like one who said: I am not light [<i>kal leit</i>],</b> meaning: My head is heavy for Me, My arm is heavy for Me. God is in distress when He has to administer punishment. <b>Rava said to him: If so, he should have</b> said explicitly: <b>My head is heavy for Me, My arm is heavy for Me. Rather, Rava said:</b> When a man is hung after he is put to death, God is <b>like one who said: The world is light for me [<i>kil li alma</i>],</b> meaning: I am light, and therefore the world is heavy for Me, and I am in distress.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> word “<i>kilelat</i>” <b>is needed for</b> what it <b>itself</b> teaches, namely that a blasphemer is hung after he has been stoned. How, then, can it be interpreted as alluding to God’s distress at the death of a transgressor? The Gemara answers: <b>If so, the verse should have stated: One who curses [<i>mekallel</i> ]. What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>kilelat</i>?</b> It serves to teach the statement taught by Rabbi Meir. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>say</b> perhaps that <b>the entire</b> verse <b>comes for this</b> purpose, to underscore the dignity of the transgressor, who was created in God’s image, and not to teach the <i>halakha</i> governing a blasphemer. The Gemara responds: <b>If so, the verse should have stated: Lightness [<i>kilat</i>]. What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>kilelat</i>? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it:</b> Conclude that the blasphemer is hung after he has been stoned, and conclude that God is distressed at the death of a transgressor.
§ The mishna teaches that everyone, <b>not only</b> an executed transgressor, must be buried on the day of his death, if that is at all possible. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who leaves his deceased</b> relative <b>overnight</b> without burying him <b>transgresses a prohibition? The verse states: “But you shall bury him [<i>kavor tikberennu</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:23), doubling the verb for emphasis. <b>From here</b> it is derived <b>that one who leaves his deceased</b> relative <b>overnight</b> without burying him <b>transgresses a prohibition.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai: From where in the Torah is there a hint to</b> the mitzva of <b>burial? The verse states: “But you shall bury him [<i>kavor tikberennu</i>],”</b> doubling the verb for emphasis. <b>From here there is a hint to</b> the mitzva of <b>burial in the Torah.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>King Shapur,</b> the monarch of Persia, once <b>said to Rav Ḥama: From where in the Torah is there a hint to</b> the mitzva of <b>burial?</b> What proof is there that the dead must be buried and not treated in some other manner? Rav Ḥama <b>was silent and said nothing to him,</b> as he could not find a suitable source. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: The world has been handed over to the foolish, as</b> Rav Ḥama <b>should have said</b> to King Shapur that the mitzva of burial is derived from the verse: <b>“But you shall bury</b> him” (Deuteronomy 21:23).
The Gemara explains: In that case, King Shapur could have replied that the verse merely proves <b>that a coffin should be made for</b> the deceased so that he can be placed in it, not that the deceased should be buried in the ground, as the verse could be understood as instructing that the corpse be placed in some sort of receptacle, not in the ground. The Gemara challenges: Rav Ḥama could still have claimed that the mitzva of burial is derived from the doubled verb “you shall <b>bury him</b> [<i>kavor <b>tikberennu</b></i><b>].”</b> The Gemara answers: In that case, King Shapur could have replied that <b>he does not learn</b> anything from a doubled verb, which seems to be merely a stylistic choice and not the source of a new <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>But let</b> Rav Ḥama <b>say</b> that the mitzva to bury the dead is derived <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the righteous</b> forefathers, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, <b>were</b> all <b>buried.</b> The Gemara answers: King Shapur could have said that this was <b>merely a custom</b> of the time, but not a mitzva. The Gemara asks: Rav Ḥama could have derived the mitzva <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Holy One, Blessed be He, buried Moses,</b> which proves that this is the proper way to handle the dead. The Gemara answers: King Shapur could still have said that God acted in this manner <b>in order not to deviate from the</b> general <b>custom,</b> but this does not prove that burying the dead is a mitzva.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof that burying the dead is a mitzva, as the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite said about Abijah, son of Jeroboam: <b>“And all Israel shall eulogize him and bury him”</b> (I Kings 14:13). The Gemara answers: From here, too, there is no proof, as they may have buried Abijah <b>in order not to deviate from the</b> general <b>custom</b> of the world, and not because they were required to do so.
The Gemara proposes another proof: Jeremiah pronounced a curse upon the wicked, saying: <b>“They shall not be eulogized, nor shall they be buried; but they shall be as dung upon the face of the earth”</b> (Jeremiah 16:4), which proves that when no curse has been pronounced, the dead should be buried. The Gemara rejects this proof: From here, too, there is no proof that it is a mitzva to bury the dead, as Jeremiah cursed the wicked, saying <b>that they would deviate from the</b> general <b>custom</b> and not be buried. Due to all these difficulties, Rav Ḥama was unable to adduce incontrovertible proof that there is a mitzva to bury the dead.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Is burial</b> obligatory <b>on account of disgrace,</b> i.e., so that the deceased should not suffer the disgrace of being left exposed as his body begins to decompose, <b>or is it on account of atonement,</b> i.e., so that the deceased will achieve atonement by being returned to the ground from which he was formed?
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> that arises from knowing the reason that burial is necessary? The Gemara answers: There is a difference in a case <b>where</b> one <b>said</b> before he died: <b>I do not want them to bury that man,</b> i.e., myself. <b>If you say</b> that burial <b>is</b> required <b>on account of disgrace, it is not in his</b> power to waive his own burial, as his family shares in the disgrace. <b>But if you say</b> that burial <b>is</b> required <b>on account of atonement, didn’t he</b> effectively <b>say: I do not want atonement,</b> and with regard to himself one should be able to do as he wishes? <b>What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the righteous</b> patriarchs, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, <b>were</b> all <b>buried. And if you say</b> that burial is required <b>on account of atonement, do the righteous need atonement?</b> The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Yes,</b> even the righteous are in need of atonement, <b>as it is written:</b> “For <b>there is no righteous person on earth who does good and never sins”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:20), and so even the righteous need atonement for the few sins that they committed over the course of their lifetimes.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the verse referring to Abijah, son of Jeroboam: <b>“And all Israel shall eulogize him and bury him,</b> for he alone of Jeroboam shall come to the grave” (I Kings 14:13). <b>And if you say</b> that burial is required <b>so that</b> the deceased <b>should achieve atonement, these too,</b> i.e., Jeroboam’s other sons, <b>should also be buried so that they should achieve atonement.</b> The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>This</b> son, Abijah, <b>who was righteous, should achieve atonement</b> through his death and burial, but <b>these</b> other sons, who were wicked, <b>should not achieve atonement</b> even in death.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the curse pronounced by Jeremiah upon the wicked: <b>“They shall not be eulogized, nor shall they be buried”</b> (Jeremiah 16:4), which indicates that it is not on account of atonement that burial is required, as were that the case the wicked are certainly in need of atonement, and therefore they should be buried. The Gemara answers: This is no proof, as Jeremiah’s intention might be <b>that</b> the wicked <b>should not achieve atonement.</b> Therefore, the question of whether burial is necessary in order to prevent disgrace or achieve atonement remains unresolved.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Is the eulogy</b> delivered for <b>the honor of the living</b> relatives of the deceased, <b>or is it</b> delivered for <b>the honor of the dead?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> between the two possible reasons? The Gemara answers: There is a difference in a case <b>where</b> one <b>said</b> before he died: <b>Do not eulogize that man,</b> i.e., myself. If the eulogy is delivered to honor the deceased, he is able to forgo this honor, but if it is delivered to honor the living, he is not, as it is not in the power of one individual to forgo the honor of others. <b>Alternately,</b> the difference is with regard to whether it is possible <b>to collect</b> the eulogist’s fee <b>from the heirs.</b> If the eulogy is to honor the dead, it is possible to collect this fee from the heirs, even against their will, but if it is to honor the living, they are able to forgo this honor.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the verse that states: <b>“And Abraham came to eulogize Sarah and weep over her”</b> (Genesis 23:2), indicating that Sarah’s funeral was delayed until Abraham returned from Beersheba to Hebron to eulogize her. <b>And if you say</b> that a eulogy is delivered <b>due to the honor of the living, would they have</b> unduly <b>delayed</b> burying <b>Sarah due to Abraham’s honor?</b> The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>It was satisfactory to Sarah herself</b> that her funeral was delayed <b>so that Abraham could be honored by</b> eulogizing <b>her.</b> Since Sarah herself would prefer that Abraham eulogize her, there was no disgrace in waiting for Abraham to arrive.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different resolution of this dilemma from the verse referring to Abijah, son of Jeroboam: <b>“And all Israel shall eulogize him and bury him”</b> (I Kings 14:13). <b>And if you say</b> that a eulogy <b>is</b> delivered <b>due to the honor of the living, are these</b> people, Jeroboam’s surviving family, <b>worthy of</b> this <b>honor?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is satisfactory to the righteous when</b> other <b>people are honored through them.</b> Since that is their wish, they are eulogized even if their wicked relatives are honored as a result.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the curse pronounced by Jeremiah upon the wicked: <b>“They shall not be eulogized, nor shall they be buried”</b> (Jeremiah 16:4). If you say that a eulogy is delivered due to the honor of the living, why should the wicked not be eulogized, as perhaps they are survived by righteous people who are worthy of this honor? The Gemara answers: <b>It is not satisfactory to the righteous when they are honored through the wicked,</b> and therefore they prefer that a eulogy not be delivered for their wicked relatives.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution of this dilemma from what Jeremiah said to Zedekiah: <b>“You shall die in peace; and with the burnings of your fathers, the former kings that were before you, so shall they make a burning for you; and they will eulogize you, saying: Ah, master”</b> (Jeremiah 34:5). <b>And if you say</b> that a eulogy <b>is</b> delivered <b>due to the honor of the living</b> relatives of the deceased, <b>what difference does it make to him</b> if he is eulogized? The Gemara answers: It is possible that a eulogy is to honor the living, and <b>this</b> is what Jeremiah <b>is saying to</b> Zedekiah: Enjoy the thought that <b>Israel shall be honored through you</b> at your funeral just <b>as they were honored through your ancestors</b> at their funerals.

Daf 47a

The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from what was taught with regard to the verse: <b>“In his eyes a vile person is despised,</b> but he honors them that fear the Lord” (Psalms 15:4). <b>This</b> is referring to <b>Hezekiah, king of Judea, who dragged the bones of his father,</b> Ahaz, <b>on a bier</b> made <b>of ropes,</b> and he did not bury Ahaz in a manner befitting a king in order to disgrace him for his sinful conduct. <b>And if</b> the eulogy and other funeral rites are meant <b>to honor the living, what is the reason</b> that he acted this way, in a manner that brought disgrace upon himself and all of the Jewish people?
The Gemara answers: Hezekiah did this <b>so that his father would achieve atonement</b> for his sins through his disgrace. The Gemara asks: Can it be that <b>for his father’s atonement they would defer the honor of</b> all of <b>Israel,</b> who would have been honored by a proper eulogy for their late king? The Gemara answers: <b>It was satisfactory to</b> the people of <b>Israel themselves to forgo their honor for him</b> in order that their former king achieve atonement for his sins.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: Before he died, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to</b> his disciples: <b>Do not eulogize me in the</b> small <b>towns</b> that you pass as you take my body out for burial, but eulogize me only in the larger cities. <b>And if you say</b> that a eulogy is delivered <b>in honor of the living, what difference does it make to him</b> if he is eulogized also in the smaller towns? The Gemara answers: <b>He thought</b> that the people of <b>Israel would be more</b> greatly <b>honored through him</b> if they gathered together for the eulogies in the larger cities.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: If <b>one left</b> his deceased relative unburied <b>overnight for the sake of his honor,</b> e.g., in order <b>to bring him a coffin or shrouds, he does not transgress</b> the prohibition of “his body shall not remain all night.” <b>What, is it not</b> referring to <b>the honor of the deceased?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is referring <b>to the honor of the living</b> relatives of the deceased.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> can it be that <b>due to the honor of the living, they allow the deceased to remain</b> unburied <b>overnight?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> as <b>when the Merciful One states: “His body shall not remain all night upon the tree,</b> but you shall bury him that day” (Deuteronomy 21:23), it teaches that the prohibition applies only to cases <b>similar to</b> that <b>of</b> a person whose body is <b>hung</b> after his death, <b>who suffers degradation</b> when his corpse is left hanging overnight. <b>But here, since</b> the deceased <b>does not suffer degradation</b> when the funeral is delayed, as the delay is in order that the burial will be performed with greater dignity, there is <b>no</b> violation of the prohibition, and he may be left unburied overnight.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one left</b> his deceased relative unburied <b>overnight for the sake of his honor,</b> for example, in order <b>to assemble</b> the people from <b>the</b> neighboring <b>towns for</b> the funeral, or <b>to bring him</b> professional <b>lamenters,</b> or <b>to bring him a coffin or shrouds, he does not transgress</b> the prohibition of “his body shall not remain all night,” <b>as anyone who acts</b> in such a manner does so <b>only for</b> the sake of <b>honoring the dead.</b> This indicates that the eulogy and other funeral rites are performed to honor the deceased. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Anyone who acts</b> in such a manner <b>for</b> the sake of <b>honoring the living</b> does not transgress the prohibition, as <b>there is no degradation of the dead.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan says:</b> It is <b>a good sign for the deceased when he is punished after</b> his <b>death</b> and does not receive an honorable burial or eulogy, as his lack of honor brings him atonement for his sins. For example, if <b>the deceased was not eulogized, or</b> if <b>he was not buried, or</b> if <b>a wild animal dragged his</b> corpse, <b>or</b> if <b>rain fell on his bier, this is a good sign for the deceased. Learn from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that a eulogy <b>is</b> delivered for <b>the honor of the dead,</b> so that when he is deprived of this honor, he achieves atonement for his sins. The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>they would not bury</b> the executed transgressor in his ancestral burial plot, but rather in one of two special graveyards set aside for those executed by the court. The Gemara explains: <b>And why</b> is <b>all this</b> necessary? It is necessary <b>because a wicked man is not buried next to a righteous man. As Rav Aḥa bar Ḥanina says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a wicked man is not buried next to a righteous man? As it is stated: “And it came to pass, as they were burying a man, that behold, they spied a raiding party; and they cast the man into the tomb of Elisha; and</b> as <b>the man</b> came there, <b>he touched the bones of Elisha, and he revived and stood up on his feet”</b> (II Kings 13:21). The man, who was not righteous, was miraculously resurrected so that he would not remain buried alongside Elisha.
<b>Rav Pappa said to</b> Rav Aḥa bar Ḥanina: What proof is there from here? <b>Perhaps</b> the man was resurrected in order <b>to fulfill</b> Elisha’s request of Elijah: <b>“I pray you, let a double portion of your spirit be upon me”</b> (II Kings 2:9), as now Elisha resurrected two people, the son of the Shunammite woman and this man, as opposed to Elijah, who had resurrected only one person? Rav Aḥa bar Ḥanina <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: <b>If so,</b> there is a difficulty, as <b>is this</b> a reasonable explanation in light of <b>what is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The words “and stood up on his feet” indicate that <b>he arose, but he did not go to his home.</b> The man did not in fact live again but for a moment, indicating that he was resurrected not in order to fulfill Elisha’s request for a double portion of Elijah’s spirit, but in order to prevent the disgrace of having a wicked man buried next to Elisha.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, with regard to the verse: <b>“I pray you, let a double portion</b> of your spirit be upon me,” <b>where do you find that</b> Elisha <b>resurrected</b> a second person? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him:</b> That request was fulfilled <b>when he cured Naaman’s leprosy</b> (see II Kings, chapter 5), an affliction <b>that is</b> considered to be <b>equivalent to death, as it is written</b> with regard to Miriam’s leprosy: <b>“Let her not be as one dead”</b> (Numbers 12:12).
The mishna teaches that two graveyards were established for the burial of those executed by the court, one for those who were killed by decapitation or strangulation, and one for those who were stoned or burned. The Gemara explains: <b>Just as a wicked man is not buried next to a righteous man, so</b> too <b>an extremely wicked man,</b> i.e., one who committed a grave offense <b>is not buried next to a less wicked man,</b> i.e., one who committed a less severe offense. The Gemara challenges: If so, <b>let them establish four</b> different <b>graveyards,</b> one for each of the different modes of judicial execution. The Gemara answers. It <b>is learned as a tradition</b> that there are <b>two graveyards</b> for those executed by the court, and no more.
§ <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one unwittingly <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat and separated an offering</b> for this sin, <b>and</b> he then <b>became an apostate and subsequently retracted</b> his apostasy, despite his retraction, <b>since</b> the offering <b>was rejected</b> from being sacrificed while he was an apostate, <b>it shall</b> remain <b>rejected.</b>
<b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one unwittingly <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat and separated an offering</b> for this sin, <b>and</b> he then <b>became insane, and</b> later he <b>regained his sanity,</b> the animal that he had dedicated as a sin-offering may not be sacrificed. <b>Since</b> the offering <b>was rejected</b> from being sacrificed while he was insane, <b>it shall</b> remain <b>rejected.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> it <b>was necessary</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan to teach us this <i>halakha</i> in both cases. <b>As, had he taught us</b> only <b>the first</b> <i>halakha</i>, with regard to the apostate, I would say that only in that case is the animal rejected forever, <b>because</b> the owner <b>actively rejected himself</b> when he became an apostate. <b>But</b> in <b>this</b> case of insanity, <b>where</b> the owner <b>was rejected automatically,</b> not of his own choice, <b>I would say</b> that he <b>is considered as one who is asleep,</b> so that as soon as he regains his sanity, his offering is once again fit.
<b>And had he taught us</b> the <i>halakha</i> only in <b>this</b> second case of insanity, I would say that only in that case is the animal rejected forever, <b>because it was not in</b> the owner’s <b>power to regain</b> his sanity, as one who is insane cannot cure himself. <b>But there,</b> with regard to an apostate, <b>who has the power to retract</b> his apostasy, <b>I would say</b> that his animal is <b>not</b> permanently rejected. It was therefore <b>necessary</b> to teach us the <i>halakha</i> in both cases.
<b>Rav Yosef said: We, too, learn</b> a similar <i>halakha</i> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>consecrated</b> items <b>were</b> found <b>in</b> an idolatrous city, they are not destroyed together with the rest of the property of the city. Animals that had been <b>consecrated to</b> be offered on <b>the altar must be left to die,</b> and property that had been <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance may be redeemed</b> and is then desacralized. <b>And we discussed it: Why must</b> the animals that had been consecrated for the altar be left to <b>die? Once</b> the idolaters <b>are killed, they achieve atonement, and</b> therefore it should be possible <b>to sacrifice</b> their offerings <b>to the Most High. Is it not</b> the case that the animals must be left to die <b>because we say: Since they were rejected</b> when their owners engaged in idol worship, <b>they</b> remain <b>rejected</b> even after their owners achieve atonement for their sins with their death?
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Do you maintain</b> that <b>one who dies in his</b> state of <b>wickedness</b> without repenting <b>achieves atonement?</b> This is not the case, as <b>one who dies in his</b> state of <b>wickedness</b> without repenting <b>does not achieve atonement, as Rav Shemaya taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the priests: “There shall none be defiled for the dead among his people, but for his kin that is near to him, for his mother, and for his father” (Leviticus 21:1–2). One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even if his father</b> had become an apostate and <b>separated himself from the ways of the community,</b> his son the priest <b>shall become ritually impure</b> in order to bury him. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Among his people,”</b> which teaches that a priest may become ritually impure only <b>for one who performs the actions of his people,</b> that is, one who conducts himself as a Jew. This indicates that one who dies in his wickedness without repenting does not achieve atonement.
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: <b>Are you comparing one who was killed in his</b> state of <b>wickedness to one who died in his</b> state of <b>wickedness?</b> An unrepentant sinner <b>who died in his</b> state of <b>wickedness does not achieve atonement, since he died a natural death</b> and there was nothing to bring about his atonement. But a transgressor <b>who was killed in his</b> state of <b>wickedness achieves atonement,</b> even without repentance, <b>since he did not die a natural death,</b> but rather he was executed.
<b>Know</b> that this is so, <b>as it is written: “A song to Asaf. O God, nations are come into Your inheritance; they have defiled your Holy Temple;</b> they have laid Jerusalem in heaps. <b>The dead bodies of Your servants they have given to be food to the birds of the sky, the flesh of Your pious ones to the beasts of the earth”</b> (Psalms 79:1–2). <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>“Your servants” and what</b> is the meaning of <b>“Your pious ones”? Is it not</b> so that the term <b>“Your pious ones”</b> is referring to <b>literally, Your pious ones,</b> those who had always feared God; whereas <b>“Your servants”</b> is referring to <b>those who had initially been liable to</b> receive <b>punishment</b> for their sins, <b>but once they were killed, they are called “Your servants”?</b> This indicates that a transgressor who was executed achieves atonement even without repentance.
<b>Abaye said to Rava: Are you comparing</b>

Daf 47b

<b>those</b> referred to in the verse in Psalms who were <b>killed by</b> a heathen <b>government to those</b> inhabitants of an idolatrous city who were <b>killed by</b> a Jewish <b>court? Those who were killed by</b> a heathen <b>government, since they were killed unjustly, achieve atonement</b> through their deaths, even without repentance. But <b>those who were killed by</b> a Jewish <b>court, since they were killed justly</b> for their sins, <b>do not achieve atonement</b> unless they repent.
The Gemara adds: <b>Know</b> that this is true, <b>as we have learned</b> in the mishna: <b>They would not bury</b> the executed transgressor <b>in his ancestral</b> burial <b>plot. And if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>once</b> the transgressors <b>are executed</b> by the court, <b>they achieve atonement, let them be buried</b> in their ancestral burial plots. The Gemara rejects this argument: An executed transgressor cannot be buried in his ancestral burial plot, because in order to achieve atonement, both <b>death and burial are needed.</b> But once he is buried in the graveyard set aside for the wicked, he achieves full atonement.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava raised an objection</b> to this from another ruling in the mishna: The relatives of the executed transgressor <b>would not mourn</b> him with the observance of the usual mourning rites, <b>but they would grieve</b> over his passing, <b>since grief is</b> felt <b>only in the heart. And if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>once</b> the executed transgressors <b>are buried they achieve atonement, let</b> the relatives of the executed transgressor <b>mourn</b> him as well, as he has already achieved atonement.
The Gemara refutes this argument: An executed transgressor is not mourned, because in order to achieve atonement, <b>decomposition of</b> his flesh <b>is</b> also <b>needed.</b> Once his flesh has decayed, he has achieved full atonement. The Gemara notes that the language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches:</b> Once <b>the flesh</b> of the deceased <b>had decomposed, they would gather</b> his <b>bones and bury them in their</b> proper <b>place</b> in his ancestral burial plot, indicating that with the decomposition of his flesh, the executed transgressor achieves atonement, so that he may be buried alongside his righteous relatives. The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from</b> the mishna that this is so.
<b>Rav Ashi says</b> that an alternative resolution of the objection raised by Rav Adda bar Ahava may be suggested: <b>When does</b> the obligation of <b>mourning</b> a deceased relative <b>commence?</b> It begins <b>from</b> the time of <b>the sealing of</b> the grave with <b>the grave cover.</b> And <b>when is atonement</b> achieved? Atonement is achieved <b>when</b> the deceased begins to <b>see</b> and experience <b>a bit of the anguish of the grave. Consequently, since</b> the mourning rites <b>were set aside</b> at the time that they should have begun, <b>they</b> remain permanently <b>set aside,</b> even after the executed transgressor has in fact achieved atonement.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that the executed transgressor achieves atonement as soon as he experiences a bit of the anguish of burial, <b>why do I</b> need <b>decomposition of</b> his <b>flesh</b> to occur before he can be reburied in his ancestral burial plot? The Gemara answers: <b>Because it is impossible</b> to move a partly decomposed body in a respectful manner, and therefore they wait until the body is fully decomposed.
§ It was related that people <b>would take dirt from the grave of Rav</b> as a cure <b>for a one-day fever.</b> A number of people <b>came and told Shmuel</b> about this practice, thinking that perhaps the dirt should be forbidden, as one may not derive benefit from a corpse. Shmuel <b>said to them:</b> They <b>are acting properly, as</b> the dirt in the grave <b>is natural ground, and natural ground does not become forbidden</b> in any situation, <b>as it is written:</b> “And he brought out the <i>ashera</i> from the house of the Lord…and beat it into dust, <b>and cast the dust of it upon the graves of the common people”</b> (II Kings 23:6). This verse <b>juxtaposes the graves of the common people to</b> objects of <b>idol worship.</b>
This teaches that <b>just as</b> objects of <b>idol worship are not forbidden when attached</b> to the ground; the Gemara interjects by teaching the source of this <i>halakha</i>: <b>As it is written:</b> “You shall utterly destroy all the places, in which the nations <b>whom you are to dispossess served their gods, upon the high mountains,</b> and upon the hills, and under every leafy tree. And you shall overthrow their altars, and break their pillars, and burn their <i>asherim</i> with fire” (Deuteronomy 12:2–3); i.e., there is an obligation to destroy <b>their gods</b> that are <b>upon the mountains, but</b> there is <b>no</b> obligation to destroy <b>the mountains</b> that are themselves <b>their gods,</b> meaning that if people worshipped the mountain itself as a god, there is no need to destroy it, as anything that is attached to the ground does not become forbidden. The Gemara resumes the comparison: <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the prohibition against deriving benefit from a corpse, the dirt in the grave <b>that is attached</b> to the ground <b>does not become forbidden.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against this ruling from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one hews a grave for his</b> deceased <b>father</b> in one place, <b>and</b> he then <b>goes and buries him in a different place,</b> the son <b>may never be buried in</b> the grave that he had dug, as it is prohibited to derive benefit from a grave that had been prepared for another. This indicates that even that which is attached to the ground can become an item from which deriving benefit is prohibited. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing not with a grave dug in the ground, but <b>with a cave that was constructed</b> above ground out of rocks that were hewn from the ground. In such a case all of the stones used in the construction become forbidden, as they were detached from the ground.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a fresh grave</b> that was not designated for anyone in particular, one is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it. But if even <b>a non-viable newborn</b> that died <b>was cast into it,</b> one is <b>prohibited from</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from the grave. This indicates that even a grave that is attached to the ground can become forbidden. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> the reference is <b>to a grave that was constructed</b> above ground out of rocks that were detached from the ground.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>It turns out</b> that <b>you say</b> that <b>there are three</b> types of <b>graves,</b> and each type is governed by different <i>halakhot</i> with regard to whether or not a corpse may be removed from the grave and buried elsewhere: A newly <b>found grave, a known grave,</b> and <b>a grave that causes damage to the public.</b> How so? With regard to a newly <b>found grave,</b> i.e., a grave in which a corpse had been buried without the permission of the property’s owner, <b>one is permitted to remove</b> the corpse from the grave and bury it elsewhere. After <b>he has removed</b> the corpse, <b>the place of</b> the grave <b>is ritually pure and</b> he is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it.
With regard to <b>a known grave,</b> i.e., a grave in which a corpse had been buried with the permission of the property’s owner, it is <b>prohibited to remove</b> the corpse from the grave and bury it elsewhere. If one went ahead and <b>removed</b> the corpse, <b>the place</b> of the grave is <b>ritually impure and</b> it is <b>prohibited to derive benefit</b> from it.
As for <b>a grave that causes damage to the public,</b> e.g., a grave that was dug on a public road and causes the passersby to contract ritual impurity, <b>one is permitted to remove</b> the corpse from the grave and bury it elsewhere. After <b>he has removed</b> the corpse, <b>the place is ritually pure, but</b> nevertheless, it is <b>prohibited to derive benefit</b> from it. This indicates that even that which is attached to the ground can become forbidden, even after the corpse has been removed from the grave. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> the reference is <b>to a grave that was constructed</b> above ground.
Having cited this last <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara raises a question about one of its details: As for a newly <b>found grave,</b> is one really <b>permitted to remove</b> the corpse just because it was buried there without the owner’s permission? But <b>perhaps this is a corpse with no one to bury it [<i>met mitzva</i>].</b> If the deceased has no relatives or acquaintances to bury him, everyone is obligated to assist in his burial. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>a <i>met mitzva</i> acquires its place,</b> i.e., the corpse is buried where it was found, and one is not permitted to remove it. The Gemara answers: <b>A <i>met mitzva</i> is different, as it generates publicity.</b> Were the corpse buried in the newly found grave that of a <i>met mitzva</i>, people would have heard about it.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about the <i>halakha</i> in the following case: With regard to <b>one who weaves a garment for one who</b> has <b>died,</b> what is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Abaye says:</b> It is <b>prohibited</b> to derive benefit from the garment, even if it was never actually used as a shroud. <b>And Rava says:</b> It is <b>permitted</b> to derive benefit from the garment.
The Gemara explains their respective opinions. <b>Abaye says</b> that one is <b>prohibited</b> from deriving benefit from the garment, since he maintains that mere <b>designation</b> of an item <b>is</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> i.e., all the relevant <i>halakhot</i> of an item already apply once an item is designated for a specific purpose, whether or not it has been used for that purpose. Therefore, a garment woven for one who had died is forbidden as if it had already been used as a shroud. <b>And Rava says</b> that the garment is <b>permitted,</b> as he maintains that mere <b>designation is nothing,</b> and therefore the garment becomes prohibited only once it is actually used as a shroud.
The Gemara explains further: <b>What is the reasoning</b> behind the opinion <b>of Abaye? He derives</b> a verbal analogy between the word <b>“there”</b> written in the context of a grave, <b>from</b> the word <b>“there”</b> written in the context of <b>a heifer whose neck is broken.</b> The verse states concerning a grave: “And Miriam died there and she was buried there” (Numbers 20:1), and the verse states concerning a heifer whose neck is broken: “And the elders of that city shall bring down the heifer to a hard valley, which is neither plowed nor sown, and shall break the heifer’s neck there in the valley” (Deuteronomy 21:4). <b>Just as</b> it <b>becomes prohibited</b> to derive benefit from <b>a heifer whose neck is broken through</b> mere <b>designation,</b> i.e., as soon as the animal is designated as such, <b>here too,</b> it <b>becomes prohibited</b> to derive benefit from the items relating to a dead person <b>through</b> mere <b>designation.</b>
<b>And Rava derives</b> a verbal analogy between the word <b>“there”</b> written in the context of a grave <b>from</b> the word <b>“there”</b> written in the context of objects of <b>idol worship.</b> The verse states concerning objects of idol worship: “The places in which the nations…served their gods there” (Deuteronomy 12:2). <b>Just as</b> it <b>does not become prohibited</b> to derive benefit from objects of <b>idol worship through</b> mere <b>designation,</b> but only through actual ritual worship, <b>so too, here</b> it <b>does not become prohibited</b> to derive benefit from items relating to a deceased person <b>through</b> mere <b>designation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rava, what is the reason</b> that <b>he does not derive</b> a verbal analogy <b>from a heifer whose neck is broken?</b> The Gemara answers: Rava could have <b>said to you:</b>

Daf 48a

<b>We derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing <b>the accessories</b> relating to a dead person, e.g., a shroud, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing the <b>accessories</b> used in idol worship, e.g., the animal sacrificed to the idol. This is <b>to the exclusion of a heifer whose neck is broken, which is itself consecrated</b> for the ceremony taking place in the valley and is not an accessory used in that ceremony.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Abaye, what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> by way of a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing accessories used in <b>idol worship?</b> The Gemara answers: Abaye could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>we learn</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing <b>something that</b> involves a proper <b>way</b> of conduct, i.e., burying the dead, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> governing <b>something that</b> involves a proper <b>way</b> of conduct, i.e., the rite relating to the heifer whose neck is broken, as these are both mitzvot by Torah law. This is <b>to the exclusion of</b> objects of <b>idol worship, which do not</b> involve a proper <b>way</b> of conduct.
§ The Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> for the forthcoming series of attempted proofs concerning the dispute between Rava and Abaye: <b>Scarf; monument; that was hewed; pouch; craftsman.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against Rava from a <i>baraita</i> discussing ritual impurity that is contracted by treading: If <b>a scarf is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>treading,</b> e.g., after a <i>zav</i> sat or lay down upon it, <b>and</b> its owner then <b>designated it</b> as a cover <b>for</b> a Torah <b>scroll,</b> it is <b>pure of</b> the more severe level of ritual impurity, that which is imparted by <b>treading,</b> even without immersion, because it is no longer an object intended to be lied on or sat upon. <b>But</b> it is still <b>impure</b> with the less severe ritual impurity, that which is contracted <b>by touching that which is treaded upon.</b> This indicates that mere designation has halakhic significance and validity. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should read as follows: The owner of the scarf <b>designated it</b> as a cover for a Torah scroll <b>and wrapped it</b> around the scroll, so that there was not only designation, but an action as well.
The Gemara asks: If there was an action, <b>why do I</b> need for the <i>baraita</i> to say that the owner <b>designated it and wrapped it?</b> Wouldn’t wrapping alone have sufficed? The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda, as Rav Ḥisda says:</b> With regard to <b>this cloth that one designated for</b> the purpose of <b>bundling phylacteries in it,</b> if he already <b>bundled phylacteries in it,</b> then <b>it is forbidden to bundle coins in it,</b> as it was designated and used as an accessory of a sacred object. But if <b>he</b> merely <b>designated it</b> for that purpose <b>but did not</b> yet <b>bundle</b> phylacteries <b>in it,</b> or if <b>he bundled</b> phylacteries <b>in it but did not</b> previously <b>designate it</b> for bundling phylacteries, then <b>it is permitted to bundle coins in it.</b> Consequently, in the case of the scarf, it was necessary both to designate it as a cover for the Torah scroll and to actually wrap it around the scroll.
<b>And according to Abaye, who said</b> that <b>designation is</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: If <b>he designated</b> the cloth for the purpose of bundling phylacteries in it, <b>even if he did not bundle</b> phylacteries <b>in it,</b> it is prohibited to bundle money in it. In a case where <b>he</b> already <b>bundled</b> phylacteries <b>in it, if he designated</b> the cloth for bundling phylacteries, <b>yes,</b> it is prohibited to bundle money in it; but <b>if he did not designate it</b> for bundling phylacteries, bundling money in the cloth is <b>not</b> prohibited.
