If it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, doesn’t he say</b> that <b>both the betrothed</b> daughter of a priest <b>and the married</b> one are executed <b>by burning?</b> The opinion of Rabbi Eliezer does not accord with either of these opinions.
<b>And if it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> (see 51b), <b>doesn’t he say</b> that only the <b>betrothed</b> daughter of a priest <b>is singled out for</b> execution by <b>burning, but not</b> one who is <b>married?</b> In his opinion, if the daughter of a priest is <b>under</b> the authority of <b>her father-in-law,</b> i.e., if she is married, her punishment <b>is</b> death by <b>strangulation,</b> like any other married woman who committed adultery.
<b>Ravin sent</b> the following explanation <b>in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: This is the explanation [<i>hatza’a</i>] of</b> this <b>mishna,</b> i.e., the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Actually, it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. And this</b> is what it <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> act of adultery <b>whose</b> punishment <b>is less</b> severe <b>than the death</b> penalty <b>for</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>her father, here, in</b> the case of the daughter of a priest, she receives <b>the death</b> penalty <b>of</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>her father,</b> namely, execution <b>by burning. And what</b> act of adultery carries a less severe punishment than intercourse with one’s father? <b>It is</b> the case of <b>the married daughter of a non-priest; as the married daughter of a non-priest</b> who committed adultery is executed <b>by strangulation.</b>
With regard to <b>any</b> act of adultery <b>whose</b> punishment <b>is more</b> severe <b>than the death</b> penalty <b>for</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>her father, here, in</b> the case of the daughter of a priest, she receives <b>the death</b> penalty <b>of</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>her father-in-law,</b> namely, execution <b>by stoning. And what</b> case <b>is it?</b> It is the case of <b>the betrothed daughter of a non-priest, as in general, the betrothed daughter of a non-priest</b> who committed adultery is executed <b>by stoning.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya objects to this</b> explanation: <b>Does</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> the words <b>more</b> and <b>less?</b> These words, central to this interpretation, are not mentioned at all. <b>Rather, Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> an alternative interpretation:

Daf 51b

<b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, and this</b> is what he <b>is saying:</b> The expression: <b>With her father,</b> means <b>under her father’s authority,</b> i.e., she is still betrothed, and she is executed <b>by burning</b> if she commits adultery. <b>And</b> the expression: <b>With her father-in-law,</b> means that after getting married, she engages in intercourse <b>with her father-in-law,</b> and she is therefore executed <b>by stoning. And</b> if she commits adultery with <b>any</b> other <b>man</b> after getting married, she is executed <b>by strangulation,</b> like any other married woman.
<b>Rava says: What is different</b> between the wording of the two clauses of Rabbi Eliezer’s statement that allows for them to be understood differently? <b>Either</b> explain <b>this one and that one literally,</b> i.e., that she engages in intercourse with her father or father-in-law, <b>or</b> explain <b>this one and that one</b> as referring to the <b>authority</b> of the father or father-in-law.
<b>Rather, Rava says: Actually,</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> that burning is more severe than stoning, <b>and Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the married</b> daughter of a priest <b>is comparable to</b> that of <b>the betrothed</b> one. <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>the betrothed</b> daughter of a priest <b>we raise her</b> punishment by <b>one level</b> vis-à-vis the betrothed daughter of a non-priest, <b>from stoning to burning, so too,</b> with regard to <b>the married</b> daughter of a priest, <b>we raise her</b> punishment by <b>one level</b> vis-à-vis the married daughter of a non-priest, <b>from strangulation to stoning.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥanina objects to this</b> explanation: <b>Doesn’t Rabbi Shimon</b> himself <b>say</b> that both in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, i.e., whether she is betrothed or married, the daughter of a priest is executed <b>by burning?</b> His opinion cannot be interpreted contrary to his own statement.
<b>Rather, Ravina says: Actually,</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that the married daughter of a priest is executed by burning and the betrothed daughter of a priest is executed by stoning. <b>And reverse</b> the wording of Rabbi Eliezer’s statement as follows: When she is <b>with her father,</b> i.e., when she is betrothed, she is executed <b>by stoning, and</b> when she is <b>with her father-in-law,</b> i.e., when she is married, she is executed <b>by burning. And</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>states</b> the phrase: <b>With her father,</b> instead of simply stating that she is betrothed, is because <b>he was merely drawn</b> to the common usage, i.e., the wording of the verse, and <b>employed</b> it.
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> in this matter <b>is in accordance with</b> the explanation <b>that Ravin sent in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. Rav Yosef said</b> in response: Does one issue <b>a <i>halakha</i> for the messianic</b> period? Since the destruction of the Temple, courts do not have the authority to adjudicate capital cases (see 52b), and this authority will be restored only once the Temple is rebuilt, in the messianic period. Therefore, what is the purpose of stating the <i>halakha</i> in this matter when it is not currently relevant?
<b>Abaye said to him: If that is so, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>not teach</b> all the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the slaughter of sacrificial</b> animals, i.e., tractate <i>Zevaḥim</i>, as <b>it is</b> entirely <b>a <i>halakha</i> for the messianic</b> period. <b>Rather,</b> one studies these <i>halakhot</i> due to the principle of: <b>Study</b> Torah <b>and receive reward,</b> i.e., one is rewarded for the study of Torah regardless of its practical applicability. <b>Here too, study</b> Torah <b>and receive reward.</b>
Rav Yosef responded: <b>This is what I</b> meant to <b>say: Why do I</b> need <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> with regard to this subject to be stated? <b>Is a <i>halakha</i> stated</b> in <b>the discussion of</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s <b>statement?</b> The statements of the <i>amora’im</i> are merely explanations of how to understand the wording of Rabbi Eliezer’s statement, but there is no difference between them with regard to the <i>halakha</i>.
§ The Gemara discusses the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael that the betrothed daughter of a priest who committed adultery is executed by burning, whereas the married daughter of a priest who committed adultery is executed by strangulation. <b>What</b> is the source for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael?</b> It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the verse: <b>“And the daughter of a priest, when she profanes herself by playing the harlot”</b> (Leviticus 21:9), <b>the verse is speaking of a young woman who is betrothed.</b>
<b>Do you say</b> that it is referring only <b>to a young woman who is betrothed, or</b> that <b>it is</b> referring <b>even</b> to <b>a married woman? The verse states:</b> “And <b>a man who commits adultery</b> with another man’s wife, he who commits adultery <b>with his neighbor’s wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress shall be put to death”</b> (Leviticus 20:10). <b>All</b> adulterers <b>were included in</b> the category of: <b>“The adulterer and the adulteress,”</b> and were executed by strangulation, until <b>the verse singled out the</b> betrothed <b>daughter of a non-priest</b> for execution <b>by stoning and the daughter of a priest</b> for execution <b>by burning.</b> It is therefore derived that <b>just as when the verse singles out the daughter of a non-priest for stoning</b> the Torah states that the reference is to a woman who is <b>betrothed and not married, so too, when the verse singles out the daughter of a priest for burning</b> it is referring to a woman who is <b>betrothed and not married.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>The conspiring witnesses</b> concerning the daughter of a priest, <b>and</b> the <b>paramour of</b> the daughter of a priest, <b>are included in</b> the verse: <b>“And you shall do to him as he conspired</b> to do to his brother” (Deuteronomy 19:19).
The Gemara interjects and asks: <b>What</b> reason <b>is there</b> for the punishment of <b>“as he conspired”</b> to be applied with regard to <b>her paramour? Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be read: <b>Her conspiring witnesses are included in the death</b> penalty <b>of her paramour,</b> i.e., they are executed by strangulation, which they sought to impose upon her paramour. They are not executed by burning, which is the death penalty that they sought to impose upon her.
This is <b>because it is stated: “And you shall do to him as he conspired to do to his brother,”</b> which is interpreted to mean: “To his brother,” <b>but not to his sister.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: Both the betrothed and the married</b> daughter of a priest <b>are singled out for</b> execution by <b>burning.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even an unmarried</b> daughter of a priest who engaged in promiscuous intercourse should be executed by burning. This is incorrect, as <b>here it is stated: “Her father,” and there it is stated,</b> with regard to a betrothed woman who committed adultery: <b>“Her father”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:21). It is derived through a verbal analogy that <b>just as below,</b> the reference is to the <b>promiscuous intercourse</b> of one who has <b>a bond to a husband, so too here,</b> the reference is to the <b>promiscuous intercourse</b> of one who has <b>a bond to a husband.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael said to him: If</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a priest’s daughter who committed adultery is compared to the <i>halakha</i> of a betrothed woman who committed adultery, then it can be inferred that <b>just as there</b> the reference is specifically to <b>a young woman who is betrothed, so too here,</b> the reference is to <b>a young woman who is betrothed.</b> This serves as a proof for the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael, which is that only the betrothed daughter of a priest is executed by burning.
<b>Rabbi Akiva said to him: Yishmael, my brother, I derive</b> it from the fact that the verse could have stated: <b>“The daughter</b> of a priest,” but instead states: <b>“And the daughter</b> of a priest,” with the conjunction “and,” that married daughters of priests are also included in this punishment.
Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to him: And because you derive</b> this from the difference between the term <b>“the daughter”</b> and the term <b>“and the daughter,” we should take this</b> married daughter of a priest <b>out to</b> be executed by <b>burning?</b> This derivation of yours is inconsistent, because <b>if</b> the conjunction “and” <b>indicates the inclusion of the married</b> daughter of a priest, then it should <b>include the unmarried</b> daughter of a priest too. <b>And if it indicates the exclusion of an unmarried one, exclude the married</b> one as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> respond? The Gemara answers: According to Rabbi Akiva, the <b>verbal analogy</b> between the <i>halakha</i> of the daughter of a priest and the <i>halakha</i> of a betrothed woman <b>serves to exclude</b> the case of <b>an unmarried</b> daughter of a priest from execution by burning, <b>and</b> the distinction between the terms <b>“the daughter”</b> and <b>“and the daughter” serves to include the</b> case of <b>a married woman.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yishmael</b> challenged Rabbi Akiva’s opinion because he <b>thought</b> that <b>since</b> Rabbi Akiva had <b>said to him</b> that a married woman is included due to the distinction between <b>“the daughter”</b> and <b>“and the daughter,”</b> it was possible to <b>conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Akiva had <b>retracted</b> his derivation <b>from the verbal analogy,</b> which would have included a married woman, and instead derived the <i>halakha</i> only from the conjunction “and” in the term “and the daughter.” But in fact, Rabbi Akiva combined this derivation with the verbal analogy.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael, what does he derive from this</b> distinction between <b>“the daughter”</b> and <b>“and the daughter”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it for that which the father of Shmuel bar Avin taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Since we find that the verse differentiates with regard to male</b> priests <b>between unblemished</b> priests <b>and blemished</b> priests, as only unblemished priests may perform the Temple service, one <b>might</b> have thought <b>we should differentiate between their daughters</b> as well, and rule that the daughter of a blemished priest should not be sentenced to execution by burning for adultery. Therefore, instead of stating: <b>“The daughter,” the verse states: “And the daughter,”</b> to include the daughter of a blemished priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> derive this? The Gemara answers: He derives it <b>from</b> the verse: “They shall be holy to their God, and not profane the name of their God; for the offerings of the Lord, the bread of their Lord, <b>they offer; and they shall be holy”</b> (Leviticus 21:6). From the phrase “And they shall be holy” <b>it is derived</b> that all priests are considered holy, even if they cannot bring offerings in the Temple. Consequently, there is no difference in this regard between the daughter of a blemished priest and the daughter of an unblemished priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why does <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> not derive this <i>halakha</i> from this verse? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yishmael would say: <b>If</b> it were to be derived <b>from that</b> verse, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this matter</b> applies with regard to the priests <b>themselves,</b> who are considered holy even if they are blemished, <b>but not</b> with regard to <b>their daughters.</b> Therefore, the term “and the daughter” <b>teaches us</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the daughters of blemished priests is just like the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the daughters of unblemished priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b>

Daf 52a

<b>what does he derive from this</b> verse: <b>“She profanes her father”</b> (Leviticus 21:9), if he does not employ the term “her father” for a verbal analogy concerning a young betrothed woman who committed adultery, as Rabbi Akiva does?
The Gemara answers: He <b>requires it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir would say: Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “She profanes her father”?</b> To teach <b>that if</b> initially <b>they would treat</b> her father in <b>a sacred</b> manner, now <b>they treat him</b> in <b>a profane</b> manner. If previously they would treat him with <b>honor,</b> they now <b>treat him</b> with <b>degradation. They say: Cursed</b> is the one <b>who bore this</b> daughter, <b>cursed</b> is the one <b>who raised this</b> daughter, <b>cursed</b> is the one <b>from whose loins this</b> daughter <b>emerged.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi says: In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do we call even a wicked person</b> who is <b>the son of a righteous person: A wicked person, the son of a wicked person? In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Meir, who says that a sinful daughter profanes her father, and he too is treated with disgrace.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>This</b> describes <b>the mitzva of those who are stoned,</b> i.e., the process of execution by stoning. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> was <b>taught</b> in the mishna with regard to <b>which it teaches</b> now: <b>This</b> describes <b>the mitzva of those who are stoned?</b>
The Gemara answers: The Mishna states this <b>because it teaches</b> in the previous chapter (42b): When <b>the trial has ended</b> in a guilty verdict and the condemned man has been sentenced to stoning, <b>he is taken out to be stoned.</b> And it continues (45a): <b>The place of stoning</b> from which the condemned party is pushed to his death <b>is</b> a platform <b>twice the height</b> of an ordinary person. <b>And since</b> the Mishna <b>wants to teach</b> in the next mishna: <b>The mitzva of those who are burned,</b> and it will then proceed to describe the processes involved in carrying out the other forms of execution, <b>it also teaches</b> in this mishna: <b>This</b> describes <b>the mitzva of those who are stoned,</b> in order to summarize what was taught up to this point.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The mitzva of those who are burned,</b> i.e., the process of execution by burning, is carried out in the following manner: The executioners <b>submerge</b> the condemned one <b>in dung up to his knees</b> so he cannot move, <b>and they place a rough scarf within a soft one,</b> so his throat will not be wounded, <b>and wrap</b> these scarves <b>around his neck. This</b> one, i.e., one of the witnesses, <b>pulls</b> the scarf <b>toward himself, and that</b> one, the other witness, <b>pulls</b> it <b>toward himself, until</b> the condemned one is forced to <b>open his mouth,</b> as he is choking. <b>And</b> another person then <b>lights the wick and throws it into his mouth, and it goes down into his intestines and burns his intestines</b> and he dies.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: But if this</b> one who is condemned to death by burning accidentally <b>died at their hands</b> by strangulation, <b>they have not fulfilled the mitzva of</b> execution by <b>burning for</b> this person. <b>Rather,</b> the process is carried out in the following manner: One <b>opens the mouth of</b> the condemned person <b>with prongs, against his will, and</b> one <b>lights the wick and throws it into his mouth, and it goes down into his intestines and burns his intestines</b> and he dies.
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Tzadok said: An incident</b> occurred <b>with regard to a certain priest’s daughter who committed adultery, and they wrapped her in bundles of branches and burned her,</b> contrary to the process described in the mishna. The Sages <b>said to him:</b> That court did not act properly; they did so <b>because the court at that time was not proficient</b> in <i>halakha</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What</b> kind of <b>wick</b> is the mishna referring to? <b>Rav Mattana says: A wick of lead,</b> i.e., a long, thin piece of lead in the shape of a wick, which is melted and poured down into the intestines.
<b>From where do we</b> derive that burning means this kind of death? <b>It is derived from</b> a verbal analogy between the <b>burning</b> that is described in the context of capital punishment (see Leviticus 21:9) and the <b>burning</b> described with regard to <b>the assembly of Korah,</b> when they were burned by God (see Numbers 17:4). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the assembly of Korah, they were killed by <b>the burning of</b> the <b>soul</b> within the body, <b>but</b> the <b>body</b> itself remained <b>intact, so too here,</b> the condemned one is executed by <b>the burning</b> of the <b>soul, but</b> the <b>body</b> remains <b>intact.</b> He is not executed by means of the burning of the body with wood, as in that case the body would be consumed.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that there is a different source for this method of burning: It is <b>derived from</b> a verbal analogy between the <b>burning</b> that is described in this context and the <b>burning</b> that is described with regard to the deaths of Nadav and Avihu, <b>the sons of Aaron</b> (see Leviticus 10:6). <b>Just as there,</b> Nadav and Avihu were killed by <b>the burning of</b> the <b>soul, but</b> the <b>body</b> remained <b>intact, so too here,</b> the execution is carried out by <b>the burning of</b> the <b>soul, but</b> the <b>body</b> remains <b>intact.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where does the one who derives</b> that burning means this kind of death <b>from the assembly of Korah</b> derive that their bodies were not burned? The Gemara answers: He derives it from that <b>which is written: “And the firepans of these men who have sinned with their souls”</b> (Numbers 17:3), which indicates <b>that</b> only <b>their souls were burned, but</b> their <b>bodies were intact.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> Sage, who does not derive that burning means this kind of death from here, interpret the deaths of the assembly of Korah? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> burning <b>was actual burning</b> of their bodies. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>“With their souls”?</b> It means <b>that they were deemed liable</b> to be killed by <b>burning due to matters of</b> sustaining <b>their souls,</b> i.e., they sinned because Korah helped them fulfill their bodily desires, and consequently they followed him.
This latter explanation is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Reish Lakish. As Reish Lakish says: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “With the flattering mockeries of spitefulness [<i>maog</i>] they gnash at me with their teeth”</b> (Psalms 35:16)? It means that <b>because of the flattery</b> of those people <b>who flattered Korah over matters of eating,</b> i.e., because of the food and drink that he would give them, <b>the minister of Gehenna gnashed his teeth over them,</b> as they eventually sinned and fell into his hands. The word <i>maog</i> is interpreted homiletically here as alluding to <i>uga</i>, cake.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where does the one who derives</b> that burning means this kind of death <b>from the sons of Aaron</b> derive that their bodies were not burned? The Gemara answers: He derives it from that <b>which is written:</b> “And fire came out from before the Lord, and devoured them, <b>and they died before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 10:2). The term “and they died” indicates that it was <b>similar to</b> a natural <b>death,</b> in which the body remains intact.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> Sage, who does not derive that burning means this kind of death from here, interpret the death of the sons of Aaron? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> burning <b>was actual burning. And</b> in that case, <b>what</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And they died”?</b> It means <b>that</b> the fire <b>started from within them,</b> and therefore it was <b>similar to</b> a natural <b>death,</b> which occurs within the person. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Yosei ben Dostai says: Two threads of fire came out of the Holy of Holies and split into four, and two entered the nostrils of this</b> one, <b>and</b> the other <b>two</b> entered <b>the nostrils of that</b> one, <b>and</b> the threads of fire <b>burned them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written: “And devoured them [<i>vatokhal otam</i>]”?</b> The usage of the expanded term “<i>vatokhal otam</i>,” instead of the terser <i>vatokhlem</i>, indicates a limitation, i.e., only they were consumed, to the exclusion of their bodies. The Gemara answers: The verse means that the fire devoured <b>“them,” but not their clothes.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us derive</b> the correct method of execution by burning <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>bull</b> offerings <b>that are burned. Just as there,</b> the reference is to <b>actual burning, so too here,</b> perhaps there should be <b>actual burning.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that <b>one should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to capital punishment <b>from</b> the death of <b>a person,</b> i.e., either from the assembly of Korah or the sons of Aaron, <b>as</b> they share common elements: They deal with <b>a person, a sinner,</b> and <b>a soul</b> that is taken through burning, i.e., the person dies as a result of the burning. Furthermore, the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it after its designated time [<i>piggul</i>],</b> is not relevant in either case, whereas it is relevant to bull offerings that are burned.
The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary, one should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to capital punishment <b>from</b> the <b>bull</b> offerings <b>that are burned, as</b> both <b>enable</b> the fulfillment of a mitzva, whereas the deaths of the assembly of Korah and the sons of Aaron were not mitzvot. Furthermore, both of these are fixed <i>halakhot</i> <b>for</b> all future <b>generations,</b> whereas the deaths of the assembly of Korah and the sons of Aaron were onetime incidents.
The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> elements that are shared by capital punishment and the deaths of the assembly of Korah and the sons of Aaron <b>are more numerous</b> than the elements that are shared by capital punishment and the bulls that are burned. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> is derived from the assembly of Korah and the sons of Aaron.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>the one who derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from the assembly of Korah, what is the reason he does not derive</b> it <b>from the sons of Aaron?</b> Because in his opinion <b>that was actual burning. But</b> if this is the case, <b>let us derive from</b> the death of the sons of Aaron that execution by burning should be performed with actual burning; why does he derive from the assembly of Korah that hot lead should be used?
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> The <b>verse states: “And you shall love your neighbor as yourself”</b> (Leviticus 19:18), which teaches that even with regard to a condemned prisoner one should <b>select a good,</b> i.e., a compassionate, <b>death for him.</b> The method of burning described in the mishna is certainly faster and less painful than the burning of the entire body.
The Gemara asks: <b>And since there is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of Rav Naḥman, why do I</b> need the <b>verbal analogy?</b> Even without this proof execution by burning would have been performed with hot lead, as it is a less painful form of death.
The Gemara answers: <b>Were it not</b> for the <b>verbal analogy, I would say</b> that a death that includes <b>the burning of</b> the <b>soul, but</b> the <b>body</b> itself remains <b>intact, is not burning at all,</b> and that it does not fulfill the mitzva of execution by burning. <b>And if</b> it is necessary to alleviate the condemned one’s pain <b>due to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>“And you shall love your neighbor as yourself” (Leviticus 19:18), let</b> the court <b>increase for him the bundles of branches, so that he will burn quicker.</b> Therefore, the verbal analogy <b>teaches us</b> that even internal burning is regarded as burning, and once this has been established it is taken into consideration that he must be executed in the least painful way.
Apropos the deaths of Nadav and Avihu, an aggadic midrash on this subject is quoted: <b>And</b> it had <b>already</b> happened that <b>Moses and Aaron were walking on</b> their <b>way, and Nadav and Avihu were walking behind them, and the entire Jewish people</b> were walking <b>behind them. Nadav said to Avihu: When will</b> it happen that <b>these two old men will die and you and I will lead the generation,</b> as we are their heirs? <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: We shall see who buries whom. Rav Pappa says: This</b> explains the adage <b>that people say: Many are the old camels that are loaded with the skins of young camels.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b>

Daf 52b

<b>To what is a Torah scholar compared</b> when he is standing <b>before an ignoramus? At first,</b> when he does not know him, the ignoramus considers him to be <b>like a goblet [<i>lekiton</i>] of gold.</b> Once <b>he has conversed with him</b> concerning mundane matters, he considers him to be <b>like a goblet of silver,</b> i.e., the stature of the Torah scholar is downgraded in the eyes of the ignoramus. Once the scholar <b>has received benefit from</b> the ignoramus, <b>he</b> considers him to be <b>like an earthenware goblet,</b> which <b>once broken cannot be fixed.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Imrata bat Talei was a priest’s daughter who committed adultery. Rav Ḥama bar Toviyya surrounded her</b> with <b>bundles of branches and burned her.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef says:</b> Rav Ḥama bar Toviyya <b>erred with regard to two</b> <i>halakhot</i>. <b>He erred with regard to</b> the ruling <b>of Rav Mattana,</b> i.e., that burning is performed using a wick of lead, <b>and he erred with regard to that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is derived from the verse: <b>“And you shall come to the priests, the Levites, and to the judge that will be in those days”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:9), that <b>at a time when there is a priest</b> serving in the Temple, i.e., when the Temple is built, <b>there is judgment</b> of capital cases. By inference, <b>at a time when there is no priest, there is no judgment</b> of capital cases.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, said: An incident</b> occurred <b>with regard to a priest’s daughter who committed adultery,</b> and she was executed by actual burn-ing, and the Sages said to him that the court at that time was not proficient in <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rav Yosef says: It was a court of the Sadducees,</b> who interpreted the verse according to its straightforward meaning.
The Gemara asks: <b>Did</b> Rabbi Elazar ben Tzadok <b>say that to</b> the Sages, <b>and did</b> the Sages <b>answer him in that manner? But isn’t</b> a different version of the exchange <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: I remember when I was a child, and was riding on</b> my <b>father’s shoulders. And they brought a priest’s daughter who had committed adultery, and surrounded her</b> with <b>bundles of branches and burned her.</b> The Sages <b>said to him: You were a minor</b> at that time <b>and one cannot bring proof from</b> the testimony of <b>a minor,</b> as perhaps you did not understand the proceedings properly. The two versions of this exchange do not accord with each other. The Gemara answers: <b>There were two</b> separate <b>incidents,</b> and Rabbi Elazar ben Tzadok testified with regard to both.
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> incident <b>did he tell</b> the Sages about <b>first? If we say</b> that <b>first he told them</b> about <b>this first</b> incident, i.e., the one that is recounted in the mishna, this is unreasonable; if he first <b>told</b> them about the incident that occurred <b>when he was an adult, and they paid no attention to him,</b> but rejected his statement by responding that the court was not proficient in <i>halakha</i>, <b>would he tell</b> them afterward about the incident that occurred <b>when he was a small child and</b> think that <b>they would pay attention to him?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is clear that <b>he first told them</b> about <b>that</b> incident, i.e., the one recounted in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and they said to him: You were a minor,</b> and one cannot bring proof from the testimony of a minor. <b>And</b> then <b>he told them</b> about the incident that occurred <b>when he was an adult, and they said to him:</b> The court did so <b>because the court at that time was not proficient</b> in <i>halakha</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The mitzva of those who are killed,</b> i.e., the process of execution by decapitation, is carried out in the following manner: The executioners <b>cut off his head with a sword, the way that the monarchy does</b> when a king sentences a person to death. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> This manner of execution is improper, as <b>it degrades him. Rather, they place the head of</b> the condemned <b>on the block, and chop</b> it off <b>with a cleaver [<i>bekofitz</i>].</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> If you are concerned about his degradation, <b>there is no death</b> penalty more <b>degrading than that.</b> It is better for him to be executed in the manner described first.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 9:3): <b>Rabbi Yehuda said to the Rabbis: I too, know that it is a degrading death, but what shall I do, as the Torah states: “And you shall not follow their statutes”</b> (Leviticus 18:3), i.e., it is prohibited to adopt the practices of the gentiles.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this claim? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> decapitation by the <b>sword is written in the Torah, it is not from</b> the gentiles that <b>we learn</b> it. This is Torah law, and the custom of the gentiles is not taken into consideration. It is of no import that they have a corresponding type of execution.
<b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that a Jewish custom is not forbidden even if the gentiles have the same custom, then <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> poses a difficulty. The <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>One burns</b> vessels and clothes <b>over</b> the deaths of <b>kings</b> as an expression of grief, <b>and</b> this is <b>not</b> forbidden <b>for</b> being <b>of the ways of the Amorites. How can we perform</b> this <b>burning? But isn’t it written: “And you shall not follow their statutes”? Rather, since burning</b> items over the death of a king <b>is written in the Torah, as it is written: “And with the burnings of your fathers,</b> the first kings who came before you, so shall they make a burning for you” (Jeremiah 34:5), it is <b>not from</b> the gentiles that <b>we learn</b> it. <b>And here too, since</b> decapitation by the <b>sword is written in the Torah,</b> it is <b>not from them</b> that <b>we learn</b> it.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna <b>in another chapter</b> of this tractate (76b): <b>These</b> transgressors <b>are those who are killed</b> by decapitation: <b>The murderer and the people of an idolatrous city,</b> there is a difficulty. <b>Granted,</b> the people of <b>an idolatrous city</b> are executed in this manner, as <b>it is written concerning them:</b> “You shall smite the inhabitants of that city <b>with the edge of the sword”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:16). <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a murderer, from where do we</b> derive that he is executed by decapitation?
The Gemara answers that it is derived <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is stated in the verse: “And if a man smites his slave or his maidservant by the staff and he dies under his hand, <b>he shall be avenged”</b> (Exodus 21:20). Prima facie, <b>I do not know what this vengeance is</b> referring to. <b>When it says: “And I will bring upon you the sword avenging the vengeance of the covenant”</b> (Leviticus 26:25), <b>you must say</b> that <b>vengeance is</b> decapitation by the <b>sword.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say that</b> the executioner <b>should stab him</b> with a sword, rather than decapitate him? The Gemara answers: <b>It is written</b> with regard to the people of an idolatrous city: <b>“With the edge of the sword,”</b> indicating that the execution should be administered with the edge of the sword and not its point.
The Gemara asks: <b>But say that</b> the executioner <b>should cut him in half [<i>gistera</i>],</b> down the middle of his body. The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> The <b>verse states: “And you shall love your neighbor as yourself”</b> (Leviticus 19:18), which teaches that even with regard to a condemned prisoner, one should <b>select a good,</b> i.e., a compassionate, <b>death for him.</b> Cutting his body in half is not a compassionate manner of execution.
The Gemara asks: <b>We have found</b> proof that one <b>who killed</b> a Canaanite <b>slave</b> is executed by decapitation. But <b>from where do we</b> derive that one who kills <b>a freeman</b> is executed in the same manner?
The Gemara answers: <b>But is it not</b> inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i>?</b> If one who <b>killed</b> a Canaanite <b>slave</b> is executed <b>by</b> the <b>sword,</b> should one who killed <b>a freeman</b> be executed merely <b>by strangulation?</b>
This Gemara rejects this answer: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>strangulation</b> is a more <b>lenient</b> type of capital punishment than decapitation. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>strangulation</b> is more <b>severe</b> than decapitation, <b>what can be said?</b> It is possible that one who murdered a freeman is in fact executed by strangulation.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>derives it from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is derived from the verse: <b>“And so shall you put away the innocent blood from your midst”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:9), that <b>all spillers of blood are compared to the heifer whose neck is broken</b> as atonement for an unresolved murder. <b>Just as there,</b> the heifer is killed <b>by</b> the <b>sword and at the neck, so too here,</b> murderers are executed <b>by</b> the <b>sword and at the neck.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If</b> so, perhaps it should be derived that <b>just as there,</b> the heifer is decapitated <b>with a cleaver and at the nape of the neck, so too here,</b> murderers should be decapitated <b>with a cleaver and at the nape of the neck.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> The <b>verse states: “And you shall love your neighbor as yourself”</b> (Leviticus 19:18), which teaches that even with regard to a condemned prisoner, one should <b>select a good,</b> i.e., a compassionate, <b>death for him.</b> Although the type of capital punishment is derived from the heifer whose neck is broken, the most compassionate method of decapitation is selected.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The mitzva of those who are strangled</b> is carried out in the following manner: The agents of the court <b>submerge</b> the condemned one <b>in dung up to his knees</b> so he cannot move, <b>and</b> one of them <b>places a rough scarf within a soft one, and wraps</b> it <b>around his neck. This</b> one, i.e., one of the witnesses, <b>pulls</b> the scarf <b>toward him, and that</b> one, the other witness, <b>pulls</b> it <b>toward him, until the soul of</b> the condemned one <b>departs.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states: “And a man who commits adultery with another man’s wife, even he who commits adultery with his neighbor’s wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress shall be put to death” (Leviticus 20:10). The term: <b>“A man,”</b> is interpreted as <b>excluding a minor boy</b> who committed adultery before he came of age. The phrase: <b>“Who commits adultery with another man’s wife,”</b> is interpreted as <b>excluding the wife of a minor boy;</b> marriage to a minor is not considered halakhic marriage. <b>“His neighbor’s wife” excludes the wife of another,</b> i.e., a gentile, who is not referred to as “his neighbor.”
<b>“Shall be put to death”</b> means death <b>by strangulation. Do you say</b> that his execution is <b>by strangulation, or is it rather by one of all the</b> other types of <b>death</b> penalty <b>stated in the Torah? You must say</b> that it is by strangulation, as <b>everywhere that</b> the <b>death</b> penalty <b>is stated in the Torah without specification you may not take it to be more stringent with regard to it,</b> i.e., to mean that the sinner should be sentenced to <b>a severe</b> type of execution; <b>rather,</b> you must take it <b>to be more lenient with regard to it,</b> i.e., that a lenient type of execution should be applied. Consequently, the sinner is sentenced to be executed by strangulation, which is the least severe type of capital punishment. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yonatan says: It is not because</b> strangulation <b>is</b> the most <b>lenient</b> type of capital punishment; <b>rather,</b> there is a principle that <b>every death</b> penalty <b>stated in the Torah without specification is nothing other than strangulation,</b> whereas the other types of capital punishment must be stated explicitly in the verse.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yonatan: <b>Death at the hand of Heaven is stated</b> in the Torah, <b>and death at the hands of a person,</b> i.e., court-imposed capital punishment, <b>is stated</b> in the Torah. <b>Just as</b> the <b>death at the hand of Heaven that is stated</b> in the Torah is <b>a death that leaves no</b> external <b>mark, so too,</b> the <b>death at the hands of a person that is stated</b> in the Torah is <b>a death that leaves no</b> external <b>mark,</b> i.e., strangulation.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that perhaps it is referring to execution by <b>burning,</b> which also leaves no external mark? The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One states</b> explicitly that <b>a priest’s daughter</b> who committed adultery is executed <b>by burning</b> one can learn <b>by inference that this</b> other woman who committed adultery <b>is not liable to</b> be executed by <b>burning,</b> but rather by a different type of execution that does not leave a mark, i.e., strangulation.

Daf 53a

<b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yonatan</b> it is clear the punishment for adultery is strangulation, <b>in the manner that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>explains the reason</b> for his opinion. <b>But according to Rabbi Yoshiya, from where</b> is it derived <b>that there is</b> a punishment of execution by <b>strangulation in the world,</b> i.e., in <i>halakha</i>, at all? Since this type of capital punishment is not mentioned in the Torah explicitly, <b>say</b> that decapitation by the <b>sword</b> is the least severe type, as it is mentioned in the Torah.
<b>Rava said:</b> The <b>four</b> types of the <b>death</b> penalty <b>are learned as a tradition.</b> There is no question as to the types of capital punishment that exist in <i>halakha</i>. Rather, the question is which type of execution is meted out as punishment for which sins.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by Rabbi Yonatan’s statement: <b>It is not because</b> strangulation <b>is</b> the most <b>lenient</b> type of capital punishment? The Gemara answers: At the root of the matter, Rabbi Yonatan and Rabbi Yoshiya <b>disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis,</b> i.e., whether strangulation or decapitation is the least severe type of execution. Consequently, Rabbi Yonatan does not employ the reasoning that strangulation is the least severe.
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Abaye:</b> With regard to <b>the rest of those</b> transgressors, other than necromancers and sorcerers, <b>who are stoned</b> to death, <b>with regard to whom stoning is not</b> explicitly <b>written</b> in the Torah <b>because</b> their punishment is <b>derived</b> via a verbal analogy <b>from</b> that of <b>a necromancer and a sorcerer,</b> about which the verse states: “They shall be put to death, they shall stone them with stones, their blood shall be upon them” (Leviticus 20:27); <b>through what</b> verbal analogy <b>is</b> their punishment <b>derived? Is it derived from</b> the phrase <b>“they shall be put to death,” or is it derived from</b> the phrase <b>“their blood shall be upon them”?</b>
Abaye <b>said to him: It is derived from</b> a verbal analogy between <b>“their blood”</b> and <b>“their blood shall be upon them.” As, if it is derived from “they shall be put to death,” why do I</b> need the verbal analogy between <b>“their blood”</b> and <b>“their blood”?</b> Why does this term need to be written with regard to the various <i>halakhot</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> is more reasonable? If <b>it is derived from</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“their blood”</b> and <b>“their blood,”</b> the same problem arises: <b>Why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“they shall be put to death”?</b>
The Gemara answers: This expression is necessary, as another <i>halakha</i> is derived from it. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse with regard to a murderer states: <b>“He that smote him shall be put to death, for he is a murderer”</b> (Numbers 35:21). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the murderer is put to death <b>with the</b> mode of <b>execution written concerning him,</b> i.e., by decapitation. <b>From where</b> do I derive <b>that if you cannot put him to death with the</b> mode of <b>execution written concerning him,</b> e.g., if the condemned man will escape if one does not kill him, <b>that you put him to death with any</b> mode of <b>execution with which you can put him to death? The verse states: “He that smote him shall be put to death [<i>mot yumat</i>],”</b> the doubled verb teaching that he is put to death <b>in any case,</b> i.e., by any mode of execution.
This exchange between Rabbi Zeira and Abaye was subsequently discussed by later <i>amora’im</i>. <b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: And if</b> the <i>halakha</i> that there are transgressors other than necromancers and sorcerers who are punished by stoning <b>is derived from “they shall be put to death,” what is difficult according to</b> Rabbi Zeira? It appears from Rabbi Zeira’s question that he was troubled by the possibility that this halakha is derived from the phrase “they shall be put to death.”
<b>If we say</b> that the case of adultery of <b>a married woman</b> would pose <b>a difficulty according to</b> Rabbi Zeira, as it is stated: “The adulterer and the adulteress shall be put to death” (Leviticus 20:10), and therefore perhaps <b>we should derive and learn from</b> the phrase “they <b>shall be put to death”</b> stated with regard to <b>a necromancer and a sorcerer</b> that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to a necromancer and a sorcerer, they are executed <b>by stoning, so too here,</b> with regard to adultery, the transgressors should be executed <b>by stoning,</b> this does not pose a difficulty.
Rav Aḥa of Difti explains why it does not pose a difficulty: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One states</b> that <b>a betrothed woman</b> who committed adultery is executed <b>by stoning, by inference</b> we learn <b>that a married woman</b> who committed adultery <b>is not</b> executed <b>by stoning,</b> but rather she is executed by a less severe type of execution. Therefore, it could not have been derived from the case of a necromancer and a sorcerer that the punishment for the adultery of a married woman is execution by stoning.
<b>And</b> if it is <b>rather</b> the case of <b>one who wounds his father or his mother</b> that poses <b>a difficulty according to</b> Rabbi Zeira, as it is stated: “And he who smites his father or his mother shall be put to death” (Exodus 21:15), and therefore perhaps <b>we should derive and learn from</b> the punishment of <b>a necromancer and a sorcerer</b> that one who wounds his father or his mother should be executed by stoning, this too does not pose a difficulty.
Rav Aḥa of Difti explains why it does not pose a difficulty: <b>Rather than deriving</b> the punishment of one who wounds his father or his mother <b>from a necromancer and a sorcerer, let us derive</b> it <b>from</b> adultery with <b>a married woman,</b> as <b>everywhere that</b> the <b>death</b> penalty <b>is stated in the Torah without specification you may not take it to be more stringent with regard to it,</b> i.e., to mean that the sinner should be sentenced to <b>a severe</b> type of execution; <b>rather,</b> you must take it <b>to be more lenient with regard to it,</b> i.e., that a lenient type of execution should be applied. Since in both the case of adultery and the case of one who wounds his parent the type of execution is evidently not stoning, why was Rabbi Zeira troubled by the possibility that the source for execution by stoning in cases other than a necromancer and a sorcerer is derived from the phrase: “They shall be put to death”?
Ravina <b>said to</b> Rav Aḥa of Difti: It is the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>the rest of those who are stoned, themselves,</b> which poses <b>a difficulty</b> according <b>to</b> Rabbi Zeira. This is <b>because if</b> their punishment <b>is derived from</b> the phrase <b>“they shall be put to death,”</b> then <b>rather than deriving from</b> the case of <b>a necromancer and a sorcerer</b> that these transgressors are executed by the severe method of stoning, <b>let us derive from</b> the case of one who commits adultery with <b>a married woman,</b> with regard to whom “they shall be put to death” is also stated, that they should be executed by strangulation, the less severe method. He therefore verified that it is derived from the phrase “their blood shall be upon them,” that they are executed by stoning.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>These</b> transgressors <b>are those who are stoned</b> to death: <b>One who engages in intercourse with</b> his <b>mother; or with</b> his <b>father’s wife,</b> even if she is not his mother; <b>or with</b> his <b>daughter-in-law; or with a male; or with an animal; and a woman who engages in intercourse with an animal. And one who blasphemes, and one who engages in idol worship. And one who gives of his offspring to Molekh, and a necromancer, and a sorcerer. And one who desecrates Shabbat, and one who curses his father or his mother, and one who engages in intercourse with a betrothed young woman, and an inciter</b> who incites individuals to idol worship, <b>and a subverter</b> who incites an entire city to idol worship, <b>and a warlock, and a stubborn and rebellious son.</b>
The mishna elaborates: <b>One who</b> unwittingly <b>engages in intercourse with</b> his <b>mother</b> who is also his father’s wife is <b>liable</b> to bring two sin-offerings <b>for</b> his intercourse with <b>her:</b> One <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>mother and</b> one <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>father’s wife. Rabbi Yehuda says: He is liable</b> to bring <b>only</b> one sin-offering, <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>mother.</b>
<b>One who</b> unwittingly <b>engages in intercourse with</b> his <b>father’s wife</b> while his father is married to her is <b>liable</b> to bring two sin-offerings: One <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>father’s wife and</b> one <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with <b>a married woman.</b> He is liable due to the former prohibition <b>both during his father’s lifetime and after his father’s death,</b> and <b>whether</b> the relationship between the woman and his father is one <b>of betrothal or</b> one <b>of marriage.</b>
Likewise, <b>one who</b> unwittingly <b>engages in intercourse with his daughter-in-law</b> during his son’s lifetime is <b>liable</b> to bring two sin-offerings <b>for</b> his intercourse with <b>her:</b> One <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>daughter-in-law, and</b> one <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with <b>a married woman.</b> The former liability applies <b>both during his son’s lifetime</b> and <b>after his son’s death,</b> and <b>whether</b> the relationship between the woman and his son is one <b>of betrothal or</b> one <b>of marriage.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to one who engages in intercourse with his mother, <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If his mother was not suitable for his father,</b> as their marriage was forbidden, <b>he is liable only due to the</b> prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>mother,</b> and not due to the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s father’s wife.
This is clarified: <b>What</b> does it mean that she <b>is not suitable for him? If we say</b> that the mother and father were <b>liable to</b> receive the punishment of <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>], or liable to</b> receive a <b>court</b>-imposed <b>death</b> penalty for their intercourse, in which case their marriage did not take effect and therefore Rabbi Yehuda holds that in this case there is no prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s father’s wife, this poses a difficulty. As accordingly, <b>by inference,</b> in may be understood <b>that the Rabbis hold</b> that there is such a prohibition <b>even if she is not suitable for him. Doesn’t</b> everyone agree that in such a case the father <b>has no</b> capability of <b>betrothal with regard to her?</b> Even if they cohabit, she is not considered his wife.
<b>Rather,</b> it is clear that Rabbi Yehuda is referring to a case where the father and mother are <b>liable for</b> violating <b>a prohibition</b> for their intercourse, but they are not liable to receive <i>karet</i> or capital punishment. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> in this matter <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that <b>betrothal does not take effect with</b> those women with regard to whom one <b>is liable</b> for violating <b>a prohibition</b> if one engages in intercourse with them. The Rabbis disagree with this; in their opinion, betrothal does take effect in such cases, although a prohibition is involved. Therefore, the mother is considered the father’s wife, and the son is liable for engaging in intercourse with his father’s wife as well as for engaging in intercourse with his mother.
<b>Rav Oshaya raises an objection</b> to this explanation, as it is stated in a mishna in tractate <i>Yevamot</i> (20a): If a <i>yevama</i> is forbidden to her <i>yavam</i> by <b>a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva or</b> by <b>a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity,</b> then since in these cases the levirate bond is not fundamentally nullified, <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> in order to become free of the levirate bond, <b>and</b> due to the prohibition <b>she does not enter into levirate marriage.</b>

Daf 53b

The mishna explains: <b>A prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva</b> is referring to <b>secondary</b> forbidden <b>relatives,</b> e.g., one’s son’s daughter-in-law, who are forbidden <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The Sages instituted this prohibition in order to distance people from incest. The Gemara explains: <b>And why do</b> the Sages <b>call it a prohibition</b> resulting from <b>a mitzva? Because it is a mitzva to listen to the words of the Sages.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>A prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity</b> is referring to the marriage of <b>a widow to a High Priest,</b> or to the marriage of <b>a divorcée or</b> of <b>a woman who has performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>], to an ordinary priest.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>And why do</b> the Sages <b>call it a prohibition</b> stemming from <b>sanctity? As it is written</b> with regard to the priests: <b>“They shall be sanctified to their God”</b> (Leviticus 21:6).
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to</b> this mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda switches</b> the terms; he refers to the marriage of a divorcée or of a <i>ḥalutza</i> to a priest as a prohibition resulting from a mitzva, and to the marriage of secondary relatives as a prohibition stemming from sanctity.
The Gemara infers: <b>He switches</b> the terms but does not dispute the <i>halakha</i>; <b>but</b> even Rabbi Yehuda agrees that if a priest marries a <i>ḥalutza</i> and then dies, <b>she requires <i>ḥalitza</i>. And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> this poses a difficulty; <b>after all,</b> those <b>liable for</b> violating <b>prohibitions, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, are considered like those liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>, and those liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i> are not capable of</b> performing <b><i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage,</b> as the mitzva of levirate marriage does not apply to such relationships.
The Gemara resolves the difficulty: Rabbi Yehuda does hold in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, and as for his comment with regard to the definitions of a prohibition resulting from a mitzva and a prohibition stemming from sanctity, he merely <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with the statement of the first <i>tanna</i>; but he himself does not hold accordingly.</b>
§ <b>When Rav Yitzḥak came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One who engages in intercourse with his mother who is also his father’s wife <b>is liable</b> to bring <b>only</b> one sin-offering, <b>due to the</b> fact that she is his <b>mother,</b> whether or not her marriage to his father was legitimate.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> for this? <b>Abaye says:</b> It is <b>because the verse states:</b> “The nakedness of your father and the nakedness of your mother you shall not uncover: <b>She is your mother;</b> you shall not uncover her nakedness” (Leviticus 18:7). Rabbi Yehuda derives from this verse that <b>you shall render him liable due to</b> the fact that she is <b>his mother, but you shall not render him liable</b> to bring another sin-offering <b>due to</b> the fact that she is his <b>father’s wife.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> it should be derived from the verse: <b>“The nakedness of your father’s wife you shall not uncover; it is your father’s nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 18:8), that <b>you shall render him liable due to</b> the fact that she is his <b>father’s wife, but you shall not render him liable due to</b> the fact that she is <b>his mother.</b>
<b>But</b> if so, with regard to one’s <b>mother who is his father’s wife,</b> it is found that the verse <b>stands,</b> i.e., is written, <b>here,</b> with regard to intercourse with one’s mother, <b>and excludes</b> liability due to the fact that she is his father’s wife, and <b>stands there,</b> with regard to intercourse with one’s father’s wife, <b>and excludes</b> liability due to the fact that she is his mother. The result <b>now</b> is that for <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife he is rendered liable,</b> and for <b>his father’s wife who is not his mother he is rendered liable,</b> but for <b>his mother who is his father’s wife he is not rendered liable at all,</b> which seems absurd.
<b>And furthermore, according to the Rabbis too,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda and hold that one who engages in intercourse with his mother who is married to his father is liable to bring two sin-offerings, <b>isn’t</b> the verse: <b>“She is your mother,” written;</b> i.e., how do they explain this verse? <b>Rather, that</b> phrase is <b>necessary for</b> the <i>halakha</i> derived from it by <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi,</b> as the Gemara will soon explain (54a). Therefore, <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda as well, that</b> phrase is <b>necessary for</b> the <i>halakha</i> derived by <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion in the mishna cannot be derived from it.
<b>Rather, Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, says</b> that there is a different source for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion: <b>The verse states:</b> “You shall not uncover <b>her nakedness [<i>ervatah</i>],”</b> in the singular form, from which it is derived that <b>you shall render him liable for one forbidden sexual relationship [<i>erva</i>], but you shall not render him liable for two</b> types of <b>forbidden sexual relationships.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then from the verse: <b>“You shall not uncover the nakedness of your daughter-in-law; she is your son’s wife, you shall not uncover her nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 18:15), should it <b>also</b> be derived that <b>you shall render him liable for one forbidden sexual relationship, but you shall not render him liable for two</b> types of <b>forbidden sexual relationships?</b>
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>One who engages in intercourse with his daughter-in-law</b> is <b>liable</b> to bring two sin-offerings <b>for</b> his intercourse with <b>her:</b> One <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with one’s <b>daughter-in-law, and</b> one <b>due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with <b>a married woman;</b> the former liability applies <b>both during his son’s lifetime and after his son’s death. And Rabbi Yehuda does not dispute</b> this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be explained that <b>since</b> the daughter-in-law has <b>one body, although</b> engaging in intercourse with her involves <b>two prohibitions,</b> the term <b>“her nakedness [<i>ervatah</i>],”</b> in the singular, <b>is written. Here too,</b> with regard to one’s father’s wife, <b>since</b> she has <b>one body, although</b> there <b>are two prohibitions,</b> the term <b>“her nakedness [<i>ervatah</i>]” is written.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava says</b> that there is an alternative source for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion: <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that concerning the meaning of the phrase <b>“the nakedness of your father,” this is</b> referring to <b>your father’s wife. And he derives</b> this interpretation <b>by means of a verbal analogy</b> from the verse: “And the man who lies with his father’s wife, he has uncovered his father’s nakedness” (Leviticus 20:11).
<b>And</b> the Torah <b>indicates</b> that she is forbidden <b>whether</b> she is <b>his father’s wife who is his mother</b> or <b>whether</b> she is <b>his father’s wife who is not his mother. From where</b> is it derived that one who engages in intercourse with <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife</b> is liable? <b>The verse states</b> subsequently: <b>“The nakedness of your mother you shall not uncover.”</b> And from the ensuing phrase: <b>“She is your mother,”</b> it is derived that in a case where his mother is also his father’s wife, <b>you shall render him liable due to</b> the fact that she is <b>his mother, but you shall not render him liable due to</b> the fact that she is <b>his father’s wife.</b>

Daf 54a

§ <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava:</b> With regard to the verse: “And the man who lies with his father’s wife, he has uncovered his father’s nakedness; both of them shall be put to death, their blood shall be upon them” (Leviticus 20:11), the term: <b>“The man,” excludes a minor.</b>
The phrase <b>“who lies with his father’s wife” indicates</b> that he is liable to receive capital punishment <b>whether</b> she is <b>his father’s wife who is his mother or whether</b> she is <b>his father’s wife who is not his mother. From where</b> is it derived that he is liable in a case where she is <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife? The verse states: “He has uncovered his father’s nakedness.”</b> Although this phrase does not relate directly to the case of one’s mother who is not his father’s wife, the <i>halakha</i> in this case is derived from this phrase as it is <b>free,</b> i.e., the phrase is superfluous in this context, and is evidently included in the verse in order <b>to compare</b> between the two cases <b>and learn a verbal analogy from it,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> will elaborate below.
From the phrase “both of them <b>shall be put to death”</b> it is derived that they are executed <b>by stoning.</b> The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Do you say</b> that that they are executed <b>by stoning, or is it rather by one of all the</b> other types of the <b>death</b> penalty <b>that are stated in the Torah?</b> The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>It is stated here: “Their blood shall be upon them,” and it is stated with regard to a necromancer and a sorcerer: “Their blood shall be upon them”</b> (Leviticus 20:27). <b>Just as there</b> the verse states that a necromancer and a sorcerer are executed <b>by stoning, so too here,</b> with regard to one who engages in intercourse with his father’s wife, the transgressors are executed <b>by stoning.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>We have learned</b> the <b>punishment</b> for one who engages in intercourse with his father’s wife. <b>From where</b> is the <b>prohibition</b> against doing this act derived? The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>The verse states: “The nakedness of your father</b> and the nakedness of your mother <b>you shall not uncover”</b> (Leviticus 18:7); the phrase <b>“the nakedness of your father” is</b> referring to <b>your father’s wife.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Do you say</b> that the reference is to <b>your father’s wife, or is it rather</b> referring to <b>the nakedness of your father literally,</b> i.e., to homosexual intercourse with one’s father? The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>It is stated here: “The nakedness of your father…you shall not uncover,” and it is stated there,</b> in the verse that describes the punishment: “And the man who lies with his father’s wife, <b>he has uncovered his father’s nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 20:11). <b>Just as there, the verse is speaking of marriage,</b> i.e., it is not referring to the father himself but to his wife, <b>so too here, the verse is speaking of marriage,</b> i.e., his father’s wife.
<b>And</b> the verse <b>indicates</b> that one’s father’s wife is forbidden to him <b>whether</b> she is <b>his father’s wife who is his mother</b> or <b>whether</b> she is <b>his father’s wife who is not his mother. From where</b> is it derived that she is forbidden to him in a case where she is <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife? The verse states: “The nakedness of your mother you shall not uncover”</b> (Leviticus 18:7).
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only with regard to</b> the <b>prohibition that the verse renders</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife like</b> that of <b>his mother who is his father’s wife.</b> But with regard to the <b>punishment, from where</b> do I derive that they share the same <i>halakha</i>?
The <i>baraita</i> answers, expounding on the verbal analogy it mentioned earlier: <b>It is stated here,</b> in the verse that describes the prohibition: <b>“The nakedness of your father…you shall not uncover”</b> (Leviticus 18:7), <b>and it is stated there,</b> in the verse that describes the punishment: <b>“He has uncovered his father’s nakedness”</b> (Leviticus 20:11). It is derived from this verbal analogy that <b>just as with regard to</b> the <b>prohibition, the verse renders his mother who is not his father’s wife like his mother who is his father’s wife,</b> i.e., both are forbidden, <b>so too, with regard to</b> the <b>punishment, the verse renders his mother who is not his father’s wife like his mother who is his father’s wife.</b>
It is derived from the phrase: <b>“She is your mother”</b> (Leviticus 18:7), that <b>you render him liable due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with <b>his mother, but you do not render him liable due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with his <b>father’s wife.</b> The <i>baraita</i> ends here. Since the <i>halakhot</i> in the collection of <i>baraitot</i> where this <i>baraita</i> appears, <i>Torat Kohanim</i>, are in accordance with the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda, the <i>baraita</i> supports the opinion of Rava, who explains the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda in this manner.
The Gemara discusses the <i>baraita</i>, asking: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda, interpret the phrase <b>“the nakedness of your father”?</b> The Gemara answers: They hold that this phrase is meant <b>literally,</b> i.e., that it is referring to homosexual intercourse. They do not accept the verbal analogy from which Rabbi Yehuda derives that the reference is to intercourse with one’s father’s wife.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t <b>this</b> prohibition against homosexual intercourse with one’s father <b>derived from</b> the verse: <b>“And</b> you shall not lie <b>with a male</b> as with a woman; it is an abomination” (Leviticus 18:22)? The Gemara answers: The prohibition is stated specifically with regard to one’s father in order <b>to render him liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings for unwittingly engaging in intercourse with his father.
<b>And</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Yehuda, as Rav Yehuda says: A gentile who engages in intercourse with his father</b> is <b>liable</b> for committing <b>two</b> transgressions. Likewise, <b>one who engages in intercourse with his father’s brother</b> is <b>liable</b> for committing <b>two</b> transgressions.
<b>Rava says:</b> It <b>stands to reason</b> that <b>the statement of Rav Yehuda is with regard to a Jew</b> who does this <b>unwittingly. And</b> the statement that he is liable for committing two transgressions <b>concerns</b> his liability to bring <b>an offering,</b> i.e., he is liable to bring two sin-offerings. <b>And</b> even though the fact remains <b>that he said gentile, it is a euphemism,</b> as he did not want to attribute such a sin to a Jew. <b>As if it enters your mind</b> that the reference is <b>literally</b> to <b>a gentile,</b> the statement that he is liable for committing two transgressions is meaningless; <b>what is his punishment</b> for such a transgression? It is <b>death.</b> Could <b>you kill him twice?</b> Rather, it must be referring to a Jew who acted unwittingly.
<b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who engages in intercourse with his father</b> is <b>liable</b> for committing <b>two</b> transgressions. <b>One who engages in intercourse with his father’s brother</b> is <b>liable</b> for committing <b>two</b> transgressions, as it is stated: “You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s brother” (Leviticus 18:14).
<b>Some say that</b> this is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as in his opinion there is no special prohibition against homosexual intercourse with one’s father. He interprets the verse: “The nakedness of your father…you shall not uncover” as referring to one’s father’s wife. Accordingly, one who engages in homosexual intercourse with his father or with his father’s brother is liable only due to the general prohibition against homosexual intercourse.
<b>And some say: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> that <b>he derives</b> that there is a specific prohibition against homosexual intercourse with one’s father <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the prohibition concerning one’s <b>father’s brother. And</b> the inference is as follows: <b>If</b> for intercourse with one’s <b>father’s brother, who is</b> merely <b>his father’s relative,</b> one is <b>liable</b> for committing <b>two</b> transgressions, for intercourse with <b>his father,</b> is it <b>not</b> clear <b>all the more so</b> that he should be liable for committing two transgressions?
<b>And</b> the Sages who provide these two interpretations of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion <b>disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Abaye and Rava.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> he of the second interpretation, <b>holds</b> that <b>one administers punishment</b> based <b>on</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference.</b> Even with regard to a prohibition that is derived <i>a fortiori</i>, one who transgresses it is liable. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> he of the first interpretation, <b>holds</b> that <b>one does not administer punishment</b> based <b>on</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>from where do they</b> derive <b>the prohibition of</b> intercourse with one’s <b>father’s wife?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They derive it from</b> the verse: <b>“The nakedness of your father’s wife you shall not uncover;</b> it is your father’s nakedness” (Leviticus 18:8).
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> derive from this verse, since he derives the prohibition from the verse: “The nakedness of your father…you shall not uncover”? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for the prohibition of</b> one’s <b>father’s wife after</b> his father’s <b>death;</b> even though his father is dead, his father’s wife remains forbidden to him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive that <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from the last clause of the verse: “It is your father’s nakedness.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> derive from that clause? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> clause <b>is necessary to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> that if one engages in intercourse with his father’s wife, <b>you render him liable due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with his <b>father’s wife, but you do not render him liable due to</b> the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with <b>a married woman.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>One who engages in intercourse with</b> his <b>father’s wife</b> is <b>liable</b> to bring two offerings, one <b>due to</b> the fact that she is his <b>father’s wife and</b> one <b>due to</b> the fact that she is <b>a married woman,</b> and he is liable due to the former prohibition <b>both during his father’s lifetime</b> and <b>after his father’s death?</b> The Gemara notes: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda does not dispute</b> this. So how can it be suggested that in Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, one who engages in intercourse with his father’s wife is not liable for engaging in intercourse with a married woman?
<b>Abaye says: He disputes</b> this ruling <b>in a <i>baraita</i>.</b> Although it is not mentioned in the mishna that Rabbi Yehuda disputes this ruling, it mentioned in a different source.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis, from where do they</b> derive <b>the punishment for</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>his father’s wife after</b> his father’s <b>death? Granted,</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yehuda, it is derived by means of a verbal analogy. But from where do the Rabbis,</b> who do not accept the verbal analogy, derive it?
The Gemara answers: The Rabbis can <b>say to you</b> that it is derived as follows: With regard to <b>that</b> phrase, <b>“he has uncovered his father’s nakedness,” from which Rabbi Yehuda derives a verbal analogy, they derive from it the punishment for</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>his father’s wife after</b> his father’s <b>death.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis, from where do they</b> derive <b>the punishment for</b> one who engages in intercourse with <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife? Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, says: The verse states: “She is your mother”</b> (Leviticus 18:7). <b>The verse renders</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>his mother who is not his father’s wife like</b> that of <b>his mother who is his father’s wife.</b>
The mishna teaches with regard to <b>one who engages in intercourse with his daughter-in-law</b> that he is liable both due to the fact that she is his daughter-in-law and due to the fact that she is a married woman. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him also be liable due to</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>his son’s wife,</b> as it is stated in the verse: “You shall not uncover the nakedness of your daughter-in-law; she is your son’s wife, you shall not uncover her nakedness” (Leviticus 18:15). <b>Abaye says: The verse begins with his daughter-in-law and ends with his son’s wife, to tell you</b> that these are not two prohibitions; rather, <b>his daughter-in-law [<i>kallato</i>] is his son’s wife.</b> They are one and the same.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A man <b>who engages in intercourse with a male or with an animal, and a woman who engages in intercourse with an animal,</b> are executed <b>by stoning.</b> The animal is likewise stoned to death. The mishna asks: <b>If</b> the <b>person sinned</b> by doing this, <b>how did the animal sin? Rather, because a calamity was caused to a person by it, therefore the verse states</b> that <b>it should be stoned,</b> so that it does not cause another to sin. <b>Alternatively,</b> it is <b>so that</b> this <b>animal will not pass through the marketplace, and</b> those who see it <b>will say: This is</b> the animal <b>because of which so-and-so was stoned,</b> and its existence would shame his memory.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>From where do we</b> derive the prohibition and punishment for homosexual intercourse with <b>a male?</b> It is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And if a man lies with a male as with a woman, both of them have committed an abomination; they shall be put to death, their blood shall be upon them” (Leviticus 20:13): The word <b>“man” excludes a minor boy.</b> The phrase <b>“lies with a male”</b> is referring to any male, <b>whether</b> he is <b>an adult man</b> or <b>whether</b> he is <b>a minor boy.</b> The phrase <b>“as with a woman [<i>mishkevei isha</i>],”</b> referring to lying with a woman, appears in the plural. <b>The verse teaches you that</b> there are <b>two</b> manners of <b>lying with a woman</b> for which one who engages in intercourse with a woman forbidden to him is punished, vaginal and anal intercourse.
<b>Rabbi Yishmael says: This</b> phrase is written to <b>come to teach</b> about the punishment for homosexual intercourse, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> that one is liable for anal intercourse with a woman who is forbidden to him is <b>found to be derived</b> from it.
The phrase <b>“they shall be put to death”</b> is referring to execution <b>by stoning. Do you say</b> that they are executed <b>by stoning, or is it rather by one of all the</b> other types of <b>death</b> penalty <b>that are stated in the Torah? It is stated here: “Their blood shall be upon them,” and it is stated with regard to a necromancer and a sorcerer: “Their blood shall be upon them”</b> (Leviticus 20:27). <b>Just as there</b> the verse states that a necromancer and a sorcerer are executed <b>by stoning, so too here,</b> they are executed <b>by stoning.</b>

Daf 54b

<b>We have learned</b> the <b>punishment</b> for homosexual intercourse, but <b>from where</b> is the <b>prohibition</b> derived? <b>The verse states: “And you shall not lie with a male as with a woman; it is an abomination”</b> (Leviticus 18:22).
