If a gentile <b>engages in intercourse with those Jews with whom relations are forbidden, he is judged according to the <i>halakhot</i> of the Jews.</b> If he <b>engages in intercourse with those descendants of Noah with whom relations are forbidden, he is judged according to the <i>halakhot</i> of the descendants of Noah. And we have only</b> the case of <b>a betrothed young woman</b> as a case where a gentile is judged according to the <i>halakhot</i> of the Jews, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>also count</b> the case of a woman who <b>had entered the wedding canopy but had not</b> yet <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her husband. The Gemara explains: <b>This <i>tanna</i> is the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Menashe, who says</b> that <b>all death</b> penalties <b>stated with regard to the descendants of Noah are</b> referring to <b>nothing other than strangulation,</b> and since the punishment in Jewish <i>halakha</i> for engaging in intercourse with a married woman is also strangulation, both <b>this</b> punishment <b>and that</b> punishment are <b>strangulation;</b> there is no difference between the <i>halakha</i> for Jews and the <i>halakha</i> for gentiles in such a case.
With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Meir stated in the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Meir hold</b> that <b>any forbidden sexual relations for which a Jewish court administers capital punishment is prohibited to a descendant of Noah? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a convert</b>

Daf 58a

<b>who was not conceived in sanctity,</b> as his parents were still gentiles, <b>but his birth was in sanctity,</b> as his mother converted before his birth, <b>he has maternal kinship,</b> i.e., his relationship to his mother’s relatives is recognized, <b>but he does not have paternal kinship.</b>
<b>How so?</b> If <b>he married his maternal half sister,</b> who was born before him and converted, <b>he must divorce</b> her. Although by Torah law they are considered unrelated, as a convert is considered to be reborn and all his previous family relationships are disregarded according to <i>halakha</i>, the Sages prohibited their marriage, lest he think that as a Jew it is permitted for him to engage in behaviors that were previously forbidden to him. If she is his <b>paternal</b> half sister, <b>he may maintain</b> her as his wife, as it is permitted for a gentile to marry his paternal half sister. If he married his <b>father’s maternal half sister, he must divorce her.</b> If he married his father’s <b>paternal</b> half sister, <b>he may maintain</b> her as his wife.
If she is his <b>mother’s maternal half sister, he must divorce</b> her. If she is his <b>mother’s paternal half sister, Rabbi Meir says he must divorce</b> her, <b>and the Rabbis say he may maintain</b> her as his wife. <b>As Rabbi Meir would say:</b> With regard to <b>any forbidden relative who is</b> forbidden <b>due to maternal kinship,</b> whether the woman is his paternal relative, e.g., his father’s maternal half sister, or his maternal relative, <b>he must divorce</b> her; whereas if she is forbidden <b>due to paternal kinship, he may maintain</b> her as his wife.
<b>And</b> according to all opinions, he is <b>permitted to</b> marry <b>his brother’s wife and his father’s brother’s wife, and all other</b> relatives <b>with whom relations are forbidden</b> in the case of born Jew <b>are</b> also <b>permitted to him.</b> The expression: And all other relatives with whom relations are forbidden, is added <b>to include his father’s wife,</b> who is permitted to him if she was widowed or divorced from his father.
With regard to a gentile who <b>married a woman and her daughter</b> and they all converted, <b>he may marry one but must divorce</b> the other <b>one; and he should not marry</b> the second of them <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> If <b>his wife,</b> the daughter, <b>died,</b> he is <b>permitted to</b> maintain <b>his mother-in-law</b> as his wife. <b>And some say</b> that he is <b>prohibited from</b> maintaining <b>his mother-in-law.</b> In any event, Rabbi Meir clearly holds that several forbidden relationships for which a Jew is not liable to receive capital punishment, but only <i>karet</i>, are forbidden to descendants of Noah as well, namely, intercourse with one’s sister or one’s parent’s sister.
<b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> This is <b>not difficult; this</b> <i>baraita</i> cites the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer, and that</b> previously mentioned <i>baraita</i> cites the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“Therefore a man shall leave his father and his mother,</b> and shall cleave to his wife, and they shall be one flesh” (Genesis 2:24), that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: “His father”</b> is referring to <b>his father’s sister,</b> i.e., one must abandon the possibility of marrying his father’s sister and marry someone else. <b>“His mother”</b> is referring to <b>his mother’s sister. Rabbi Akiva says: “His father”</b> is referring to <b>his father’s wife; “his mother”</b> is referring to <b>his mother, literally.</b>
<b>“And shall cleave</b> to his wife,” <b>but not to a male;</b> such a relationship is not defined as cleaving. <b>“To his wife,” but not to the wife of another</b> man. <b>“And they shall be one flesh”</b> indicates that he should marry one of <b>those</b> with <b>whom</b> he can <b>become one flesh,</b> i.e., they can bear children together. This <b>excludes domesticated and undomesticated animals,</b> with which one is prohibited from engaging in bestiality, <b>as they do not become one flesh.</b> All these are forbidden to the descendants of Noah.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in this <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: “His father”</b> is referring to <b>his father’s sister.</b> The Gemara asks: Why not <b>say</b> that it is referring to <b>his father, literally,</b> prohibiting homosexual intercourse with one’s father? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> prohibition <b>is</b> derived from another phrase in the verse: <b>“And shall cleave</b> to his wife,” <b>but not to a male;</b> this includes his father.
The Gemara asks: Why not <b>say</b> that “his father” is referring to <b>his father’s wife?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> prohibition <b>is</b> derived from the term <b>“to his wife,” but not to the wife of another</b> man. The Gemara asks: Why not <b>say</b> that it is referring to his father’s wife <b>after</b> his father’s <b>death,</b> when she is no longer a married woman? The Gemara answers: The term “his father” is interpreted in a way that is <b>similar to</b> the interpretation of the term <b>“his mother.” Just as his mother is not</b> forbidden due to her <b>marriage</b> to his father, but rather due to her relationship to him, <b>so too,</b> the term <b>“his father”</b> is <b>not</b> referring to a relative who is forbidden to him due to her <b>marriage.</b>
Rabbi Eliezer says that <b>“his mother”</b> is referring to <b>his mother’s sister.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that it is referring to <b>his mother, literally?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> prohibition <b>is</b> derived from the term <b>“to his wife,” but not to the wife of another</b> man; and his mother is his father’s wife. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that it is referring to his mother <b>after</b> his father’s <b>death,</b> when she is no longer married? The Gemara answers: The term “his mother” is interpreted in a way that is <b>similar to</b> the interpretation of the term <b>“his father.” Just as</b> the term <b>“his father” is not</b> interpreted <b>literally, so too,</b> the term <b>“his mother” is not</b> interpreted <b>literally.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: “His father”</b> is referring to <b>his father’s wife.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> it is referring to <b>his father, literally?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> prohibition <b>is</b> derived from the term <b>“and shall cleave</b> to his wife,” <b>but not to a male.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> the prohibition of <b>his father’s wife is also</b> derived from another term: <b>“To his wife,” but not to the wife of another</b> man. The Gemara explains: The term “to his wife” is referring to his father’s wife <b>after</b> his father’s <b>death,</b> when she is no longer married.
Rabbi Akiva says: <b>“His mother”</b> is referring to <b>his mother, literally.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>That</b> prohibition <b>is</b> derived from the term <b>“to his wife,” but not to the wife of another</b> man. The Gemara explains: According to Rabbi Akiva, the term “his mother” is referring to <b>his mother whom</b> his father <b>raped,</b> i.e., she was never his father’s wife.
<b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Akiva <b>disagree? Rabbi Eliezer holds</b>

Daf 58b

that the term <b>“his father”</b> should be interpreted in a way that is <b>similar to</b> the term <b>“his mother,” and “his mother”</b> should be interpreted in a way that is <b>similar to “his father.” You find</b> such an interpretation <b>only with regard to sisterhood,</b> i.e., “his father” is referring to his father’s sister, and “his mother” is referring to his mother’s sister.
<b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> holds that <b>it is preferable to interpret</b> the term “his father” as referring <b>to his father’s wife, who is referred to as his father’s nakedness</b> in the verse: “You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s wife; it is your father’s nakedness” (Leviticus 18:8), <b>to the exclusion of his father’s sister, who is referred to as his father’s kin</b> in the verse: “You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father’s sister; she is your father’s kin” (Leviticus 18:12), and who <b>is not referred to as his father’s nakedness.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof for the opinion of Rabbi Akiva from the verse: <b>“And Amram took Jochebed his aunt</b> as a wife” (Exodus 6:20). <b>What,</b> was she <b>not his maternal aunt?</b> Presumably, Jochebed was the sister of Kohath, Amram’s father, from both of Kohath’s parents, and not from his father alone. Evidently, a descendant of Noah may marry his father’s sister.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No,</b> she was <b>his paternal aunt,</b> Kohath’s half sister. Since she was not Kohath’s sister from his mother’s side, she was not forbidden to Amram.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof for the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer from what Abraham said to Abimelech with regard to Sarah: <b>“And moreover, she is my sister, the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother;</b> and so she became my wife” (Genesis 20:12). <b>By inference, the daughter of the mother</b> of a descendant of Noah <b>is forbidden</b> to him.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>But</b> how can <b>you understand</b> that Sarah <b>was</b> Abraham’s <b>sister? She was his brother’s daughter.</b> By tradition, it is known that Sarah was Haran’s daughter Iscah. <b>And since that was so,</b> there <b>is no difference</b> whether they were <b>paternal</b> relatives, <b>and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> whether they were <b>maternal</b> relatives; in any event she was <b>permitted</b> to him, even according to the <i>halakha</i> of Jews. <b>Rather, this</b> is what Abraham <b>was saying to</b> Abimelech <b>there: She is related to me like a sister,</b> as the daughter of my brother is like a sister, and our relationship is <b>from</b> the side of my <b>father but not from</b> the side of my <b>mother.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>For what</b> reason <b>did Adam not marry his daughter? So that Cain would marry his sister</b> and they would procreate immediately, <b>as it is stated: “For I have said: The world shall be built on kindness [<i>ḥesed</i>]”</b> (Psalms 89:3). This verse alludes to the fact that at the beginning of the world’s existence it was permitted for men to marry their sisters, which was later forbidden in the verse: “And if a man shall take his sister…it is a shameful thing [<i>ḥesed</i>]” (Leviticus 20:17). The Gemara infers: If it had <b>not</b> been <b>so,</b> if God had not specially permitted Cain to marry his sister, she would have been <b>forbidden</b> to him. This is difficult according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, who deems it permitted for a gentile to marry his sister.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Once it was permitted</b> for Cain to marry his sister, <b>it was permitted</b> for all descendants of Noah to do so, and it was forbidden only to Jews.
<b>Rav Huna says: A gentile is permitted to</b> marry <b>his daughter. And if you say, for what</b> reason <b>did Adam not marry his daughter?</b> It was <b>so that Cain would marry his sister, because</b> it is stated: <b>“The world shall be built on kindness.”</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rav Huna did not say this; rather, <b>Rav Huna says: A gentile is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>his daughter. Know</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>, <b>as Adam did not marry his daughter.</b> The Gemara rejects this statement: <b>But</b> that <b>is not so, as there, this is the reason</b> Adam did not marry his daughter: <b>So that Cain would marry his sister, because</b> it is stated: <b>“The world shall be built on kindness.”</b>
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> A Canaanite <b>slave</b> is <b>permitted to</b> marry <b>his mother, and</b> he is <b>permitted to</b> marry <b>his daughter.</b> This is because he has <b>left the category of a gentile</b> by immersing in a ritual bath for the purpose of becoming a slave to a Jew, and consequently all his previous family relationships are disregarded according to <i>halakha</i>; <b>but he has not entered the category of a Jew,</b> as evidenced by the fact that he is not obligated to observe all of the mitzvot of male Jews. Therefore, the decree of the Sages prohibiting the maternal relatives of converts does not apply to him.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> In the case of a <b>descendant of Noah who designated a maidservant</b> as a mate <b>for his slave, and</b> then he himself <b>engaged in intercourse with her, he is executed</b> for adultery <b>on her account.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From when</b> is she considered the slave’s mate? <b>Rav Naḥman says: From</b> the time <b>that she is called so-and-so’s girl.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From when is she released</b> from her relationship with the slave? <b>Rav Huna says: From</b> the time <b>that she exposes her head in the marketplace.</b> Since married women would cover their hair, even among the gentiles, by exposing her hair she proves that she no longer wishes to remain with him.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: A descendant of Noah who engages in intercourse with his wife in an atypical manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse, <b>is liable</b> for engaging in forbidden sexual intercourse, <b>as it is stated: “And shall cleave</b> to his wife” (Genesis 2:24), an expression that indicates natural intercourse, <b>but not</b> intercourse <b>in an atypical manner.</b>
<b>Rava says: Is there any</b> action <b>for which a Jew is not deemed liable, but a gentile is deemed liable</b> for performing it? A Jew is not liable for engaging in anal intercourse with his wife.
<b>Rather, Rava says</b> that the verse is to be understood as follows: A <b>descendant of Noah who engages in intercourse with the wife of another</b> man <b>in an atypical manner is exempt. What is the reason?</b> The verse states: “And shall cleave <b>to his wife,” but not to the wife of another.</b> With regard to this prohibition, the verse states: <b>“And shall cleave,”</b> indicating vaginal intercourse, <b>and not</b> intercourse <b>in an atypical manner.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: A gentile who struck a Jew is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty, <b>as it is stated</b> when Moses saw an Egyptian striking a Hebrew: <b>“And he turned this way and that way, and when he saw that there was no man, he struck the Egyptian</b> and hid him in the sand” (Exodus 2:12).
<b>And Rabbi Ḥanina says: One who slaps the cheek of a Jew</b> is considered <b>as though he slapped the cheek of the Divine Presence; as it is stated: “It is a snare [<i>mokesh</i>] for a man to rashly say [<i>yala</i>]: Holy”</b> (Proverbs 20:25). The verse is interpreted homiletically to mean: One who strikes [<i>nokesh</i>] a Jew is considered as though he hurt the cheek [<i>lo’a</i>] of the Holy One.
The Gemara states <b>a mnemonic</b> for the upcoming statements of Reish Lakish: <b>Raises, his slave, Shabbat. Reish Lakish says: One who raises his hand to</b> strike <b>another, even if he</b> ultimately <b>does not strike him, is called wicked, as it is stated:</b> “And two men of the Hebrews were struggling with each other, <b>and he said to the wicked one: Why should you strike your friend?”</b> (Exodus 2:13). The phrase: <b>Why did you strike, is not stated,</b> but <b>rather: “Why should you strike,”</b> indicating that one who raised his hand to strike another, <b>even if he</b> ultimately <b>did not strike him, is called wicked.</b>
<b>Ze’eiri says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> One who raises his hand to strike another <b>is called a sinner; as it is stated:</b> “And the priest’s lad would come…and would say to him, but you shall give now, <b>and if not, I will take by force”</b> (I Samuel 2:15–16), <b>and it is written</b> with regard to this behavior: <b>“And the sin of the youths was very great”</b> (I Samuel 2:17).
<b>Rav Huna says: His hand should be cut off, as it is stated: “And the high arm shall be broken”</b> (Job 38:15). If one habitually lifts his arm to strike others, it is better that it be broken. The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Huna cut off the hand</b> of a person who would habitually hit others.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> Such a violent person <b>has no remedy but burial, as it is stated: “And as a mighty man [<i>ve’ish zero’a</i>], who has the earth”</b> (Job 22:8). The expression <i>ish zero’a</i> literally means: A man of the arm, and the verse is interpreted homiletically to mean that one who habitually strikes others deserves to be buried.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar states</b> a different interpretation of that verse: <b>The land is given only to mighty men</b> who can protect themselves from all enemies; <b>as it is stated: “And as a mighty man, who has the earth.”</b>
<b>And</b> in connection with that statement, the Gemara notes that <b>Reish Lakish says: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “One who works [<i>oved</i>] his land shall have plenty of bread”</b> (Proverbs 12:11)? <b>If a person makes himself like a slave [<i>ke’eved</i>] to the land,</b> devoting his efforts to it, <b>he will have plenty of bread, but if not, he will not have plenty of bread.</b>
<b>And Reish Lakish says: A gentile who observed Shabbat is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty, <b>as it is stated: “And day and night shall not cease”</b> (Genesis 8:23), which literally means: And day and night they shall not rest. This is interpreted homiletically to mean that the descendants of Noah may not take a day of rest. <b>And the Master said</b> (57a) that <b>their prohibition is their death</b> penalty, i.e., the punishment for any prohibition with regard to descendants of Noah is execution. <b>Ravina says:</b> If a descendant of Noah observes a day of rest on any day of the week, <b>even</b> one not set aside for religious worship, e.g., <b>on a Monday,</b> he is liable.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>count</b> this prohibition <b>among</b> the <b>seven</b> Noahide <b>mitzvot.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>When</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>counts</b> the seven mitzvot, he counts only those that require one to <b>sit and refrain from action,</b> i.e., those that include a prohibition against performing a certain action. <b>He does not count</b> mitzvot that require one to <b>arise and take action.</b>

Daf 59a

The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the mitzva of establishing courts of <b>judgment is</b> a mitzva to <b>stand up and take action, and</b> nevertheless <b>he counts it</b> among the seven mitzvot. The Gemara answers: This mitzva contains a requirement to <b>stand up and take action,</b> i.e., the obligation to establish courts and carry out justice, <b>and</b> it also contains a requirement to <b>sit and refrain from action,</b> i.e., the prohibition against doing injustice.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A gentile who engages in Torah</b> study is <b>liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty; <b>as it is stated: “Moses commanded us a law [<i>torah</i>], an inheritance</b> of the congregation of Jacob” (Deuteronomy 33:4), indicating that <b>it is an inheritance for us, and not for them.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>count</b> this prohibition <b>among</b> the <b>seven</b> Noahide <b>mitzvot.</b> The Gemara explains: According to <b>the one who says</b> that the verse is referring to the Torah as <b>an inheritance,</b> this prohibition is included in the prohibition of robbery, as a gentile who studies Torah <b>robs</b> the Jewish people of <b>it.</b> According to <b>the one who says</b> that the verse is referring to the Torah as <b>betrothed,</b> as the spelling of the Hebrew word for betrothed [<i>me’orasa</i>], is similar to that of the word for inheritance [<i>morasha</i>], <b>the punishment of</b> a gentile who studies Torah <b>is like</b> that of one who engages in intercourse with <b>a betrothed young woman, which is</b> execution <b>by stoning.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir would say: From where</b> is it derived <b>that even a gentile who engages in Torah</b> study <b>is</b> considered <b>like a High Priest?</b> It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated:</b> “You shall therefore keep My statutes and My ordinances, <b>which if a man does he shall live by them”</b> (Leviticus 18:5). The phrase: Which if <b>priests, Levites, and Israelites</b> do they shall live by them, <b>is not stated,</b> but <b>rather: “A man,”</b> which indicates mankind in general. <b>You have therefore learned that even a gentile who engages in Torah</b> study <b>is</b> considered <b>like a High Priest.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, the reference is to a gentile who engages <b>in</b> the study of <b>their seven mitzvot.</b> It is a mitzva for a gentile to study the <i>halakhot</i> that pertain to the seven Noahide mitzvot, and when he does so he is highly regarded.
§ The <i>baraita</i> that lists the Noahide mitzvot (56a) teaches that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says:</b> The descendants of Noah are <b>also</b> commanded concerning the prohibition against consuming <b>the blood from a living</b> animal. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the verse: <b>“Only flesh with its life, which is its blood, you shall not eat”</b> (Genesis 9:4), <b>this is</b> the prohibition against eating <b>a limb from a living</b> animal. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says: The blood from a living</b> animal is <b>also</b> prohibited in this verse.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning</b> behind the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel?</b> The Gemara answers: He <b>reads into</b> the verse: <b>Flesh with its life you shall not eat; blood with its life you shall not eat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> explain the mention of blood in this verse? After all, in their opinion, blood from a living animal is not forbidden. The Gemara answers: <b>That comes to permit</b> eating limbs from living <b>creeping animals.</b> The verse indicates that the prohibition does not apply to creeping animals, whose blood is not considered separate from their flesh (see 59b).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Similarly, you</b> can <b>say</b> that according to the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina, blood from a living animal is also forbidden to the Jewish people in particular; as it is stated: <b>“Only be steadfast in not eating blood, as the blood is the life,</b> and you shall not eat the life with the flesh” (Deuteronomy 12:23). With regard to the statements: <b>“Only be steadfast in not eating blood,” this is a limb from a living</b> animal; <b>“as the blood is the life,” this is blood from a living</b> animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that there is no specific prohibition with regard to blood from a living animal, interpret this verse? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>comes to</b> teach the prohibition against consuming <b>blood</b> spilled in the process <b>of bloodletting,</b> as this is blood <b>through which the soul departs</b> (see <i>Karetot</i> 20b).
The Gemara asks: According to Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel, <b>why do I</b> need the Torah to write this <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to descendants of Noah, and why do I</b> need the Torah to <b>repeat</b> it <b>at Sinai</b> with regard to Jews? Aren’t Jews also descendants of Noah?
The Gemara answers that it is to be understood <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina; as Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: Any mitzva that was</b> first <b>stated with regard to the descendants of Noah and was repeated at Sinai was stated for this</b> group <b>and for that</b> group, i.e., it applies to both gentiles and Jews.
But a mitzva that was stated <b>with regard to the descendants of Noah and was not repeated at Sinai</b> among the mitzvot given to the Jewish people <b>was stated for the Jewish people and not for the descendants of Noah. And we have only</b> the prohibition against eating <b>the sciatic nerve</b> to which this classification applies, <b>and</b> this is <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that the verse: “Therefore the children of Israel do not eat the sciatic nerve, which is on the hollow of the thigh, until this day” (Genesis 32:32), is referring to the sons of Jacob, who were commanded to observe this prohibition even though they had the status of descendants of Noah.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Any mitzva that was stated with regard to the descendants of Noah and was repeated at Sinai was stated for this</b> group <b>and for that</b> group. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>On the contrary, from</b> the fact <b>that it was repeated at Sinai,</b> clearly it can be derived that <b>it was stated for the Jewish people and not for the descendants of Noah,</b> as if it pertains to the descendants of Noah as well, why repeat it at Sinai? Aren’t the Jewish people are also descendants of Noah?
The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the prohibition of <b>idol worship was repeated at Sinai, and we find that</b> God <b>punished gentiles for it, conclude from it</b> that any mitzva that was repeated at Sinai <b>was stated for this</b> group <b>and for that</b> group, and not only for the Jewish people.
It is further stated in the <i>baraita</i> that a mitzva that was stated <b>with regard to the descendants of Noah and was not repeated at Sinai was stated for the Jewish people and not for the descendants of Noah.</b> The Gemara raises an objection: <b>On the contrary, from</b> the fact <b>that it was not repeated at Sinai,</b> clearly it can be derived that <b>it was stated for the descendants of Noah and not for the Jewish people.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is nothing that is permitted to a Jew and forbidden to a gentile.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there <b>not? But isn’t there</b> the permission for a Jew to take a married <b>beautiful woman,</b> who was taken as a prisoner of war, to be his wife? For a gentile to do so is forbidden. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the reason gentiles are prohibited from doing so is <b>because they are not authorized to conquer.</b> It is not permitted for gentiles to wage wars of conquest, and the <i>halakha</i> of marrying a beautiful woman is stated only with regard to a war of conquest. Therefore the fact that a beautiful woman who is a prisoner of war is permitted only to a Jew and not to a gentile does not indicate that gentiles have a higher degree of sanctity.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> stealing <b>less than the value of one <i>peruta</i></b> prohibited to a gentile and permitted to a Jew? The Gemara answers: <b>There it is because</b> gentiles <b>are not apt</b> to grant <b>forgiveness</b> of debts, even of less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>. Therefore, for a gentile to take even such a minuscule amount is considered robbery. Jews normally forgive such small amounts.
It is stated in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>any mitzva that was stated with regard to the descendants of Noah and was repeated at Sinai was stated</b> both <b>for this</b> group <b>and for that</b> group.

Daf 59b

The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the mitzva of <b>circumcision, which was stated with regard to descendants of Noah,</b> i.e., Abraham and his descendants, who had the status of descendants of Noah at that time? <b>As it is written</b> that God said to Abraham with regard to the mitzva of circumcision: <b>“And as for you, you shall keep My covenant,</b> you and your offspring after you, throughout their generations” (Genesis 17:9). <b>And it was repeated at Sinai</b> for the Jewish people: <b>“And on the eighth day</b> the flesh of his foreskin <b>shall be circumcised”</b> (Leviticus 12:3), and nevertheless <b>it was stated for the Jewish people</b> alone <b>and not for the descendants of Noah.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse stated at Sinai is not necessary for the mitzva itself, but rather <b>it comes to permit</b> circumcision on <b>Shabbat.</b> It is derived from the phrase <b>“on the</b> eighth <b>day”</b> that circumcision must always be performed on the eight day, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if it falls <b>on Shabbat.</b> Therefore the mitzva is not considered to have been repeated at Mount Sinai.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the mitzva of <b>procreation, which was stated with regard to the descendants of Noah? As it is written: “And you, be fruitful and multiply,</b> swarm in the land and multiply in it” (Genesis 9:7). <b>And it was repeated at Sinai,</b> in the verse: <b>“Go say to them: Return to your tents”</b> (Deuteronomy 5:26), when the Jewish men were commanded to resume conjugal relations with their wives after having been commanded to separate from them in preparation for the giving of the Torah. Nevertheless, the mitzva of procreation <b>was stated for the Jewish people and not for the descendants of Noah.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse stated at Sinai is not necessary for the mitzva itself, but rather <b>it comes to</b> teach another <i>halakha</i>: <b>That any matter that</b> was prohibited <b>by</b> an official <b>vote</b> of the Sanhedrin <b>requires another vote to permit it.</b> Even if a rabbinic prohibition is no longer relevant, it is not automatically canceled, but rather a special ruling is required to cancel it. This is derived from the fact that it was necessary for God to issue a declaration (Deuteronomy 5:26) specifically canceling the prohibition that had been issued before the giving of the Torah.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let us say</b> with regard to <b>each and every one</b> of the seven Noahide mitzvot that <b>it was repeated because of</b> an additional <b>matter</b> the Torah teaches, and the descendants of Noah are exempt from them all.
The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>is saying:</b> After stating <b>a prohibition</b> with regard to the descendants of Noah, <b>why do I</b> need the Torah to <b>then repeat</b> the prohibition itself for the Jewish people? If the only purpose is to teach an additional <i>halakha</i>, it is unnecessary to repeat it in the form of a prohibition, e.g., “You shall not murder…you shall not commit adultery” (Exodus 20:13). Therefore, it is derived from the fact that the entire prohibition is repeated, and not just the new details, that it applies both to Jews and to descendants of Noah.
It is stated in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And we have only</b> the prohibition against eating <b>the sciatic nerve</b> to which this classification applies, <b>and</b> this is <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara asks: But <b>these</b> aforementioned mitzvot <b>also,</b> procreation and circumcision, <b>were not repeated</b> at Sinai in order to teach that they apply to the descendants of Noah as well as to the Jewish people, but rather were mentioned for other purposes, and therefore, they apply only to the Jewish people, similar to the prohibition against eating the sciatic nerve.
The Gemara answers: <b>These</b> mitzvot <b>were repeated for the sake of</b> teaching <b>some</b> other <b>matter.</b> By contrast, <b>this</b> prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>was not repeated at all;</b> it is mentioned only in Genesis. Therefore, circumcision and procreation are not included in the category of mitzvot that were given to the descendants of Noah and were not repeated at Sinai.
<b>If you wish, say</b> that there is another explanation for the fact that the mitzva of <b>circumcision</b> does not apply to the descendants of Noah despite the fact that it was repeated for the Jewish people: <b>From the outset, it was Abraham,</b> and not all the descendants of Noah, <b>that the Merciful One commanded to</b> perform this mitzva; as He said to him: <b>“And as for you, you shall keep My covenant, you and your offspring after you, throughout their generations”</b> (Genesis 17:9). The Gemara infers: <b>“You and your offspring,” yes; another person, no.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If that is so, the descendants of Ishmael should</b> also <b>be obligated</b> to observe circumcision, as they are also the offspring of Abraham. The Gemara explains: The verse states: <b>“For through Isaac, offspring shall be called yours”</b> (Genesis 21:12), which means that Ishmael’s descendants are not called the offspring of Abraham.
The Gemara challenges: Granted, Ishmael’s descendants are not considered the offspring of Abraham, but at least <b>the descendants of Esau,</b> Isaac’s son, <b>should be obligated</b> to observe circumcision. The Gemara explains: Since the term: <b>“Through Isaac [<i>beYitzḥak</i>],”</b> also means: Of Isaac, it is derived that the mitzva applies to only some of Isaac’s offspring, <b>but not all</b> the descendants of <b>Isaac.</b> This serves to exclude the descendants of Esau.
<b>Rav Oshaya objects to this: If that is so, the descendants of Keturah,</b> Abraham’s second wife, <b>should not be obligated</b> to observe circumcision. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Avin says, and some say</b> that it is <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina</b> who says that the verse: “And the uncircumcised male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin, that soul shall be cut off from his people; <b>he has broken My covenant”</b> (Genesis 17:14) is stated <b>to include the descendants of Keturah</b> in the obligation to observe circumcision.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: Meat was not permitted to Adam, the first</b> man, <b>for consumption, as it is written:</b> “And God said: Behold, I have given you every herb that brings forth seed, which is upon the face of all the earth, and every tree, in which is the fruit of a tree that gives forth seed; <b>for you it shall be for food, and for every animal of the earth,</b> and for every fowl of the air, and for everything that creeps upon the earth, in which there is a living soul, every green herb for food. And it was so” (Genesis 1:29–30). It is derived God told Adam: Eating vegetation is permitted to people and animals, <b>but</b> eating <b>the animals of the earth is not</b> permitted <b>to you.</b>
<b>But when the children of Noah came,</b> God <b>permitted them</b> to eat meat; <b>as it is stated:</b> “Every moving thing that lives shall be for food for you; <b>as the green herb I have given you all”</b> (Genesis 9:3). One <b>might</b> have thought that accordingly, even the prohibition against eating <b>a limb from a living</b> animal <b>does not apply to</b> the descendants of Noah; therefore <b>the verse states: “Only flesh with its life, which is its blood, you shall not eat”</b> (Genesis 9:4). One <b>might</b> have thought that the prohibition against eating a limb from a living animal applies <b>even to creeping animals;</b> therefore <b>the verse states “only,”</b> a term used for exclusion, indicating that creeping animals are not included.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the derivation?</b> What is the proof that it is creeping animals that are excluded from this prohibition and not another type of animal? <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The term <b>“its blood”</b> indicates that the prohibition pertains to animals <b>whose blood is</b> halakhically considered <b>separate from their flesh.</b> This <b>excludes creeping animals, whose blood is not</b> considered <b>separate from their flesh.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the assertion that eating meat was prohibited to Adam, from the verse: <b>“And have dominion over the fish of the sea,</b> and over the fowl of the air, and over every living thing that creeps upon the land” (Genesis 1:28). <b>What, is it not</b> stated <b>with regard to consumption,</b> i.e., doesn’t this verse mean that people may eat the meat of animals? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the verse is referring <b>to</b> using animals for <b>labor.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But are fish capable of</b> performing <b>labor?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> they are capable, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Raḥava; as Raḥava asked</b> the following question: If one <b>drove</b> a wagon to which <b>a goat and a <i>shibbuta</i></b> fish were harnessed together, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Has he violated the prohibition of diverse kinds, in the same way that one does when plowing with an ox and a donkey together? In any event, Raḥava’s question indicates that there is a way, albeit far-fetched, for a fish to perform labor.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof that it was permitted for Adam to eat meat, from the phrase in the aforementioned verse: “And have dominion…<b>and over the fowl of the air.” What, is it not</b> stated with regard <b>to consumption?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is referring <b>to labor.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But are birds capable of</b> performing <b>labor?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> they are capable, <b>as Rabba bar Rav Huna raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>threshed with geese and chickens, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, derives from the verse: “You shall not muzzle an ox when it treads” (Deuteronomy 25:4), that a laborer in a field is entitled to eat from the produce during his work only if his work involves both his hands and his feet, like an ox, which treads with its forelegs as well as its hind legs. Rabba bar Rav Huna raises a dilemma as to whether the prohibition against muzzling an animal while it is being used for labor in the field applies to geese and chickens, which have only two feet. In any event, it is indicated in that dilemma that birds can perform labor.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the phrase: “And have dominion…<b>and over every living thing that creeps upon the land.”</b> Creeping animals certainly cannot be used for labor. Apparently, the verse is referring to eating them. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> phrase <b>comes to include</b> the <b>snake,</b> which was capable of performing labor when it was created.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says: Woe over a great attendant that has been lost to the world; as had the snake not been cursed</b> that it should go on its belly, <b>there would have been two fine snakes at the disposal of each and every one of the Jewish people. One he would send to the north, and</b> the other <b>one he would send to the south, to bring him precious <i>sandalbonim</i>,</b> a type of precious stone, <b>and</b> other <b>precious stones and pearls. Moreover,</b> he would <b>attach a strap under</b> his snake’s <b>tail</b> like a harness to an animal, <b>and use it to take dirt out to his garden and to</b> rebuild <b>his ruin,</b> as he does with other animals. This demonstrates that the snake was capable of performing labor.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> to the assertion that eating meat was prohibited to Adam: <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima would say: Adam, the first</b> man, <b>would dine in the Garden of Eden, and the ministering angels would roast meat for him and strain wine for him. The snake glanced at him and saw his glory, and was jealous of him,</b> and for that reason the snake incited him to sin and caused his banishment from the Garden. According to this, evidently Adam would eat meat. The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> the reference is <b>to meat that descended from heaven,</b> which was created by a miracle and was not the meat of animals at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is there</b> such a thing as <b>meat that descends from heaven?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is like this</b> incident: <b>As Rabbi Shimon ben Ḥalafta was walking along the way, he encountered those lions that were roaring at him,</b> intending to eat him. <b>He said: “The young lions roar after their prey,</b> and seek their food from God” (Psalms 104:21), and they deserve to receive food. <b>Two thighs</b> of an animal <b>descended</b> from heaven <b>for him.</b> The lions <b>ate one</b> of these thighs, <b>and they left</b> the other <b>one. He took it and entered the study hall,</b> and <b>inquired about it: Is this</b> thigh <b>a kosher item or a non-kosher item?</b> The Sages <b>said to him:</b> Certainly it is kosher, as <b>a non-kosher item does not descend from heaven.</b>
In connection to that story, it is related that <b>Rabbi Zeira asked Rabbi Abbahu:</b> If <b>the likeness of a donkey had descended for him, what</b> would the <i>halakha</i> have been? Would it have been permitted? Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him: Foolish bird [<i>yarud nala</i>].</b> The Sages already <b>said to him</b> that <b>a non-kosher item does not descend from heaven;</b> therefore, it must be kosher.
§ In the <i>baraita</i> that lists the Noahide mitzvot (56a), it is stated that <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the descendants of Noah were <b>also</b> commanded <b>concerning</b> the prohibition against engaging in <b>sorcery.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning</b> behind the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written:</b>

Daf 60a

<b>“You shall not allow a witch to live”</b> (Exodus 22:17), <b>and it is written</b> in the following verse: <b>“Whoever lies with an animal shall be put to death”</b> (Exodus 22:18). It is derived from here that <b>anyone who is included in</b> the prohibition of: <b>“Whoever lies with an animal,”</b> including gentiles, <b>is included in</b> the command: <b>“You shall not allow a witch to live.”</b>
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that descendants of Noah were <b>also</b> commanded <b>about</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Shmuel says:</b> They are derived from that <b>which the verse states: “My statutes you shall keep.</b> You shall not breed your animal with a diverse kind; you shall not sow your field with two kinds of seed” (Leviticus 19:19). God is saying: Keep the <b>statutes that I have already instituted for you,</b> i.e., mitzvot that were already given to the descendants of Noah, namely, <b>“you shall not breed your animal with a diverse kind; you shall not sow your field with two kinds of seed.”</b>
The Gemara derives the details of this prohibition from the verse: <b>Just as</b> the Noahide prohibition concerning <b>your animal</b> applies <b>with regard to breeding</b> animals of different species, and not with regard to plowing with animals of two different species working together, which is prohibited only for Jews, <b>so too,</b> the Noahide prohibition in <b>your field</b> applies <b>with regard to grafting</b> one species onto another, which is equivalent to breeding, but it is not prohibited for gentiles to sow different seeds together. Furthermore, <b>just as</b> the Noahide prohibition against breeding <b>your animal</b> applies <b>both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>so too,</b> the Noahide prohibition against grafting diverse kinds in <b>your field</b> applies <b>both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the term “My statutes” is understood as referring to mitzvot that were already given to the descendants of Noah, then the verse: <b>“You shall therefore keep My statutes and My ordinances”</b> (Leviticus 18:5), referring to the entire Torah, should also obligate the descendants of Noah, as it would be referring to: <b>Statutes that I have already instituted for you.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> the verse states: <b>“You shall therefore keep My statutes,”</b> indicating only those statutes <b>that</b> I am giving you <b>now,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> in the verse concerning diverse kinds, the wording is <b>“My statutes you shall keep,”</b> meaning <b>statutes that</b> obligate you <b>from the outset you shall keep</b> in the future.
§ After clarifying the <i>halakhot</i> of the descendants of Noah, the Gemara returns to the <i>halakhot</i> stated in the mishna with regard to one who blasphemes. It is stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa said</b> that during a blasphemer’s trial, the judges ask the witnesses to use an appellation for the name of God so that they do not utter a curse of God’s name. Specifically, they would use the sentence: Let Yosei smite Yosei, as the name Yosei has four letters in Hebrew, like the Tetragrammaton.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov says:</b> The blasphemer <b>is not liable unless he blesses,</b> i.e., curses, <b>the Tetragrammaton,</b> the four-letter name of God, which is <b>to the exclusion of</b> one who curses the <b>two-letter</b> name of God, spelled <i>yod heh</i>, <b>who is not</b> liable.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious? We learned</b> in the mishna that the expression used in court is <b>let Yosei smite Yosei,</b> which indicates a four-letter name. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> <b>mentions</b> this <b>statement</b> as <b>a mere</b> example but does not intend that the witnesses use the four-letter name in particular, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <b>teaches us</b> that one is liable only for cursing the Tetragrammaton.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov says</b> as follows: <b>Conclude from</b> the mishna that the <b>Tetragrammaton is also a name</b> for which one is liable, and he is liable not only for cursing the forty-two-letter name of God.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious? We learned</b> in the mishna that the expression used in court is <b>let Yosei smite Yosei.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that one is not liable <b>unless there is a grand name</b> that he curses, i.e., the forty-two-letter name, <b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>mentions</b> this <b>statement</b> as <b>a mere</b> example, Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <b>teaches us</b> that one is liable even for cursing the Tetragrammaton, and the name Yosei is mentioned specifically.
§ The mishna teaches: When <b>the judgment is over,</b> and judges need to hear the exact wording of the curse so they can sentence the defendant, the eldest of the witnesses repeats the curse, and the judges rise and make a tear in their clothing.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the judges must <b>stand? Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Ami says:</b> It is derived from that <b>which the verse states</b> about Eglon: <b>“And Ehud came to him, and he was sitting by himself alone in his cool upper chamber. And Ehud said: I have a message from God [<i>Elohim</i>] to you. And he arose out of his seat”</b> (Judges 3:20). <b>And are</b> these <b>matters not</b> inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i>? And if Eglon, king of Moab, who was a gentile and knew</b> the name of God <b>only by an appellation, stood</b> in honor, <b>all the more so</b> must <b>a Jew</b> stand if he hears <b>the ineffable name.</b>
The mishna teaches that upon hearing the curse the judges each <b>make a tear</b> in their garments. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? The Gemara answers that it is derived from that <b>which is written: “Then came Eliakim, son of Hilkiah,</b> who was over the household, <b>and Shebna the scribe, and Joah, son of Asaph, the recorder, to Hezekiah with torn garments, and they told him Rabshakeh’s statement”</b> (II Kings 18:37). Apparently, since they heard the blasphemous statement of Rabshakeh they were obligated to make a tear in their garments.
It is furthermore stated that the judges <b>do not</b> ever fully <b>stitch</b> the tear together again. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this?
<b>Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the <b>tearing</b> stated in this regard and the <b>tearing</b> stated with regard to Elijah’s ascendance to heaven. <b>It is written here,</b> with regard to those who heard Rabshakeh’s blasphemy: <b>“With torn garments,” and it is written there: “And Elisha saw it, and he cried: My father, my father, the chariots of Israel and its horsemen. And he saw him no more, and he grabbed hold of his clothes and tore them into two pieces”</b> (II Kings 2:12). <b>From the meaning of that</b> which <b>is stated: “And tore them into two,” do I not know that they are pieces? And why</b> must <b>the verse state: “Pieces”?</b> This <b>teaches that they</b> remain <b>torn forever;</b> they may never be fully stitched back together, but only partially sewn.
<b>The Sages taught: Both one who hears</b> the curse himself <b>and</b> one who <b>hears</b> it <b>from</b> the one who <b>heard</b> it are <b>obligated to make a tear</b> in their garments. <b>But the witnesses are not obligated to make a tear</b> when they testify, <b>as they already made a tear when they heard</b> it from the blasphemer himself.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if they made a tear when they heard</b> the curse, <b>what of it? Aren’t they</b> also <b>hearing</b> the curse <b>now?</b> The Gemara answers: It should <b>not enter your mind</b> that they are obligated to make a tear a second time, <b>as it is written: “And it came to pass, when King Hezekiah heard the statement of Rabshakeh, that he tore his clothes”</b> (II Kings 19:1). It can be inferred that <b>King Hezekiah tore</b> his clothes, <b>but those</b> who reported the blasphemy <b>did not tear</b> their clothes a second time.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: One who hears a mention</b> of God’s name in a blasphemous manner <b>from a gentile is not obligated to make a tear</b> in his garments. <b>And if you</b> object and <b>say</b> that those who heard the blasphemy of <b>Rabshakeh</b> made a tear even though he was a gentile, that is not correct, as Rabshakeh <b>was an apostate Jew.</b>
<b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: One makes a tear only for</b> hearing a curse of <b>the ineffable name</b> of God, <b>to the exclusion of</b> hearing a curse of <b>an appellation</b> for the name of God, for <b>which</b> one does <b>not</b> make a tear.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> Shmuel <b>disagrees with Rav Ḥiyya with regard to two</b> matters. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya says: One who hears a mention</b> of God’s name in a blasphemous context <b>nowadays is not obligated to make a tear, as if you do not say so, the entire garment will be full of tears.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>From whom</b> does one hear these mentions of God’s name about which Rabbi Ḥiyya says that one’s entire garment would be full of tears? <b>If we say</b> that he hears <b>from</b> it <b>a Jew, are</b> Jews <b>irreverent to such an extent</b> that they demean the name of God? <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that Rabbi Ḥiyya is referring to hearing it <b>from a gentile. And if</b> you say that the reference is to cursing <b>the ineffable name, have</b> the gentiles <b>learned</b> it? They have no knowledge of his name. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to cursing <b>by an appellation</b> of God’s name?
<b>And conclude from it</b> that <b>it is</b> specifically <b>nowadays that,</b> according to Rav Ḥiyya, one is <b>not</b> obligated to make a tear in his garment when hearing the curse of a gentile and when hearing a curse of God that referred to God with an appellation, <b>but initially,</b> when the fundamental <i>halakha</i> was practiced, one was <b>obligated</b> to make a tear in these cases, contrary to the opinion of Shmuel. The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is so.
§ The mishna teaches that after the eldest witness states the exact wording of the curse, <b>the second</b> witness does not repeat it, but he <b>says: I too</b> heard <b>as he</b> did. <b>Reish Lakish says: Conclude from it</b> that saying: <b>I too</b> heard <b>as he</b> did, is <b>valid</b> testimony by Torah law, both <b>in</b> cases of <b>monetary law and in</b> cases of <b>capital law. And</b> the requirement that every witness must relate his testimony separately <b>is a higher standard that the Sages instituted, and here, since it is not possible</b> to fulfill this requirement, as it is not appropriate for a blasphemous statement to be repeated several times, <b>the Sages established</b> the matter <b>according to Torah law</b> and did not require that every witness repeat the curse.
<b>As if it enters your mind</b> that saying: I too heard as he did, is <b>not valid</b> testimony by Torah law, <b>here,</b> in the case of blasphemy, <b>would we execute the man</b> without full testimony <b>because it is not possible</b> to allow the repetition of blasphemy? Clearly, such testimony is valid by Torah law.
The mishna teaches: <b>And the third</b> witness <b>says: I too</b> heard <b>as he</b> did. The Gemara comments: The <b>unattributed</b> <i>tanna</i> of the mishna holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who compares three</b> witnesses <b>to two.</b> Rabbi Akiva maintains that just as in a case where there are two witnesses, the disqualification of one disqualifies all of the testimony, so too, even if there are three witnesses, and one of the three is disqualified, all of the testimony is disqualified. Similarly, here too he holds that if there are three witnesses, each of them must testify concerning the curse.

Daf 60b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who worships idols</b> is executed by stoning. This includes <b>one who worships</b> an idol, <b>and one who slaughters</b> an animal as an idolatrous offering, <b>and one who burns</b> incense as an idolatrous offering, <b>and one who pours a libation</b> in idol worship, <b>and one who bows</b> to an idol, <b>and one who</b> declares that he <b>accepts</b> an idol <b>upon himself as a god, and one who says to</b> an idol: <b>You are my god.</b>
<b>But</b> with regard to <b>one who hugs</b> an idol, <b>or one who kisses</b> it, <b>or one who cleans</b> it, <b>or one who sprays</b> water before it, <b>or one who washes</b> it, <b>or one who rubs</b> it with oil, <b>or one who dresses</b> it, <b>or one who puts its shoes on</b> it, he <b>transgresses a prohibition</b> but is not liable to receive capital punishment. With regard to <b>one who vows in</b> an idol’s <b>name and one who affirms</b> his statement by an oath <b>in its name,</b> he <b>transgresses a prohibition.</b>
<b>One who defecates before</b> the idol known as <b>Ba’al-Peor</b> is liable to receive capital punishment, even though defecating is a degrading act, as <b>that is its</b> form of <b>worship.</b> Likewise, <b>one who throws a stone at Mercury</b> is liable to receive capital punishment, as <b>that is its</b> form of <b>worship.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What</b> is added in the mishna by stating the phrase: <b>One who worships?</b> Since worship is the general description of all the actions detailed in the mishna, why is this phrase necessary?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: One who worships</b> an idol <b>in its</b> typical <b>manner</b> of worship is liable to be executed; <b>and</b> furthermore, <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal as an idolatrous offering, <b>and one who burns</b> incense, <b>and one who pours</b> a libation, <b>and the one who bows</b> to an idol are all liable to be executed, <b>and</b> this applies <b>even</b> if this manner of worship is <b>not</b> the idol’s typical <b>manner</b> of worship. Even if the idol in question is not typically worshipped in these ways, these specific acts are still considered idol worship because these are the ways in which God is worshipped in the Temple.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> the mishna <b>also count sprinkling</b> the blood of an offering, which is also one of the sacrificial rites in the Temple. <b>Abaye says: Sprinkling</b> the blood of an offering <b>is</b> the same as <b>pouring</b> a libation, since they are essentially one sacrificial rite, <b>as it is written: “I will not pour their libations of blood”</b> (Psalms 16:4), indicating that sprinkling the blood of an offering is also referred to as offering a libation.
§ The Gemara asks with regard to the <i>halakha</i> that one is liable for worshipping an idol in these manners even if they are not the way the idol is typically worshipped: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived?
The Gemara answers: <b>As the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “One who sacrifices to the gods shall be utterly destroyed, except to the Lord alone” (Exodus 22:19): <b>If it were stated: One who sacrifices shall be utterly destroyed, I would have said</b> that <b>the verse speaks of one who slaughters a sacrificial</b> animal <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, referring to a severe transgression that is stated elsewhere in the Torah. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “To the gods,”</b> indicating that <b>the verse speaks of one who slaughters</b> an offering <b>to an idol.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> asks: From here <b>I</b> know <b>only</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who slaughters</b> an offering to an idol. <b>From where</b> is it derived that one who <b>burns</b> incense <b>or pours</b> a libation is also liable to receive the death penalty? The <i>baraita</i> answers that <b>the verse states: “Except to the Lord alone”;</b> the verse <b>emptied out,</b> i.e., designated, <b>all the</b> sacrificial <b>rites to the ineffable name</b> of God, indicating that one who performs any of these rites in idol worship is liable.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Since slaughter is singled out</b> from all of the forms of worship to be mentioned in this verse in order <b>to derive</b> from it that <b>with regard to</b> all the sacrificial <b>rites</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Temple, one who performs them in idol worship is liable to receive capital punishment, <b>from where</b> is it derived that this <i>halakha</i> <b>includes bowing</b> down to an idol, which is not a sacrificial rite?
The <i>baraita</i> answers that <b>the verse states: “And has gone and served other gods and bowed to them”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:3), <b>and</b> a verse <b>near it</b> states: <b>“Then you shall bring forth that man</b> or that woman who has done this evil thing to your gates, the man or the woman, and you shall stone them with stones and they shall die” (Deuteronomy 17:5). It is derived from the juxtaposition of these two verses that one who bows down to an idol is liable to be executed.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>We have heard</b> the <b>punishment</b> for bowing down to an idol, but <b>from where</b> is the <b>prohibition</b> against doing so derived? The <i>baraita</i> answers that <b>the verse states: “For you shall bow to no other god”</b> (Exodus 34:14).
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I should include</b> among those liable to receive capital punishment <b>one who hugs</b> an idol, <b>or one who kisses</b> it, <b>or one who puts its shoes on</b> it as well. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “One who sacrifices</b> shall be utterly destroyed,” referring to the act of slaughtering an offering in idol worship.
The <i>baraita</i> explains: The <b>slaughter</b> of an offering <b>was included</b> in the general category of the prohibited forms of idol worship, <b>and why was it singled out</b> to be mentioned in this verse? It was singled out <b>to compare</b> a matter <b>to it and say to you: Just as slaughter is notable</b> in <b>that it is</b> a sacrificial <b>rite</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Temple, <b>and</b> those who perform this rite for the purpose of idol worship <b>are liable</b> to receive <b>the death penalty for it, so too, any</b> form of worship <b>that is</b> a sacrificial <b>rite</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Temple is prohibited when performed for idol worship, <b>and</b> transgressors <b>are liable</b> to receive <b>the death penalty for it.</b>
Therefore, the act of <b>bowing</b> to an idol <b>is singled out</b> to be mentioned in a separate verse <b>to derive</b> the death penalty for that action <b>itself,</b> despite the fact that it is not a sacrificial rite performed in the Temple, whereas the <b>slaughter</b> of an offering <b>is singled out</b> to be mentioned in order <b>to derive</b> from it the principle <b>with regard to the entire category,</b> namely, that generally one is not liable to receive capital punishment for a form of worship that is not performed in the Temple.
The Gemara proceeds to clarify the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>I would have said</b> that <b>the verse speaks of one who slaughters a sacrificial</b> animal <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard. The Gemara asks: The punishment for <b>one who slaughters a sacrificial</b> animal <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>is <i>karet</i>,</b> not capital punishment, as it is stated: “Each and every man…who offers a burnt-offering or sacrifice, and does not bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting to sacrifice it to the Lord, even that man shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 17:8–9). Therefore, how can the <i>baraita</i> suggest that a verse that mentions capital punishment could be referring to this transgression?
The Gemara answers: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that in a case <b>when</b> the witnesses <b>warned</b> the transgressor not to slaughter the offering outside the Temple he is liable to receive <b>the death</b> penalty, but in a case <b>when they did not warn him</b> he is liable to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that one who slaughters an offering outside the Temple is not liable to receive the death penalty even if he was warned.
The <i>baraita</i> states that the principle concerning the forms of idol worship that are punishable by execution is derived from the verse that mentions slaughtering an animal as an idolatrous offering, whereas bowing to an idol is mentioned in the verse as an exception. <b>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye: Say</b> that <b>bowing is singled out</b> to be mentioned <b>to teach, with regard to the entire category,</b> that any honorable form of worship, when performed for the sake of idol worship, carries the death penalty, not only sacrificial rites performed the Temple.
<b>And if you would say</b> that if so, <b>why do I</b> need <b>slaughter</b> to be mentioned in the verse specifically, one can say that mentioning slaughter is necessary <b>for</b> the matter of slaughter <b>itself,</b> i.e., to teach <b>that one can have intention from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite.</b> In other words, slaughtering an animal with idolatrous intent is punishable by death even if the intention of the transgressor pertains not to the slaughter itself but to another part of the sacrificial process.
<b>As it was stated</b> that with regard to <b>one who slaughters an animal</b> in order <b>to sprinkle its blood in idol worship or to burn its fat in idol worship, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b>

Daf 61a

Deriving benefit from the animal is <b>prohibited,</b> as it is considered an offering of idol worship, even if its blood was not ultimately sprinkled for idol worship or its forbidden fat burned for that purpose. <b>And Reish Lakish says:</b> Deriving benefit from the animal is <b>permitted.</b>
Rava bar Rav Ḥanan concludes his analysis: <b>According to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who derives this <i>halakha</i> from another source, <b>this</b> statement in the <i>baraita</i> <b>works out well.</b> The verse that mentions the slaughter of an animal in idol worship apparently teaches a principle, as it is superfluous with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of slaughter itself, as stated in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>But according to Reish Lakish,</b> who does not derive from any verse that one can have intention from one rite to another rite, <b>one needs</b> this <b>verse</b> to derive precisely this <i>halakha</i>, that one can have intention from one rite to another rite. Consequently, the verse is not superfluous, and it cannot be assumed that it teaches a principle with regard to the forms of idol worship that are punishable by death.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this: And according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, does one not need a verse</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> in a case of intention from one rite to another rite? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> initially <b>only prohibits</b> deriving benefit from the <b>animal; but</b> if not for this verse, <b>the man</b> who slaughtered the animal would <b>not be liable</b> to receive <b>the death</b> penalty. <b>And</b> therefore <b>the verse comes to render the man liable</b> to receive <b>the death</b> penalty. Therefore this verse is not superfluous according to Rabbi Yoḥanan either.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, objects to</b> Rava bar Rav Ḥanan’s challenge to the derivation in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> even <b>according to Reish Lakish, does one need a verse</b> to teach that the one who slaughtered the animal is liable? <b>Reish Lakish only permits</b> one to derive benefit from the <b>animal; but the man is</b> certainly <b>liable to</b> receive <b>the death</b> penalty. This is <b>just as</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> in the case of <b>one who bows to a mountain, as</b> deriving benefit from the <b>mountain is permitted, but</b> nevertheless <b>the one who worshipped it</b> is liable to be executed <b>by</b> the <b>sword.</b> Therefore, the verse that states that one who slaughters an offering in idol worship is liable to be executed is superfluous with regard to the issue of intention from one rite to another.
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: According to what Rava bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye,</b> that there is room to <b>say</b> that <b>bowing was singled out</b> in the verse <b>to teach, with regard to the entire category,</b> that any honorable form of worship carries the death penalty, there is a difficulty. With regard to the verse: “Take heed to yourself that you not be ensnared to follow them…saying, <b>how do</b> these nations <b>serve</b> their gods, so I will do likewise” (Deuteronomy 12:30), which indicates that one is liable for worshipping an idol in the manner that the gentiles worship it, this is stated <b>to exclude what?</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that this verse is stated <b>to exclude one who defecates before</b> an idol that is worshipped by <b>sacrificing</b> offerings, it is not necessary to derive this <i>halakha</i> from this verse, as <b>it is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>bowing</b> to an idol, as follows: <b>Just as bowing is an honorable</b> form of worship and is punishable by death, <b>so too, any honorable</b> form of worship is punishable by death when performed as idol worship, which excludes an offensive act such as defecating. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> that one is not liable for defecating before an idol can be derived from bowing.
<b>Rather,</b> this verse is stated <b>to exclude one who defecates before</b> the idol called <b>Mercury,</b> which is not its typical manner of worship. It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> the standard manner of <b>worship</b> of Mercury, namely, throwing stones at it, <b>is</b> in any event an act of <b>degradation, so too,</b> one who performs <b>any</b> act of <b>degradation</b> as worship of Mercury should be liable. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that one is liable only for worshiping Mercury in its standard manner of worship.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>But</b> Rava bar Rav Ḥanan’s interpretation of the verses appears to contradict <b>that which Rabbi Eliezer says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> one who <b>sacrifices an animal to Mercury is liable? As it is stated: “And they shall no longer sacrifice their sacrifices to the satyrs”</b> (Leviticus 17:7).
Rabbi Eliezer explains: <b>If</b> the verse <b>is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of</b> one who worships an idol <b>in its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> i.e., one who sacrifices an animal as an offering to an idol that is worshipped by sacrificing offerings, <b>as</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case <b>is</b> already <b>written</b> in the aforementioned verse: <b>“How do</b> these nations <b>serve</b> their gods, so I will do likewise,” <b>apply it to</b> the <b>matter</b> of one who worships an idol <b>not in its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> by sacrificing an offering to an idol that is not typically worshipped by sacrificing offerings. Therefore, one who sacrifices an offering to Mercury is liable, even though that is not its typical form of worship.
According to Rava bar Rav Ḥanan, by contrast, <b>it is derived</b> that one is liable for worshipping an idol in any honorable manner, even <b>not in its</b> typical <b>manner</b> of worship, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>bowing.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the verse mentioned by Rabbi Eliezer, the reference is <b>to one who sacrifices</b> an offering to Mercury not as a form of worship, but rather <b>in order to express insolence</b> toward the Torah prohibition against sacrificing an offering to an idol. It is derived from the verse that this too is a transgression of the prohibition and renders one liable for the death penalty.
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Hamnuna lost his oxen</b> and went to search for them. <b>Rabba met him</b> and <b>raised</b> a contradiction <b>between</b> two <b><i>mishnayot</i>. We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>one who worships idols</b> is liable. By inference, one who <b>worships</b> idols, <b>yes,</b> he is liable, but one who merely <b>says</b> that he will worship idols is <b>not</b> liable. <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in another mishna (67a): <b>One who says: I will worship</b> an idol, or: <b>I will go and worship</b> an idol, or: <b>Let us go and worship</b> an idol, is liable, just as one who actually worships an idol is liable. Evidently, one is liable for merely stating his intention to engage in idol worship.
Rav Hamnuna <b>said to him:</b> The mishna here is referring <b>to one who states: I</b> intend to <b>accept</b> this idol <b>upon myself</b> as a god <b>only through worship.</b> Consequently, he is liable only when he actually worships it. One who intends to accept the idol as a god immediately is liable even before he actually worships it.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This answer is unnecessary; <b>have you removed the <i>tanna’im</i> from the world? It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who says:</b> I am a god; <b>come and worship me, Rabbi Meir deems</b> him <b>liable</b> for incitement to idol worship, <b>and Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara explains: In a case <b>where</b> those to whom the inciter spoke subsequently <b>worshiped</b> him, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the inciter is liable, <b>as it is written: “You shall not make yourself a graven image”</b> (Exodus 20:4), which is interpreted to include a case where one establishes himself as a god. <b>When they disagree</b> is in a case where the incident ended <b>in mere speech. Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>speech is</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> and therefore the inciter is liable for incitement, <b>and Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>speech is nothing.</b> Therefore, the contradiction between the <i>mishnayot</i> can be resolved by attributing each mishna to a different <i>tanna</i>.
<b>Rav Yosef then said</b> after reconsidering the matter: <b>What I said is not correct, as even according to Rabbi Yehuda, one is deemed liable for speech as well. As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Actually,</b> one <b>is not liable unless he says: I will worship,</b> or: <b>I will go and worship,</b> or: <b>Let us go and worship.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda holds that one is liable even for speech alone, not only for actual worship.
Accordingly, <b>with regard to what</b> principle do Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagree? They disagree with regard to</b> the case of one who <b>incites</b> others to worship <b>him, and</b> the others <b>say to him: Yes,</b> we will worship you. <b>One</b> Sage, Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that when <b>one incites</b> others <b>to</b> worship <b>him,</b> they are apt to <b>listen to him, and</b> the response: <b>Yes, that they say to him, is sincere. And one</b> Sage, Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> when <b>one incites</b> others <b>to</b> worship <b>him,</b> they are <b>not</b> apt to <b>listen to him,</b> as <b>they say</b> to themselves:

Daf 61b

In <b>what</b> way <b>is he different from us?</b> The suggestion to worship him is nonsense. <b>And</b> the fact <b>that they say to him: Yes,</b> is because <b>they ridicule him.</b>
<b>And</b> the contradiction between the <b><i>mishnayot</i></b> can be resolved as follows: <b>There,</b> where the mishna states that one is liable for speech alone, the reference is <b>to an individual</b> who was <b>incited; here,</b> where the mishna indicates that one not is liable for speech alone, it is referring <b>to</b> a case of <b>an incited multitude</b> of people. The Gemara explains: <b>An individual</b> who was incited <b>does not</b> typically <b>change his mind, and he goes astray after</b> idol worship. Therefore, once he agrees to the suggestion to worship an idol, he has fully accepted the idol upon himself as a god and is liable. By contrast, <b>a multitude</b> of people are apt to <b>change their minds, and</b> consequently they <b>do not go astray after</b> idol worship.
<b>Rav Yosef said: From where do I say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that one is liable for merely stating that he will worship an idol is referring to an individual who was incited? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to one who incites people to engage in idol worship: <b>“You shall not approve of him, nor listen to him”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:9), which indicates that if one <b>approved</b> of <b>and listened</b> to the inciter, stating his intention to engage in idol worship, he is <b>liable</b> even if he does not actually worship an idol.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rav Yosef’s opinion: <b>Is</b> there <b>a difference</b> in <i>halakha</i> <b>between</b> the cases of <b>an incited multitude</b> of people <b>and an individual</b> who was <b>incited? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“If your brother, the son of your mother,</b> or your son, or your daughter, or the wife of your bosom, or your neighbor who is like your own soul, <b>incites you</b> secretly, saying: Let us go and serve other gods” (Deuteronomy 13:7), that <b>both an individual</b> who was <b>incited and an incited multitude</b> of people are included in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>but the verse singles out the individual from the category of the multitude, and</b> another verse singles out <b>the multitude from the category of the individual.</b>
The Torah states separately the <i>halakhot</i> of an individual who is incited to engage in idol worship and of an entire city that is subverted to engage in idol worship in order to distinguish between the two cases, as follows: <b>An individual</b> who was incited is singled out <b>from the category of</b> a subverted <b>multitude</b> of people in order <b>to render</b> the punishment <b>to</b> an individual’s <b>body</b> more <b>stringent.</b> The individual is executed by stoning, whereas the residents of an idolatrous city are executed by decapitation. <b>And</b> an individual was singled out <b>to render</b> the treatment of <b>the property of</b> an individual who was incited more <b>lenient,</b> as it is not destroyed like that of the residents of an idolatrous city.
Additionally, the Torah singles out the subverted <b>multitude</b> of people <b>from the category of an individual</b> who was incited in order <b>to render</b> the punishment given <b>to the bodies of</b> the residents of an idolatrous city, decapitation, more <b>lenient</b> than that given to an individual who was incited, <b>and to render</b> the treatment <b>of their property</b> more <b>stringent,</b> as the city and the property of its residents are burned.
Abaye concluded his objection to Rav Yosef’s opinion: It can be inferred from the <i>baraita</i> that only <b>with regard to this matter,</b> i.e., the <i>halakhot</i> mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of an individual who was incited <b>different</b> than that of an incited multitude of people, <b>but with regard to all</b> other halakhic <b>matters they are the same.</b> Therefore, a distinction cannot be made between them with regard to the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a verbal commitment to idol worship.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that the contradiction between the <i>mishnayot</i> is to be resolved as follows: <b>Here,</b> where the mishna indicates that one is liable only for actual worship, the reference is <b>to</b> one who is <b>incited by himself,</b> i.e., no one incited him to idol worship and he made the decision on his own. Whereas <b>there,</b> in the mishna that deems one liable for stating that he will worship an idol, the reference is <b>to</b> one who is <b>incited by others.</b> The reason for the difference is that one who makes the decision <b>on his own</b> is apt to <b>change his mind,</b> whereas one who is incited <b>by others is drawn after them</b> and is unlikely to change his mind.
