<b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>a minor</b> who dies, <b>from when,</b> i.e., from what stage, <b>does he come into the World-to-Come?</b> There is a dispute between <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>One</b> of them <b>says: From the moment that he is born, and</b> the other <b>one says: From the moment that</b> he begins to <b>talk.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>The one who says: From the moment that he is born,</b> derives it from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: “They shall come and shall declare His righteousness to a people that shall be born, that He has done this”</b> (Psalms 22:32). <b>And the one who says: From the moment that</b> he begins to <b>talk,</b> derives it from <b>that</b> which <b>is written: “Their seed shall serve Him; it shall be told of the Lord to the coming generation”</b> (Psalms 22:31), as from the moment he talks, he belongs to God.
<b>It was stated</b> that additional <i>amora’im</i> expressed opinions about the same matter. <b>Ravina says: From the moment that</b> the child <b>is conceived,</b> even before his birth, he can enter the World-to-Come, <b>as it is written: “Their seed shall serve Him”</b> (Psalms 22:31); even as seed the child merits to enter the World-to-Come. <b>Rabbi Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: From the moment that he is circumcised, as it is written: “I am poor and close to death from youth; I suffered your terrors [<i>emekha</i>], I am numb”</b> (Psalms 88:16). From the moment that one bears the mark that the Jewish people have due to fear of God [<i>eima</i>], he turns to God and he belongs to Him.
It is <b>taught in the name of Rabbi Meir: From the moment that</b> the child <b>will say amen, as it is stated: “Open the gates, so that the righteous nation that keeps faithfulness may enter”</b> (Isaiah 26:2). <b>Do not read</b> the verse as <b>“that keeps faithfulness [<i>shomer emunim</i>]”; rather,</b> read it as: <b>That says amen [<i>she’omer amen</i>].</b> From the moment he says amen, the gates to the World-to-Come open.

Daf 111a

<b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b>amen? Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> It is an acronym of the words: <b>God, faithful King [<i>El Melekh ne’eman</i>].</b>
§ With regard to the verse: <b>“Therefore, the netherworld has enlarged itself and opened its mouth without measure [<i>livli ḥok</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 5:14), <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> It is referring to <b>one who leaves even one statute [<i>ḥok</i>]</b> unfulfilled; the netherworld expands for him. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It is not satisfactory to</b> God, <b>their Master, that you said this about them,</b> as according to Reish Lakish’s opinion most of the Jewish people would be doomed to Gehenna. <b>Rather, even if one learned only one statute,</b> he has a share in the World-to-Come, and “<i>livli ḥok</i>” means one who has learned no statutes at all.
With regard to <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: “And it shall come to pass that in all the land, says the Lord, two parts shall be excised and die, but the third shall remain in it”</b> (Zechariah 13:8), <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> “The third” means that only <b>one-third</b> of the descendants <b>of Shem,</b> son of Noah, will remain, and everyone else will die. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to</b> Reish Lakish: <b>It is not satisfactory to</b> God, <b>their Master, that you said this about them,</b> that the overwhelming majority of the world will be destroyed. <b>Rather, even</b> as many as <b>one-third</b> of the descendants <b>of Noah,</b> one-third of the population of the world, will remain.
With regard to the verse: <b>“For I have taken you to Myself: And I will take out one of a city, and two of a family”</b> (Jeremiah 3:14), <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> The meaning of this <b>statement</b> is <b>as it is written,</b> that only individuals will be spared and the rest will be destroyed. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: It is not satisfactory to</b> God, <b>their Master, that you said this about them. Rather,</b> the merit of <b>one from the city causes the entire city</b> to <b>benefit, and</b> the merit of <b>two from a family causes the entire family</b> to <b>benefit</b> and be redeemed. Likewise, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav Kahana sat before Rav, and sat and said:</b> The meaning of <b>this statement</b> is <b>as it is written. Rav said to him: It is not satisfactory to</b> God, <b>their Master, that you said this about them. Rather,</b> the merit of <b>one from the city causes the entire city</b> to <b>benefit, and</b> the merit of <b>two from a family causes the entire family</b> to <b>benefit</b> and be redeemed.
The Gemara relates that Rav <b>saw that</b> Rav Kahana <b>was washing</b> the hair on <b>his head and</b> then <b>arose and sat before Rav.</b> Rav <b>said to</b> Rav Kahana: <b>“Nor shall it be found in the land of the living [<i>haḥayyim</i>]”</b> (Job 28:13). Rav Kahana thought that Rav addressed that verse to him and <b>he said to</b> Rav: <b>Are you cursing me?</b> Rav <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>a verse</b> that <b>I am saying</b> to remind you that <b>Torah will not be found in one who sustains [<i>meḥayye</i>] himself</b> in an indulgent manner <b>in its</b> study; rather, Torah is acquired through suffering and difficulty.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the few that are destined to be redeemed: <b>Rav Simai says</b> that <b>it is stated: “And I will take you to Me as a people”</b> (Exodus 6:7), <b>and</b> juxtaposed to that verse <b>it is stated: “And I will bring you</b> into the land” (Exodus 6:8). The Torah <b>compares their exodus from Egypt to their entry into the land; just as</b> during <b>their entry into the land</b> only <b>two of six hundred thousand</b> entered the land, as they all died in the wilderness except for Caleb and Joshua, <b>so too,</b> during <b>their exodus from Egypt,</b> in terms of the ratio, <b>only two of six hundred thousand</b> left Egypt and the rest died there. <b>Rava says: And likewise,</b> that will be situation <b>in the messianic era, as it is stated: “And she shall respond there, as in the days of her youth, and as in the day when she came up out of the land of Egypt”</b> (Hosea 2:17). The ultimate redemption and the exodus from Egypt are juxtaposed, indicating that in the messianic era too, only few will survive.
§ <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says: One time I entered Alexandria of Egypt. I found one old man and he said to me: Come and I will show you what my ancestors,</b> the Egyptians, <b>did to your ancestors,</b> the Jewish people. Some <b>of them they drowned in the sea,</b> some <b>of them they killed with the sword,</b> and <b>some of them they crushed in the buildings. And</b> it is <b>over this matter,</b> Moses’ protest of the afflictions suffered by the Jewish people, that <b>Moses, our teacher, was punished, as it is stated: “For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Your name, he has done evil to this people,</b> neither have You delivered Your people at all” (Exodus 5:23).
<b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to</b> Moses: <b>Woe over those who are gone and are no</b> longer <b>found; as several times I revealed Myself to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob as God Almighty [<i>El Shaddai</i>] and they did not question My attributes, and did not say to Me: What is Your name? I said to Abraham: “Arise, walk through the land in the length of it and in the breadth of it; for unto you I will give it”</b> (Genesis 13:17). Ultimately, <b>he sought a place to bury Sarah and did not find</b> one <b>until he purchased</b> it <b>for four hundred silver shekels, and he did not question My attributes</b> and did not protest that I failed to fulfill My promise to give him the land.
<b>I said to Isaac: “Sojourn in this land, and I will be with you and will bless you”</b> (Genesis 26:3). <b>His servants sought water to drink and they did not find</b> it <b>until they started a quarrel, as it is stated: “And the herdsmen of Gerar quarreled with Isaac’s herdsmen saying: The water is ours”</b> (Genesis 26:20), <b>and he did not question My attributes.</b>
<b>I said to Jacob: “The land upon which you lie, to you I will give it”</b> (Genesis 28:13). <b>He sought a place to pitch his tent and he did not find</b> one <b>until he purchased</b> it <b>for one hundred coins, and he did not question My attributes, and did not say to Me: What is Your name? And you,</b> Moses, <b>ask Me: What is Your name, initially,</b> after witnessing My greatness more than they ever did. <b>And now you say to Me: “Neither have You delivered Your people”</b> (Exodus 5:23). The verse then states: <b>“Now shall you see what I will do to Pharaoh”</b> (Exodus 6:1). One can infer: <b>The war with Pharaoh</b> and his downfall <b>you</b> shall <b>see, but you will not see the war with the thirty-one kings</b> in Eretz Yisrael, as you will not be privileged to conquer Eretz Yisrael for the Jewish people.
§ With regard to the verse: “And the Lord passed before him and proclaimed: The Lord, the Lord, compassionate and gracious God, slow to anger, abounding in loving-kindness and truth, extending loving-kindness to thousands of generations…<b>and Moses made haste and bowed his head toward the earth and prostrated himself”</b> (Exodus 34:6–8), the Gemara asks: <b>What did Moses see</b> in these attributes that caused him to hastily prostrate himself?
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamla says: He saw</b> the attribute of <b>slow to anger; and the Rabbis say: He saw</b> the attribute of <b>truth. It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said: He saw</b> the attribute of <b>slow to anger, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>When Moses ascended on high, he discovered the Holy One, Blessed be He, sitting and writing: Slow to anger.</b> Moses <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe,</b> is Your attribute of <b>slow to anger</b> only to be used <b>for the righteous?</b> God <b>said to him:</b> It is an attribute <b>even for the wicked.</b> Moses <b>said to Him: Let the wicked be doomed.</b> God <b>said to him: Now, you</b> will <b>see that you will need</b> this, as ultimately you will reconsider that statement.
<b>When the Jewish people sinned</b> in the sin of the spies and Moses asked God to forgive them, the Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said to</b> Moses: <b>Didn’t you say to Me</b> that the attribute of <b>slow to anger</b> is <b>for the righteous</b> alone? They are not worthy of atonement.

Daf 111b

Moses <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe, and isn’t this</b> what <b>You said to me:</b> It is an attribute <b>even for the wicked? And that is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And now, I pray You, let the power of my Lord be great, as You have spoken, saying”</b> (Numbers 14:17). Moses was repeating God’s promise with regard to His employment of the attribute of slow to anger.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Ḥagga was walking up the stairs in the school of Rabba bar Sheila. He heard a certain child who said: “Your testimonies are very sure; sanctity becomes Your house, Lord, for the length of days”</b> (Psalms 93:5). The phrase “length of days” is a reference to the attribute of slow to anger. <b>And juxtaposed to it</b> is the phrase: <b>“A prayer of Moses”</b> (Psalms 90:1), indicating that this chapter was also stated by Moses our teacher. Upon hearing those verses, Rabbi Ḥagga <b>said: Conclude from it</b> that it was the attribute of <b>slow to anger</b> that Moses <b>saw.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, is destined to be a crown on the head of each and every righteous</b> person, <b>as it is stated: “In that day shall the Lord of hosts be for a crown of glory, and for a diadem of beauty, unto the remnant of His people”</b> (Isaiah 28:5). <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>“For a crown of glory, and for a diadem of beauty”?</b> It means: A crown <b>for those who perform His will and</b> a diadem <b>for those who await His salvation.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that this extends <b>to everyone</b> in those categories. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Unto the remnant of His people,”</b> meaning that God will be a crown and a diadem <b>to one who</b> humbly <b>establishes himself like a remnant,</b> and does not conduct himself with self-importance.
The Gemara interprets a verse in Isaiah. <b>“And for a spirit of justice to him that sits in judgment and for strength to them who retaliate in battle to the gate”</b> (Isaiah 28:6). <b>“And for a spirit of justice”; this</b> is referring to <b>one who subdues his</b> evil <b>inclination</b> and prevents himself from sinning. <b>“To him that sits in judgment”; this</b> is referring to <b>one who judges a true judgment truthfully. “And for strength”; this</b> is referring to <b>one who overcomes his</b> evil <b>inclination. “Them who retaliate in battle”; this</b> is referring to one <b>who gives and takes</b> and engages <b>in the battle,</b> i.e., in the discourse <b>of Torah. “To the gate”</b> is referring to <b>those</b> Torah scholars <b>who arrive early and remain late within</b> the gates of <b>synagogues and study halls.</b>
<b>The attribute of justice said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, how do these</b> people, who possess these qualities, <b>differ from those</b> who engage in Torah study but lack these qualities? God <b>said to</b> the attribute of justice that those others do not receive the crown and diadem because: <b>“These also reel through wine, and stagger through strong drink…they stumble [<i>paku</i>] in judgment [<i>peliliyya</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 28:7). <b>And <i>puka</i></b> in this context is referring to <b>nothing other than Gehenna, as it is stated: “That this shall not be a cause of stumbling [<i>puka</i>] for you”</b> (I Samuel 25:31). <b>And</b> the term of <b><i>pelila</i></b> in the verse in Isaiah is referring to <b>nothing other than judges, as it is stated: “And he shall pay as the judges [<i>biflilim</i>] determine”</b> (Exodus 21:22). Those who lack the qualities listed in the previous verses are not worthy of the aforementioned reward.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The residents of an idolatrous city have no share in the World-to-Come, as it is stated: “Certain men, wicked persons, are gone out from your midst, and have subverted the inhabitants of their city, saying:</b> Let us go and let us worship other gods” (Deuteronomy 13:14). <b>And</b> idol worshippers <b>are not executed</b> as residents of an idolatrous city <b>unless its subverters are from that city and from that tribe, and unless most of</b> the inhabitants of the city <b>are subverted, and unless men subvert</b> the inhabitants of the city. If it occurs that <b>women or children subvert</b> the inhabitants of the city, <b>or that a minority of</b> the inhabitants of the city <b>were subverted, or that its subverters were from outside</b> the city and were neither residents of that city nor members of that tribe, <b>these</b> idol worshippers <b>are</b> judged <b>as individuals. And</b> to judge the inhabitants of a city <b>one requires two witnesses and forewarning for each and every one</b> who engaged in idol worship.
<b>This is a stringency with regard to individuals</b> who worship idols that is more stringent <b>than</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to multitudes</b> who worship idols: <b>As the individuals</b> who worship idols are executed <b>by stoning; therefore,</b> since there is a stringency with regard to their mode of execution, <b>their property is spared</b> and is inherited by their heirs. <b>And the multitudes</b> are executed <b>by the sword;</b> therefore, since there is a leniency with regard to their mode of execution, <b>their property is eliminated.</b>
From the verse: <b>“You shall smite the inhabitants of that city with the edge of the sword”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:16), it is derived that <b>the caravan of donkeys and the caravan of camels that move from place to place, these</b> donkey or camel drivers <b>save</b> the city. If they were residing in the city for a period, they could join the minority of permanent residents who were not subverted to idol worship in order to create a majority and prevent the destruction of the city and its contents.
<b>It is stated: “Destroy it utterly, and all that is in it and its animals, with the edge of the sword”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:16). <b>From here,</b> the Sages <b>stated: The property of the righteous,</b> who did not engage in idol worship, <b>that is inside</b> the city <b>is destroyed</b> with the rest of the city and its contents; but the property of the righteous <b>that is outside</b> the city <b>is spared. And</b> the property <b>of the wicked, whether</b> it is <b>inside</b> the city <b>or whether it is outside</b> the city, <b>these</b> items <b>are destroyed.</b>
<b>It is stated: “And you shall gather all of its spoils into the midst of its square”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:17). <b>If</b> the city <b>has no square, one creates a square for</b> the city in order to fulfill the mitzva as it is written. <b>If there was a square outside of</b> the city, <b>they bring it inside</b> the city by expanding the city wall to include the square.
<b>It is stated</b> in the continuation of the verse: <b>“And you shall burn it with fire, both the city and all its spoils, entirely for the Lord your God.”</b> The mishna infers: <b>“Its spoils,” but not the spoils of Heaven. From here</b> the Sages <b>stated: The consecrated</b> property <b>in it,</b> which was no longer the property of its inhabitants, <b>must be redeemed, and <i>terumot</i></b> are neither eaten nor burned; rather <b>they must</b> be left to <b>decay.</b> And <b>second tithe and sacred scrolls</b> that were in the city <b>must be interred.</b>
With regard to the phrase: <b>“Entirely [<i>kalil</i>] for the Lord your God,” Rabbi Shimon says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, says: If you implement judgment on an idolatrous city, I ascribe you</b> credit <b>as though you have sacrificed an entirely [<i>kalil</i>] burnt offering before Me.</b>
It is written: <b>“And it shall be a heap forever”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:17), meaning: The idolatrous city <b>shall not be converted</b> even into <b>gardens and orchards;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> From the end of that verse: <b>“It shall not be built again,”</b> it is derived: To restore it <b>to the way it was</b> before destruction, <b>it</b> may <b>not</b> be <b>built; but it may be converted into gardens and orchards.</b> The next verse states: <b>“And there shall cleave nothing of that which was devoted to your hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:18). This teaches that <b>as long as the wicked</b> exist <b>in the world,</b> there is <b>wrath in the world;</b> once <b>the wicked are eliminated from the world, wrath leaves the world.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> an interpretation of the verse: “Certain men, wicked persons, are gone out from your midst, and have subverted the inhabitants of their city saying: Let us go and let us worship other gods that you have not known” (Deuteronomy 13:14). From the term <b>“are gone out”</b> it is derived that these <i>halakhot</i> apply only if <b>they,</b> the subverters themselves, subverted the residents, <b>but not agents</b> whom they designated to subvert. From the term <b>“men”</b> it is derived that <b>men</b> in the plural means <b>no less than two. Alternatively,</b> it is derived: <b>Men, but not women; men, but not children.</b>
The phrase <b>“wicked persons [<i>benei veliyya’al</i>]”</b> is an abbreviation of <i>banim beli ol</i>, meaning: <b>Sons who have cast off the yoke of Heaven from their necks.</b> From the term <b>“from your midst”</b> it is derived that these <i>halakhot</i> apply only to a city located in the center of the country, <b>but not</b> to a city located <b>on the border.</b> From the phrase <b>“inhabitants of their city”</b> it is inferred: <b>But not inhabitants of another city.</b> The term <b>“saying”</b> alludes to the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> in order to convict them <b>one requires witnesses and forewarning for each and every one</b> who worshipped idols.
<b>It was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One divides one city into</b> the tribal territory of <b>two tribes; and Reish Lakish says: One does not divide one city into</b> the tribal territory of <b>two tribes. Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> from the mishna, which states: <b>Unless its subverters are from that city and from that tribe; what, is it not that although its subverters are from that city, if they are from that tribe, yes,</b> they render the city an idolatrous city, and <b>if not, no,</b> they do not render the city an idolatrous city? <b>Conclude from it: One divides one city into</b> the tribal territory of <b>two tribes,</b> as otherwise, by definition, a resident of that city is a member of that tribe.
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No,</b> even if a city is not divided between two tribes, the scenario in the mishna is possible in a case <b>where</b> the property in the city <b>fell to him as an inheritance</b> from the family of his mother, who was from a different tribe. <b>Alternatively,</b> it is possible in a case <b>where they gave him</b> that property <b>as a gift.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>raised an objection to</b> the opinion of Reish Lakish from a verse written with regard to the cities designated for the Levites: <b>“Nine cities from those two tribes”</b> (Joshua 21:16). <b>What, is it not</b> that those nine cities were equally divided; <b>four-and-a-half from this</b> tribe, <b>and four-and-a-half from that</b> tribe, <b>and conclude from it</b> that <b>one divides one city into</b> the tribal territory of <b>two tribes?</b> The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No,</b> those nine cities were divided in this manner: <b>Four</b> cities <b>from this</b> tribe <b>and five</b> cities <b>from that</b> tribe.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, let</b> the verse <b>state explicitly</b> from which tribe the additional city was taken.

Daf 112a

The Gemara comments: The matter presents <b>a difficulty</b> with the opinion of Reish Lakish.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If the inhabitants of an idolatrous city <b>subverted themselves</b> to idol worship and were not subverted by others, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Since <b>the Merciful One states: “And have subverted,”</b> perhaps it may be inferred: <b>But not if they subvert themselves; or perhaps even</b> if <b>they subverted themselves</b> to idol worship, the city can be deemed an idolatrous city.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution of the dilemma from the mishna: If <b>women or children subvert</b> the inhabitants of the city, these idol worshippers are judged as individuals. <b>Why</b> is that so? <b>Let</b> their status <b>be</b> considered <b>as</b> though <b>they subverted themselves.</b> Apparently, if the inhabitants subverted themselves the city is not deemed an idolatrous city. The Gemara rejects this proof: These cases are not comparable, as <b>these,</b> who subverted themselves, <b>are drawn after their own</b> initiative and worship idols wholeheartedly, and therefore perhaps the city is rendered an idolatrous city. <b>Those,</b> who are subverted by women and children, <b>are drawn after women and children</b> and are not committed to idol worship, and therefore, perhaps the city is not rendered an idolatrous city.
§ The mishna teaches that a city is not deemed an idolatrous city <b>unless most of</b> the inhabitants of the city <b>are subverted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How do we act</b> in order to determine if most of the inhabitants have been subverted? <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> The court <b>judges</b> each inhabitant suspected of idol worship, <b>and</b> if he is found liable <b>imprisons</b> him in a jail, and it <b>judges and imprisons</b> each succeeding idolater until a majority of the city has been convicted. <b>Ulla said to him:</b> That will <b>result in you delaying justice for those</b> already sentenced and awaiting execution, and it is prohibited to delay justice. <b>Rather, Ulla says:</b> The court <b>judges</b> each inhabitant <b>and stones</b> him if he is found liable, then <b>judges and stones</b> each succeeding idolater until half of the city is found guilty, and all future convicted idolaters are executed by the sword.
<b>It was stated</b> that there is a parallel amoraic dispute. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The court <b>judges and stones</b> the idolater, then <b>judges and stones</b> each succeeding idolater. <b>And Reish Lakish says: One increases</b> the number of <b>courts for them</b> so that all the inhabitants of the city can stand trial at the same time and the means of their execution will be determined with no delay of justice.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥama bar Yosei say</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says</b> that it is written: <b>“And you shall take that man or that woman out…</b>to your gates” (Deuteronomy 17:5), from which it is derived: <b>You take a man and a woman out to your gates</b> and they are judged by the local court, <b>but you do not take the entire city out to your gates;</b> instead, they stand trial before the Great Sanhedrin. <b>Rather,</b> the procedure is that <b>one increases</b> the number of <b>courts for them and</b> those courts <b>analyze their cases,</b> and when they conclude that a majority of the inhabitants are guilty of idolatry they are not sentenced; instead, <b>we take them to the High Court [Sanhedrin] and</b> the court <b>issues</b> the <b>verdict of</b> the idolaters <b>and executes them.</b>
§ It is written: <b>“You shall smite the inhabitants of that city</b> with the edge of the sword, destroy it utterly, and all that is in it and its animals, with the edge of the sword” (Deuteronomy 13:16). <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The caravan of donkeys and the caravan of camels that move from place to place,</b> that <b>lodged in</b> the city <b>and were subverted with it, if they had stayed there thirty days they</b> are executed <b>by the sword and their property is destroyed.</b> If they had stayed there <b>less than that, they</b> are executed <b>by stoning,</b> as individual idolaters, <b>and their property is spared.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How long shall</b> one <b>be in the city and</b> as a result, his status <b>will be like</b> that of <b>the residents of the city</b> with regard to giving charity and paying taxes? He is obligated if he remained there <b>twelve months,</b> and not thirty days. <b>Rava says:</b> This contradiction is <b>not difficult,</b> and it may be resolved: <b>This</b> period of twelve months is the period required <b>to become</b> one <b>of the citizens of the city; this</b> period of thirty days is the period required <b>to become</b> one <b>of the inhabitants of the city.</b>
<b>And</b> so <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one prohibited by a vow from deriving benefit from the citizens of the city, if there is a person who had stayed there twelve months, it is prohibited</b> for the one for whom deriving benefit is forbidden <b>to derive benefit from him.</b> If a person had stayed there <b>less than that, it is permitted</b> for the one for whom deriving benefit is forbidden <b>to derive benefit from him.</b> With regard to one prohibited by a vow from deriving benefit <b>from the inhabitants of the city, if</b> there is a person who <b>had stayed there thirty days, it is prohibited</b> for the one for whom deriving benefit is forbidden <b>to derive benefit from him.</b> If a person had stayed there <b>less than that, it is permitted</b> for the one for whom deriving benefit is forbidden <b>to derive benefit from him.</b> In the context of an idolatrous city, the reference is to the inhabitants of the city, which includes anyone who had stayed there for thirty days.
It is written: <b>“Destroy it utterly, and all that is in it”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:16). <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to that which is written: <b>“Destroy it utterly, and all that is in it”;</b> this serves <b>to exclude the property of the righteous that is</b> located <b>outside</b> the city, which is not destroyed. <b>“And all that is in it”;</b> this serves <b>to include the property of the righteous that is</b> located <b>inside</b> the city; it is also destroyed. It is stated: “And you shall gather all of its spoils into the midst of its square” (Deuteronomy 13:17). From the term <b>“its spoils”</b> it is derived: <b>But not the spoils of Heaven;</b> all consecrated property is excluded. The phrase <b>“and</b> you shall gather <b>all of its spoils”</b> serves <b>to include the property of the wicked that is</b> located <b>outside</b> the city; it is also destroyed.
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: For what</b> reason <b>does the Torah say</b> that <b>the property of the righteous that is in it shall be destroyed?</b> Why must they suffer for the sins of others? The reason is: <b>Who caused</b> the righteous <b>to live in</b> this city inhabited by wicked people? It is <b>their property</b> that tied them to this city; <b>therefore, their property is destroyed. The Master said</b> that the phrase <b>“and you shall gather all of its spoils”</b> serves <b>to include the property of the wicked that is</b> located <b>outside</b> the city; it is also destroyed. <b>Rav Ḥisda says: And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to</b> property that can be <b>gathered into</b> the city.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says: Deposits of the inhabitants of an idolatrous city are permitted,</b> i.e., they are not destroyed. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that Rav Ḥisda is referring to property belonging to inhabitants <b>of another city and</b> that property <b>is</b> deposited <b>within</b> the idolatrous city, it is <b>obvious that</b> the deposits are <b>permitted,</b> as the deposits are <b>not “its spoils”;</b> they are the property of others. <b>But rather,</b> say that Rav Ḥisda is referring to property <b>belonging to</b> the inhabitants of the idolatrous city, <b>and</b> it <b>is</b> deposited <b>within another city.</b> If so, the status of that property should be like any other property belonging to the inhabitants of the idolatrous city; <b>if</b> it is property <b>that</b> can be <b>gathered into</b> the city, <b>why are</b> the deposits <b>permitted?</b> It was already established that the property of the wicked is destroyed. <b>And if</b> it is property that <b>cannot</b> be <b>gathered into</b> the city, <b>didn’t</b> Rav Ḥisda already <b>say once</b> that this property is not burned?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> Rav Ḥisda is <b>actually</b> referring to property belonging to inhabitants <b>of another city that is deposited within</b> the idolatrous city; <b>and what are we dealing with here?</b> It is a case <b>where</b> an inhabitant of the idolatrous city <b>assumes</b> financial <b>responsibility for</b> the deposit in his possession. <b>Lest you say: Once he assumes</b> financial <b>responsibility for</b> the deposit in his possession, the status of the deposit is <b>like</b> that of <b>his own</b> property and it should be destroyed, therefore Rav Ḥisda <b>teaches us</b> that deposits are permitted and not destroyed.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says: An animal</b> that is <b>half</b> the property <b>of an idolatrous city and half</b> the property <b>of another city</b> is <b>forbidden.</b> By contrast, with regard to <b>dough</b> that is <b>half</b> the property <b>of an idolatrous city and half</b> the property <b>of another city,</b> the half that belongs to the other city is <b>permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the difference between them? The Gemara explains: <b>An animal is like an entity that is not divided,</b> as it is possible to eat part of an animal only through the slaughter of the entire animal. Therefore, if any portion of the animal is forbidden, the entire animal is forbidden. <b>Dough is like an entity that is divided.</b> Therefore, the fact that one portion of the dough is forbidden does not render the entire dough forbidden.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>the animal of an idolatrous city, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>; <b>is ritual slaughter effective</b> at least <b>in purifying it from</b> the ritual impurity <b>of an unslaughtered animal carcass?</b> If the animals of the city are killed but not ritually slaughtered, they are impure with the impurity of a carcass and transmit impurity by means of contact as well as if they are lifted. Will the ritual slaughter of those animals prevent the transmission of that impurity? Is it so that since <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And its animals, <b>with the edge of the sword,”</b> indicating that <b>it is no different</b> if <b>one ritually slaughtered</b> the animal, and <b>it is no different</b> if <b>one killed</b> the animal in another way, its status is that of a carcass and it transmits impurity? <b>Or perhaps, since one ritually slaughtered</b> the animal, <b>ritual slaughter is effective. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Yosef raises a dilemma: What is</b> the status of <b>the hair of pious women</b> in the idolatrous city; must it be destroyed? <b>Rava says:</b> Is that to say <b>that the hair of wicked</b> women is <b>forbidden</b> and must be destroyed? <b>“And you shall gather…and you shall burn”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:17), <b>is written,</b> and it is derived: An item <b>that is lacking,</b> i.e., that requires, <b>only gathering and burning</b> must be destroyed, <b>excluding this</b> hair, <b>which is lacking detaching, gathering, and burning.</b> Therefore, even the hair of a wicked woman is not forbidden.
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> This dilemma is raised <b>with regard to a wig.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the wig <b>is attached to her body,</b> its status is <b>like</b> that of <b>her body.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this dilemma <b>is necessary</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the wig <b>is hanging on a peg. Is</b> its status <b>like</b> that of <b>the property of the righteous inside</b> the city <b>and</b> therefore <b>it is destroyed, or perhaps, since she enters and exits</b> with the wig, its status is <b>like</b> that of <b>a garment,</b> and it is not destroyed? This dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
With regard to the verse: <b>“And you shall gather all of its spoils into the midst of its square”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:17), <b>the Sages taught:</b> If the city <b>has no square, it does not become an idolatrous city,</b> as it does not fulfill the criterion mandated by the verse; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> If the city <b>has no square, one creates a square for</b> the city. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yishmael, <b>holds “its square” indicates</b> a square that existed <b>from the outset. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that <b>“its square”</b> can <b>also indicate</b> a square that was created <b>now.</b>

Daf 112b

§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the consecrated</b> property <b>in it must be redeemed. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 14:5): <b>If there were offerings of the most sacred order in it,</b> if they were animals <b>consecrated for</b> sacrifice on <b>the altar, they shall die;</b> one causes their death. Items <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance must be redeemed, and <i>terumot</i> must</b> be left to <b>decay, and second tithe and sacred scrolls must be interred. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> That is not so; rather, the term: <b>“Its animals”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:16), serves to <b>exclude a firstborn animal and</b> animal <b>tithe,</b> as they never belonged to the idolatrous city. The term: <b>“Its spoils”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:17), serves to <b>exclude consecrated money and tithe money.</b>
The Gemara proceeds to analyze the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: If there were offerings of the most sacred order in it,</b> if they were animals <b>consecrated for</b> sacrifice on <b>the altar, they shall die.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But why shall they die? They should graze until they become unfit, and</b> then <b>they should be sold and their value should be allocated for</b> communal <b>gift</b> offerings.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> They shall die, as it is written: <b>“The offering of the wicked is an abomination”</b> (Proverbs 21:27), and it is unacceptable for sacrifice on the altar. <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> They shall die because the animal <b>is the property of its owner</b> and is not exclusively consecrated property. <b>And</b> the reason it is considered the property of the owner is that <b>here,</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring <b>to offerings</b> with regard to <b>which one bears</b> financial <b>responsibility for their</b> replacement. That responsibility renders the status of these consecrated animals like that of his property. <b>And</b> this <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says:</b> An offering with regard to which one bears financial responsibility for its replacement <b>is the property of</b> its <b>owner.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> one may infer that <b>the first clause is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> The Gemara suggests a new explanation: Rather, the animals that shall die are <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, and</b> the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says: Offerings of lesser sanctity are the property of</b> their <b>owner.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>But offerings of the most sacred order, what</b> shall be done with them? <b>They shall be redeemed.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>rather than teaching</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: Items <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance must be redeemed, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>distinguish and teach</b> a distinction <b>within</b> the category of animals consecrated for sacrifice on the altar <b>itself,</b> as follows: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that animals shall die, <b>said?</b> It is stated <b>with regard to offerings of lesser sanctity; but with regard to offerings of the most sacred order, they shall be redeemed.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since there is</b> among offerings of the most sacred order the case of the sin-offering whose owners were killed in the idolatrous city, rendering the animal <b>a sin-offering whose owners have died, which is left to die,</b> that distinction <b>is not clear-cut for</b> the <i>tanna</i>, as offerings of the most sacred order are not always redeemed. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> preferred to cite a distinction without exceptions.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, Rabbi Yoḥanan does not say</b> his explanation of the <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> due to the fact <b>that it is written: “The offering of the wicked is an abomination,”</b> and he bases his explanation on that verse. <b>But Reish Lakish, what is the reason he does not say</b> his explanation of the <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan?</b> The Gemara answers: He could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>when we say: “The offering of the wicked is an abomination,” this statement</b> applies in a case <b>where</b> the offering <b>is in its unadulterated form. But here, since</b> if they were to redeem it, <b>it</b> would have <b>changed</b> and would no longer be the animal of the wicked itself, but rather an animal purchased with the proceeds of the redemption of the original, <b>it</b> would have <b>changed,</b> and it would no longer be an abomination.
§ The <i>baraita</i> continues. <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the term <b>“its animals”</b> serves to <b>exclude a firstborn animal and</b> animal <b>tithe.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> animals <b>are we dealing with? If we say</b> that Rabbi Shimon is speaking <b>with regard to unblemished animals,</b> like all other offerings <b>they are the spoils of Heaven</b> and not the spoils of the inhabitants of the city. <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Shimon is speaking <b>with regard to blemished</b> animals, which belong to their owners. If so, <b>they are the spoils of</b> the city, and what is the reason that Rabbi Shimon says that there is no obligation to destroy these animals?
<b>Ravina says: Actually,</b> Rabbi Shimon is speaking <b>with regard to blemished</b> animals, <b>and</b> his statement should be understood as follows: The mitzva is to destroy that <b>which is eaten as its animals,</b> i.e., as the property of an inhabitant of an idolatrous city. <b>Excluded are those</b> firstborn and tithe animals, <b>which,</b> even when blemished, <b>are not eaten as its animals; rather,</b> they are eaten <b>as firstborn and tithe</b> animals. They are given as gifts to priests, and <b>are</b> considered <b>the spoils of Heaven.</b>
<b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>disputes</b> the statement <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel says: Everything is sacrificed and everything is redeemed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is he saying?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what <b>he is saying: Any</b> offering <b>that is sacrificed</b> on the altar <b>when it is unblemished and is redeemed when it is blemished is excluded from</b> the term “its <b>spoils,”</b> since it is considered the spoils of Heaven. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>any</b> offering <b>that is sacrificed</b> on the altar <b>when it is unblemished and is not redeemed when it is blemished, e.g., a firstborn</b> animal <b>and</b> animal <b>tithe, is derived from</b> the term “its <b>animals,”</b> as they are not the city’s animals and they are not included in the city’s property.
§ The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b><i>Terumot</i> must</b> be left to <b>decay. Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> that is still <b>in the possession of an Israelite,</b> who has not yet given it to a priest. <b>But</b> concerning <b><i>teruma</i></b> that is already <b>in the possession of a priest</b> who lives in the idolatrous city, <b>since it is his property, it shall be burned.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef raises an objection</b> from the mishna: <b>Second tithe and sacred scrolls must be interred. But isn’t</b> the status of <b>second tithe in the possession of an Israelite like</b> that of <b><i>teruma</i> in the possession of a priest,</b> as he may partake of it and benefit from it in Jerusalem; <b>and</b> nevertheless, <b>it is taught:</b> They <b>must be interred? Rather, if</b> the statement of Rav Ḥisda <b>was stated, this is what was stated: Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> that is already <b>in the possession of a priest</b> who lives in the idolatrous city, as even though it is his property, it maintains the sanctity of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But <i>teruma</i></b> that is still <b>in the possession of an Israelite,</b> which is not his property at all, <b>shall be given to a priest who is in another city,</b> and should not be left to decay.
<b>We learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>there: Second-tithe dough is exempt from</b> having <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> separated since it is property belonging to the Most High; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>liable</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from second-tithe dough. <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is <b>with regard to second tithe in Jerusalem; as Rabbi Meir holds: Second-tithe</b> produce <b>is property</b> belonging <b>to the Most High,</b> but the Torah permitted its owners to partake of it in Jerusalem. Since it is the property of Heaven, one is exempt from separating priestly gifts. <b>And the Rabbis hold: It is non-sacred property</b> from which one is liable to separate <i>ḥalla</i>. <b>But</b> with regard to second-tithe dough <b>in the outlying areas, everyone agrees that one is exempt</b> from separating <i>ḥalla</i>, as outside of Jerusalem it is prohibited to partake of it.
<b>Rav Yosef raises an objection</b> from the mishna: <b>Second tithe and sacred scrolls must be interred. What are we dealing with? If we say</b> that the reference is to second tithe <b>in Jerusalem, can</b> Jerusalem <b>be an idolatrous city? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ten matters were stated with regard to Jerusalem, and this is one of them: It does not become an idolatrous city. Rather,</b> apparently the reference is to second tithe <b>in a different city</b> that was rendered an idolatrous city, <b>and</b> before it was so rendered <b>one took</b> the second-tithe produce <b>up into</b> Jerusalem. The Gemara asks: In that case, <b>wasn’t</b> the produce <b>admitted</b> by <b>the walls</b> of Jerusalem, making it no longer associated with the idolatrous city, and it should therefore be permitted to partake of it?
<b>Rather,</b> is the reference in the mishna <b>not</b> to second-tithe produce <b>in an outlying area? And it is taught:</b> They <b>must be interred.</b> Apparently, second-tithe produce is not the property of Heaven; it belongs to an inhabitant of the idolatrous city. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, actually,</b> the reference in the mishna is to second-tithe produce <b>in a different city, and</b> before it was rendered an idolatrous city <b>one took</b> the second-tithe produce <b>up into</b> Jerusalem. <b>And what are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> that second-tithe produce <b>became ritually impure.</b> Since it is prohibited to partake of it, there is no alternative to interment.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let him redeem it</b> in Jerusalem, <b>as Rabbi Elazar says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to second-tithe</b> produce <b>that became impure, that one may redeem it even in Jerusalem?</b> As <b>the verse states:</b> “And if the way is too long for you <b>so that you are unable to carry it [<i>se’eto</i>]…</b>and you shall turn it into money” (Deuteronomy 14:24–25). <b>And <i>se’et</i></b> means <b>nothing other than eating, as it is stated: “And he took portions [<i>masot</i>] from before him”</b> (Genesis 43:34), indicating that second-tithe produce that cannot be eaten, whether due to the distance from Jerusalem or due to its impurity, may be redeemed. The Gemara answers: <b>What are we dealing with here?</b> It is not a case where the second-tithe produce became impure; rather, it is a case <b>where</b> an item <b>purchased</b> with second-tithe money became impure.

Daf 113a

The Gemara challenges: <b>And let him redeem</b> that which was purchased with second-tithe money and became ritually impure, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 3:10): An item <b>that is purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money</b> and <b>that became ritually impure shall be redeemed.</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says:</b> An item that is purchased with second-tithe money and that became ritually impure <b>shall be buried,</b> and it may no longer be redeemed. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> and the mishna is referring to an item purchased with second-tithe money that became ritually impure, <b>why</b> did the mishna cite this <i>halakha</i> <b>specifically</b> in the case of <b>an idolatrous city?</b> The same would hold true <b>even</b> in cities <b>in general as well,</b> as in Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, the <i>halakha</i> there too is that the item is buried.
<b>Rather, actually,</b> the case in the mishna is <b>with regard to pure</b> second-tithe produce of an idolatrous city that was taken into Jerusalem, <b>and</b> it is a case <b>where the walls</b> of Jerusalem then <b>fell. And</b> this <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rava, <b>as Rava says:</b> The capacity of the <b>wall</b> of Jerusalem to enable one <b>to partake</b> of second-tithe produce is <b>by Torah law.</b> By contrast, the capacity of the <b>wall</b> of Jerusalem <b>to admit</b> second-tithe produce, in the sense that once it enters Jerusalem the produce assumes the status of the property of the Most High and may no longer be redeemed, is <b>by rabbinic law. And</b> the case <b>where the Sages issue the decree</b> that entry into Jerusalem admits the produce is <b>where the wall is</b> intact; however, in a case <b>where the wall is not</b> intact, <b>no,</b> the Sages did not issue a decree, and the second tithe remains the spoils of the idolatrous city.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Sacred scrolls must be interred.</b> The Gemara comments: The <i>halakha</i> cited in <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Any city in which there is even one <i>mezuza</i> is not rendered an idolatrous city, as it is stated: “And you shall burn it with fire, both the city and all its spoils, entirely</b> for the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 13:17). <b>And</b> in a city <b>where there is a <i>mezuza</i> it is not possible</b> to burn all its spoils, <b>as it is written: “You shall not do so to the Lord your God”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:4), from which it is derived that it is prohibited to destroy any item upon which the name of God appears.
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: The Holy One, Blessed be He, says:</b> If you implement judgment on an idolatrous city, I ascribe you credit as though you have sacrificed an entirely burnt offering before Me, and Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yosei HaGelili disagree as to whether one may convert the ruins of the idolatrous city into gardens and orchards. The Gemara posits: <b>Let us say</b> that it is <b>with regard to</b> the statement <b>that Rabbi Avin says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ile’a</b> says that these <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree, as Rabbi Avin says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ile’a says: Anywhere that you find a generalization</b> formulated <b>as a positive mitzva</b> followed by <b>a detail</b> formulated <b>as a prohibition, one does not deduce</b> from it that the generalization includes only the detail <b>based on</b> the hermeneutical principle of <b>a generalization and a detail;</b> rather, one interprets them as two independent <i>halakhot</i>.
On that basis, say that the dispute is <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Avin, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Avin.</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili holds that the positive mitzva: “And it shall be a heap forever,” and the succeeding prohibition: “It shall not be built again” (Deuteronomy 13:17), are independent mitzvot. The result is that the city must remain a heap and may not be converted into gardens and orchards. Rabbi Akiva employs the hermeneutical principle and deduces that the generalization “and it shall be a heap forever” means only that “it shall not be built again,” but converting the ruins of the idolatrous city into gardens and orchards is permitted.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Avin, and here, they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>holds</b> that the term <b>“again” indicates</b> that it is <b>entirely</b> prohibited to rebuild it at all. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that the term <b>“again”</b> indicates that <b>it is not built to</b> be <b>as it was, but it</b> may be <b>converted into gardens and orchards.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>there were trees in</b> the city, if they are <b>detached</b> from the ground, they are <b>forbidden</b> and must be burned as the spoils of an idolatrous city; if they are <b>attached</b> to the ground they are <b>permitted,</b> i.e., they are not destroyed. By contrast, trees <b>of another city, whether detached or attached,</b> are <b>forbidden.</b> The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> is the <i>baraita</i> referring with the phrase: <b>Another city? Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The reference is to <b>Jericho, as it is written: “And the city shall be devoted,</b> it and all that is in it, <b>to the Lord…And Joshua charged them at that time by oath, saying: Cursed be the man before the Lord, that rises up to build this city Jericho; he shall lay its foundation with his firstborn, and with his youngest son shall he set up the gates of it”</b> (Joshua 6:17, 26).
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that this includes a prohibition <b>not</b> to build <b>Jericho</b> even after changing its name <b>to the name of another city, and not</b> to build <b>another city</b> after giving it the <b>name</b> of <b>Jericho, as it is written: “Hiel the Bethelite built Jericho; with Abiram, his firstborn, he laid its foundation, and with his young son Segub set up its gates”</b> (I Kings 16:34).
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the death <b>of Abiram, his firstborn, the wicked, it was not</b> incumbent <b>upon him to learn</b> not to build Jericho, as Abiram’s death could be attributed to chance. But <b>with</b> the death of <b>Segub his young son, it was</b> incumbent <b>upon him to learn</b> that it was due to Joshua’s curse that they died.
The Gemara asks: <b>What did Abiram and Segub do</b> that they are characterized as wicked, and <b>what is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: From</b> the death of <b>Abiram, his firstborn, that wicked man</b> Hiel <b>should have learned about</b> the cause of the death of <b>Segub his young</b> son. <b>By inference from that</b> which <b>is stated: “With Abiram, his firstborn,” do I not know that Segub</b> was <b>his young</b> son? Rather, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “His young son Segub”?</b> It <b>teaches that he gradually buried</b> all his sons <b>from Abiram through Segub,</b> and he should have suspected that Joshua’s curse caused the deaths.
<b>Ahab was</b> Hiel’s close friend and <b>groomsman. He and Elijah came to inquire about</b> Hiel’s <b>welfare</b> in <b>the house of mourning [<i>bei tamya</i>].</b> Hiel <b>sat and said: Perhaps when Joshua cursed, this</b> is what <b>he cursed: Not</b> to build <b>Jericho</b> even after changing its name <b>to the name of another city, and not</b> to build <b>another city</b> after giving it the <b>name</b> of <b>Jericho. Elijah said to him: Yes,</b> that is the curse. Ahab <b>said to</b> Elijah: <b>Now the curse of Moses is not fulfilled, as it is written: “And you go astray and worship</b> other gods,” <b>and it is written: “Then the Lord’s anger will flare against you, and He will close the heavens,</b> and there will be no rain” (Deuteronomy 11:16–17). <b>And that man,</b> referring to himself, <b>established</b> an object of <b>idol worship on each and every furrow</b> in the kingdom of Israel, <b>and the rain</b> is so plentiful that <b>it does not allow him to go and worship it;</b> will <b>the curse of his student, Joshua, be fulfilled?</b>
The verse relates Elijah’s reaction: <b>Immediately: “And Elijah the Tishbite, who was of the inhabitants of Gilead, said</b> to Ahab: <b>As the Lord God of Israel lives,</b> before whom I stand, <b>there shall not be dew or rain</b> these years, but according to my word” (I Kings 17:1). Elijah <b>prayed for mercy and they gave him the key to rainfall</b> enabling him to dictate when it would rain, <b>and he arose and went.</b>
It is written about Elijah: <b>“And the word of the Lord came to him, saying: Go from here, and turn eastward, and hide yourself by Wadi Cherith…And the ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning”</b> (I Kings 17:2–3, 6). The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> did they bring him bread and meat? <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> They brought it <b>from the slaughterhouse of Ahab.</b> And it is written: <b>“And it came to pass after some days, that the wadi dried up, because there was no rain in the land”</b> (I Kings 17:7). <b>Since</b> God <b>saw that there is suffering in the world</b> and Elijah was insensitive to it, <b>it is written: “And the word of the Lord came to him, saying: Arise, go to Zarephath”</b> (I Kings 17:8–9), to initiate a chain of events that would lead Elijah to return the key to rainfall to God.
<b>And it is written: “And it came to pass after these matters, that the son of the woman, the mistress of the house, became sick”</b> (I Kings 17:17). Elijah <b>prayed for mercy,</b> for God <b>to give him the key to the resurrection of the dead. They said to him</b> from Heaven: <b>Three keys were not</b> typically <b>passed to an agent:</b> The key <b>to a woman in childbirth,</b> the key <b>to rainfall, and</b> the key <b>to the resurrection of the dead.</b> You already have the key to rainfall; do you also request the key to the resurrection of the dead? People <b>will say: Two</b> keys <b>are in the possession of the student and one</b> key <b>is in the possession of the Master. Bring</b> Me <b>this</b> key to rainfall, <b>and take this</b> key to the resurrection of the dead. Due to Elijah’s request, he was forced to revoke his oath, <b>as it is written: “Go, appear before Ahab; and I will give rain”</b> (I Kings 18:1).
<b>A certain Galilean taught before Rav Ḥisda:</b> There is <b>a parable</b> for the actions <b>of Elijah; to what is this matter comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to a man who slammed his door and lost his key.</b> Elijah first prevented the rain from falling, and then no longer had possession of the key to enable it to fall again.
<b>Rabbi Yosei of Tzippori taught: Father Elijah,</b> a deferential and affectionate characterization for Elijah the prophet,

Daf 113b

was <b>difficult.</b> Elijah <b>was accustomed to coming</b> and revealing himself <b>before</b> Rabbi Yosei each day. <b>He was obscured from him for three days and did not come. When he came</b> again, Rabbi Yosei <b>said to him: Why did the Master not come?</b> Elijah <b>said to him:</b> You denigrated me when <b>you called me difficult.</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>said to</b> Elijah: <b>This</b> example <b>that is before us</b> illustrates the point, <b>as my Master was</b> being <b>difficult</b> by not coming during those days.
§ The mishna teaches with regard to the verse: <b>“And there shall cleave nothing of that which was devoted to your hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:18), <b>as long as the wicked</b> exist <b>in the world,</b> there is <b>wrath in the world.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who are</b> these <b>wicked</b> people mentioned in the mishna? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> They are <b>thieves.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When <b>a wicked</b> person <b>comes into the world, wrath comes into the world, as it is stated: “When the wicked comes into the world, contempt also comes, and with ignominy, reproach”</b> (Proverbs 18:3). When <b>a wicked</b> person <b>is eliminated from the world, good comes into the world, as it is stated: “And when the wicked perish there is jubilation”</b> (Proverbs 11:10). When <b>a righteous</b> person <b>passes from the world, evil comes into the world, as it is stated: “The righteous perishes and no man lays it to heart; and merciful men are taken, none understand that due to the evil the righteous is taken”</b> (Isaiah 57:1) When <b>a righteous</b> person <b>comes into the world, good comes into the world</b> with him, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to Noah: <b>“This is one who shall comfort us for our work and the toil of our hands”</b> (Genesis 5:29).
